{dearmad_cordoba}Duke of Cordoba \nRuler of Andalusia
{dearmad_cordoba_desc}Named Duke of Cordoba and ruler of Andalusia.\n\nDescription:\nCordoba has been known since the Phoenician colonization. According to Strabo and Ptolemy, Cordoba is the center of the Turdetan tribe. Captured in the Second Punic War (218–201 BC) by the Romans. Under Augustus - the main city of the province of Betica. Conquered by vandals, Byzantium, Visigoths, and in 711 - by Arab troops. With 756 it was the capital of the Cordoba Emirate, and from 929 it was the Cordoba Caliphate. In the X century. reached its peak, became one of the centers of education and science, when it had up to 1 million inhabitants, many palaces, mosques, caravanserais and was the center of Arab science, poetry and art. With the collapse of the Cordoba Caliphate in 1031, Cordoba remained independent only until 1070, when it was subordinated to the Emir of Seville.
{dearmad_cordoba_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+10% to tax revenues. \n+1 to the morale of all troops on the battlefield. \n+5% to public order as governor. \n+1 to popularity.
¬----------------------
{idearmad_cordoba}Caliph of Cordoba \nRuler of Andalusia
{idearmad_cordoba_desc}Named by the Caliph of Cordoba and ruler of Andalusia.\n\nDescription:\nCordoba has been known since the Phoenician colonization. With the collapse of the Cordoba Caliphate in 1031, Cordoba remained independent only until 1070, when it was subordinated to the Emir of Seville.

{king_salamanca}Earl of Salamanca \nLord of Salamanca
{king_salamanca_desc}Named Earl and Ruler of Salamanca.\n\nDescription:\nThe city was significant already in the time of the Iberians. It is referred to as the Wakken city of Helmantica when it was captured in 217 BC. e. Hannibal. Under the Romans there was an important crossing over the Tormes River on the “Silver Road” (Via de la Plata) from Asturica Augusta to the port of Cadiz. Under the Visigoths in the 7th century, this settlement (then called Salmantica) had its own bishop. After the Arab-Berber conquest (712), the department was moved to the city of Oviedo. The Christian population succeeded the Arabs during the Reconquista of 1087-1102.
{king_salamanca_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues. \n+5% to legality. \n-5% to corruption. \n+1 to fidelity. \n+1 to nobility.
¬----------------------

¬------------------------------------------------- -----------------
{king_murcia}Earl of Murcia \nLord of Murcia
{king_murcia_desc}Named Earl and ruler of Murcia.\n\nDescription:\nIt is widely believed that the name of the city comes from Latin. Myrtea or Murtea, meaning "land of myrtle." According to the second version, Murcia comes from Murtia, which means "the settlement of Murtius" (Murtius is a common Roman name). There is also an opinion that the name comes from lat. Murtae, Mulberry. The city on the site where Murcia is now located was founded by the Cordoban emir Abd ar-Rahman II in 825 under the name Medinat Mursiya. City planners created an extensive network of irrigation canals near Segura, which led to the expansion of the agricultural sector. In the XII century, the geographer Al-Idrisi described Murcia as a densely populated and well-fortified city. After the collapse of the Cordoba caliphate in 1031, Murcia fell into the hands of the rulers who ruled in Almeria, Toledo and Seville. After the collapse of the Almoravid state, Muhammad ibn Mardanish made Murcia the capital of an independent kingdom. During this period, Murcia became a prosperous city, famous for ceramic products that were exported to Italy. Silkworm and paper production, the first in Europe, also developed in Murcia.
{king_murcia_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues. \n+1 to agriculture (increases the city’s income from agriculture).
¬----------------------
{iking_murcia}Emir of Murcia \nLord of Murcia

{king_oporto}Earl of Porto \nLord Douro-Litoral
{king_oporto_desc}Named Earl of Porto and ruler of Douro-Litoral.\n\nDescription:\nPorto history begins around 300 BC. e. from the Proto-Celtic and Celtic peoples, the earliest known inhabitants of these places. Ruins of this period were discovered in several areas. In the area of ​​modern Porto, there was also a settlement of galleks. The Roman commander Decimus Junius Brutus Callaic conquered the city in about 136 BC. The Romans called the city Portus Cale. In 540, the Visigoths made the city the residence of the bishop and built a fortress. Porto came under the control of the Moors during their invasion of the Iberian Peninsula in 711. In 868, conquered by Count Vimara Pires. From 997 to 1050 again under the rule of the Moors. Since 1092, the city during the reconquest was finally liberated and part of the kingdom of Leon, as part of the county of Portucale, which is inherited by Henry of Burgundy, from which the history of independent Portugal begins in 1096.
{king_oporto_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to income from taxes. \n+10% to income from trade. \n+1 to fidelity. \n+5% to public order as governor. \n+1 to popularity.
¬----------------------

¬------------------------------------------------- -----------------
{dearmad_lisbon}Duke of Lisbon \nLuft of Lusitania
{dearmad_lisbon_desc}Named the Duke of Lisbon and ruler of Lusitania.\n\nDescription:\n During the Neolithic period, the region was inhabited by pre-Celtic tribes who erected religious and funerary monuments, megaliths, dolmens and menhirs. The Celts arrived here in the 1st millennium BC. After the victory over Carthage, the Iberian Peninsula fell under the rule of Rome. Olissipo, like most cities in the West of the empire, became the center of the spread of Christianity. After the collapse of the Roman Empire, raids of barbarians began. 711 years, Lisbon was captured by Muslims. The conquerors, mostly Berbers and Arabs erected many mosques and houses, restored the city wall and established administrative control. Islam was the official religion, Christians were allowed to live while maintaining their religion in the status of Zimmis, for which they came It was necessary to pay a special tax, however, in all other matters — property rights, debt obligations and contracting — Christians and Jews were equal with Muslims. In 1108, Lisbon was recaptured and occupied by the Norwegian crusaders led by Sigurd I on their way to the Holy. 1111 was captured by the Almoravid Moors. In 1147 during the Reconquista, the Crusaders, led by Alfonso I of Portugal, besieged and recaptured Lisbon.
{dearmad_lisbon_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+10% to tax revenues. \n+1 to fidelity.\n+5% vision radius (increases visibility range). 
¬----------------------

Islam was the official religion, Christians were allowed to live while maintaining their religion in the status of Zimmis, for which they came It was necessary to pay a special tax, however, in all other matters — property rights, debt obligations and contracting — Christians and Jews were equal with Muslims. In 1108, Lisbon was recaptured and occupied by the Norwegian crusaders led by Sigurd I on their way to the Holy. 1111 was captured by the Almoravid Moors. In 1147 during the Reconquista, the Crusaders, led by Alfonso I of Portugal, besieged and recaptured Lisbon.
{odearmad_lisbon_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+10% to tax revenue. \n+1 to fidelity.\n+5% vision radius (increases visibility range). 
¬------------------------------------------------- -----------------
{dearmad_staufen}Duke of Ulm \nLord of Swabia
{dearmad_staufen_desc}Named Duke of Ulm and ruler of Swabia.\n\nDescription:\nHere there was a palace of kings from the Carolingian dynasty. In it 854 King Louis of Germany published a document in which the name of the city was first mentioned. However, the foundation of the city is usually referred to XI. During the reign of the Salic Dynasty, Ulm became the most important city of the Duchy of Swabia. From here, in December 1076, he went on his penitent trip to Canossa Henry IV in order to pray for forgiveness from Pope Gregory VII and again receive the right to be emperor. Two years later about Mr. handed over his palace along with all the duchy to his brother-in-law, Frederick I Staufen, who could take possession of it only in 1098 after a long struggle with the second anti-duke Bertold I von Reinfelden and his successor Bertold II. The kings of the Staufen dynasty intended to make Ulm an oppressor During the war for the throne with the Dynasty, the Duke Heinrich the Proud of this dynasty destroyed the city twice to the ground. Not a destroyed church, on the site of which the Ulm Cathedral was erected. When the Staufen for a long time came to power, the city began to develop rapidly.
{dearmad_staufen_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+1 to cruelty. \n+5% to the rule of law. \n-5% to corruption.

{dearmad_nuremburg}Duke of Nuremberg \nLord of Bavaria
{dearmad_nuremburg_desc}Named the Duke of Nuremberg and ruler of Lower Bavaria.\n\nDescription:\n Emperor Konrad II of the Salic Dynasty built a royal court on the left bank of the Pegnitz River. In the middle of the 11th century, a castle with a representative hall begins to be erected on a high rock on the right bank of the river. Castle servants and merchants settled on the lands south of the castle, forming the basis of the future city. Due to its strategically advantageous location on a rocky hill dominating a fairly flat plain, the Nuremberg fortress became a fortified residence her German kings and was of great importance for the whole of the Holy Roman imperii.Pri Conrad III of, 1140 began the expansion of the fortress by the extension of the new castle, completed in 1180 by Emperor Frederick I Barbarossa Frederick Barbarossoy.Pri the castle became one of the Kaiserburg-time imperial residence.

When Conrad III, in 1140, the expansion of the fortress by adding a new castle began, completed in 1180 by Emperor Frederick I Barbarossa. Under Frederick Barbarossa, this castle becomes Kaiserburg - one of the imperial temporary residences.

{king_salzburg}Duke of Salzburg \nLord of Upper Bavaria
{king_salzburg_desc}Named the Duke of Salzburg and ruler of Upper Bavaria.\n\nDescription:\nThe settlement on the site of modern Salzburg has existed since the Neolithic period. Later there was a Celtic settlement that was conquered by the Romans in the 1st century BC. e. Juvavum colony was formed in the area of ​​modern Salzburg, which became one of the main settlements of the Roman province of Norik. In 477, the leader of the Orugians, Odoacer, at the head of the allied army of the Rugians, Gepids, Goths and Gerul, according to legend, took the city of Yuvavum and executed St. Maximus and 50 In 696, the Bavarian Duke granted these lands to Bishop Rupert (later ranked as a saint) .He founded here about 700 years two monasteries, the male Benedictine Abbey of St. Peter and the convent of Nonnberg. In 739, the city became the episcopal re identity, at the end of the 8th century under the bishops of Virginia and Arno, it became the center of missionary activity of the Christian church in the Alpine region. Since that time, the city bears the name Salzburg, which owes many salt deposits in the district. In 798, the Salzburg bishops were promoted to status and they became archbishops. In 1077, on the mountain above the city, the Hohensalzburg fortress was built, which was subsequently rebuilt many times.
{king_salzburg_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenue. \n+2 to piety.
¬----------------------

{dearmad_frankfurt}Duke of Frankfurt \nLord of Franconia
{dearmad_frankfurt_desc}Named the Duke of Frankfurt and ruler of Franconia.\n\nDescription:\nRoman settlements in the region of Römer tentatively appeared in the first century AD. There is an assumption that the name of the city district of Bonames comes from the Latin bona mansion ("good halt"), and Nida County was a Roman civilian capital. The name Frankfurt is derived from the word Franconofurd, a Germanic tribe of Franks. The German word Furt denotes a shallow place on the river, suitable for fording. The first mention of Frankfurt dates back to 794, when Charlemagne began the creation of the empire and convened Frankfurt Cathedral, although Alemans and Franks inhabited this area for a long time. The city played an important role in the Holy Roman Empire. Starting in 885, German kings and emperors were chosen in Frankfurt and crowned in Aachen. Known for the Cathedral, better known as the "Imperial Cathedral". Since the 1150s, the first mention of the Frankfurt Fair.
{dearmad_frankfurt_effects_desc}\nAnch Bonus:\n+10% tax income.\n+5% trade income.\n+5% legality.\n-5% corruption.\n+1 to piety.\n+ 5% to public order as a governor.\n+1 to popularity.\n+5% to movement range of a commander without an army.

{dearmad_innsbruck}Margrave of Innsbruck \nTyrol Ruler
{dearmad_innsbruck_desc}Named by the Margrave of Innsbruck and ruler of Tyrol.\n\nDescription:\n15 years under Emperor Augustus, Roman troops entered the Alpine region under the command of his adoptive sons Tiberius and Druz, who conquered the area up to the Danube. The Tyrol region has since become an important transit region on the North-South trade route. In the year 200 CE under the emperor Septimius Severus, on the way to Augsburg, the fortified Veldidena fortress was founded. After the collapse of the Western Roman Empire, the region of Tyrol was conquered by the Allemans and then the Ostrogoths. In 550, the ancestors of modern Bavarians in the process of resettlement of peoples occupied the Valley of Inn and the whole territory fell under the rule of the Duchy of Bavaria. Having penetrated the Brenner Pass to South Tyrol, the Bavarians, who had mixed up with the local population at that time, encountered the Slavs living in the Lienz region. Further Christianization of the region continued Irish and Anglo-Saxon missionaries. The name Innsbruck was first mentioned in 1180. How the city of Innsbruck was founded in 1234, by order of the Duke of Otto Meransky.
{dearmad_innsbruck_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus:\n+5% tax income.\n+1 command when commanding infantry.\n+1 morale of all troops on the battlefield.

{dearmad_vienna}Duke of Vienna \n Governor of Austria
{dearmad_vienna_desc}Named the Duke of Vienna and ruler of Austria.\n\nDescription:\nThe history of Vienna as a settlement begins in the middle of the 1st century AD with the beginning of the construction of the outpost of the 15th Roman Legion on the territory of today's old city. Civil constructions began to grow around the military camp. At the beginning of the 5th century AD e. Vindobona survived a severe fire, and by the end of the 5th century the Romans left these places. In the 9th century, the Carolingians who came from the west build a small castle in the north-eastern part of the former Roman camp and the church of St. Ruprecht that has been preserved to this day. By the middle of the XII century, Vienna became the residence of the Austrian Dukes of Babenberg. In 1155, Duke Henry II Babenberg built a house on Am Hof ​​Square. In the years 1137-1147. The first church of St. Stephen was built.
{dearmad_vienna_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to income from taxes. \n+5% to income from trade. \n+1 to fidelity.\n+5% to public order as a governor. \n+1 to popularity.

The newly founded city began to develop rapidly, as it turned out to be a convenient center of the Duke's possessions, so vast that the nickname “Rich” was entrenched to him. His Burgundian possessions passed to the Holy Roman Emperor Frederick II, while Bern (and Zurich) was declared an imperial city.

{dearmad_metz}Duke of Metz \nLord of Upper Lorraine
{dearmad_metz_desc}The Duke of Metz and the ruler of Upper Lorraine were named.\n\nDescription:\n Shortly before the Roman invasion, there was the main settlement of the Celtic tribe of media experts, who gave the name to the city. After the capture by the Romans, the city of Divodur stood at this place. In 451, the city was taken by Attila. With the collapse of the Frankish Empire, it became the capital of Lothar's possessions. Between 1180 and 1210, the Metz flourished as a free imperial city, then became one of the three bishoprics that divided France and Germany.

{king_cologne}Duke of Cologne \nPower of Westphalia
{king_cologne_desc}The Duke of Cologne and the ruler of Westphalia are named.\n\nDescription:\n38 BC the castrum Ubiorum Mark Vipsaniy Agrippa, commander of Emperor Augustus is founded in this fortified village, surrounded by dense forests, in the family of commander Agripp Germanica which is considered to be the founding mother of the city of Cologne. The city began to develop rapidly. Later, Cologne becomes the center of the glass industry, a mint appears, chic villas are being built outside the city walls, which will be destined to stand for hundreds more years. Muscovite nobility. By this time communities of Christians and Jews were already functioning in Cologne, after the Edict of Milan, Bishop of Cologne Matern took part in the First Ecumenical Council. Since the 4th century, the situation has been turbulent and the victim of Franks raids. In 454, Franks conquered Cologne. In 508, he left for the kingdom. Merovingov. In 795, Charlemagne proclaims Cologne to be Archbishopric; the Norman attack in 881; in the middle of the 10th century, Emperor Otto Veli s assigns his brother, the archbishop of Cologne Bruno, the title of Duke Lotaringskogo.Koln starting to become one of the most important cities of medieval Evropy.Vozvodyatsya Catholic churches, trade flourishes.
{king_cologne_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenue. \n+2 to piety.
¬----------------------
{iking_cologne}Caliph of Cologne \nPower of Westphalia
{iking_cologne_desc}Named by Caliph of Cologne and ruler of Westphalia.\n\nDescription:\n38 BC the castrum Ubiorum Mark Vipsaniy Agrippa, commander of Emperor Augustus is founded in this fortified village, surrounded by dense forests, in the family of commander Agripp Germanica which is considered to be the founding mother of the city of Cologne. The city began to develop rapidly. Later, Cologne becomes the center of the glass industry, a mint appears, chic villas are being built outside the city walls, which will be destined to stand for hundreds more years. {dearmad_antwerp}Duke of Antwerp \nLord of Lorraine
{dearmad_antwerp_desc}Named the Duke of Antwerp and ruler of Lower Lorraine.\n\nDescription:\nThe exact date of the beginning of the history of Antwerp is unknown, most likely it happened no earlier than the 7th century. The Duke of Brabant granted free trade in Antwerp to English, Venetian and Genoese merchants had a beneficial effect on the popularity of the local fair. At first, Antwerp competed with nearby Hertogenbosch and Bergen, then - with Leuven and Brussels. From the decline of Bruges in the 12th century to the Eighty Years War, Antwerp remained the richest trading city not only in the Netherlands, but throughout Northern Europe.
{dearmad_antwerp_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenue. \n+10% to trade revenue.

{king_groningen}Earl of Greningen \nRuler of Friesland
{king_groningen_desc}Named Count of Greningen and ruler of Friesland.\n\nDescription:\nThe city was founded on the northernmost point of the Hondsrüg district. The first mention of Groningen in a written source dates back to 1040. Cultural layers are found on the territory of the city that testify to the presence of people there in 3950–3720. BC. In the 13th century, when Groningen became a major trading center, its inhabitants built the city walls, emphasizing its increasing importance at that time. The city exerted a strong influence on the surrounding lands and contributed to bringing into uniformity the dialects that existed in the district.
{king_groningen_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues. \n+5% to legality. \n-5% to corruption.

{dearmad_hamburg}Duke of Hamburg \nLord of Saxony
{dearmad_hamburg_desc}Named the Duke of Hamburg and ruler of Saxony.\n\nDescription:\nThe settlement that gave rise to the city of Hamburg allegedly arose at the mouth of Alster in the 8th century. In 808, Emperor Charles the Great built the Hammburg fortress to protect it from the Western Slavs. that this place was a Slavic shrine (“the city of God”), which, among other things, is indicated by its name in the Vandal chronicles as “the city of God.” In 810 the fortress was taken by the Welsh and practically destroyed. In 834, the ar the residence of the archbishop was called, repeatedly besieged and devastated by the Slavs, Danes and Normans. In the XII century, due to the rapid development of trade in northern Europe, the importance of the Elbe River significantly increased as an important transport artery. On May 7, 1189, Emperor Frederick I Barbarossa granted Hamburg significant trade privileges, including allowing Hamburg to collect customs duties on goods transported along the Elbe. One of the first to enter Hamburg was the Hanseatic League created in the Middle Ages in Northern Europe. SW and became the most important port in the North more.Gorod served as a transit point in the transportation of grain, cloth, furs, herring, spices, wood and metals.
{dearmad_hamburg_effects_desc}\nAnch Bonus:\n+10% tax income.\n+1 Nobility.\n+1 General's health.\n+1 defensive command during an assault.\n+5% public order in role governor.\n+1 popularity.

One of the first to enter the Hamburg created in the Middle Ages in Northern Europe is the Hanseatic Union and became the most important port on the North Sea. The city served as a transshipment point in the transportation of grain, fabrics, furs, herring, spices, wood and metals.

{dearmad_prague}Prince of Prague \nRuler of Bohemia
{dearmad_prague_desc}Named Prince of Prague and ruler of the Czech Republic.\n\nDescription:\nFrom the first Slavic settlements in the 9th century, Prague developed, constantly increasing in size, uniting neighboring settlements and villages. Prague was the capital city of the Czech Principality until the end of the 12th century. A fortress (Prague Castle) and the first Christian church appeared on the cliff on the left bank of the Vltava. Soon, around 950, another fortress was founded on the right bank a little upstream - Vysehrad and the Cathedral of Peter and Paul. In the 10th century, Prague was already the center of the Przemylovych state; on the right bank there was already a settlement - Stare Mesto. In medieval times, only a settlement that had fortress walls could be considered a city.
{dearmad_prague_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to income from taxes. \n+5% to income from trade. \n-1 from fidelity.

{dearmad_arhus}Duke of Aarhus \nLord of Jutland
{dearmad_arhus_desc}Named Duke of Aarhus and ruler of Jutland.\n\nDescription:\nAt the beginning of the VIII century, settlements of people who migrated from the territory of continental Scandinavia begin to appear on the east coast of Jutland. Approximately in 770, the Vikings founded a settlement on the banks of Aarhus Bug Bay. Its favorable geographical position contributed to its rapid development, thanks to its favorable location, the city became a center of trade between the German countries and the Baltic countries. In 948, the city was first mentioned in written sources under the names Aros, Arus, Aru¬sius, which meant "estuary". This is due to the fact that by 951 the city became an important Catholic center in northern Europe and the residence of the first bishop appointed by Otto the Great. In the middle of the XI century, under the rule of Knud II, a coin was minted here, as well as Aarhus receives the privileges of a trading city. Thus, by the beginning of the XII century, Aarhus is a large trading city and is the center of crafts and jewelry.
{dearmad_arhus_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenue. \n+1 to piety.

{king_hamar}Jarl Roskilde \nLord of Zealand
{king_hamar_desc}Named Jarl Roskilde and ruler of Zealand.\n\nDescription:\nRosskill is a city in Denmark located in the southern part of the Roskilde fjord, which is the southern branch of the Isefjord overlooking the Kattegat Strait. According to Adam of Bremen and Saxon, Gramatica was founded in 980, King Harald Sinezub, on a hill above the harbor, he built a wooden church dedicated to the Holy Trinity, as well as a royal residence nearby. In 1020, King Knud in Roskilde established a bishopric, giving it a high national status and transferring large territories in the region into the hands of the clergy. It is not clear when Roskilde became a trading city, but he definitely enjoyed trading privileges. These privileges were firmly established when the city council of Roskilde granted market city status to other cities in Zealand. Back in 1070, Adam von Bremen called Roskilde “the largest city in Zealand”, and in the 12th – 13th centuries it was perhaps the largest and most important city in Denmark, numbering With around 2,600 farms.
{king_hamar_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to income from taxes. \n+5% to income from trade. \n+2 to piety.

{king_lund}Jarl Lund \nSkone Ruler
{king_lund_desc}Named Jarl Lund and ruler of Skåne.\n\nDescription:\nLund is located in the largest agricultural region of Sweden, in the south-west of Skåne and not far from the Öresund Strait. The exact date of the foundation of Lund is not known, but it is believed that it was founded in 990, when these lands belonged to Denmark. The population from the settlement of Uppokra moved to the place where Lund is located today, which happened at the behest of King Sven Viloborodogo. Lund's location, on a hill and across a ford, provided significant defensive advantages over Uppakra, located on the highest point of a large plain. At the beginning of the 12th century, the city became the residence of the archbishop, whose power extended to all of Scandinavia, and even Gardar in Greenland. Also, a cathedral was founded during this period, after which the region became the Christian center of Northern Europe.
{king_lund_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenue. \n+1 to piety.
¬----------------------

{king_kalmar}Jarl Kalmar \nRuler of Småland 
{king_kalmar_desc}Named Jarl Kalmar and ruler of Smoland.\n\nDescription:\nKalmar is one of Sweden's oldest cities. Located in the south-east of the country, on the shores of the Baltic Sea. It is not known exactly when Kalmar received city rights, but the area in which it is located now was inhabited a long time ago, in written sources the mention of the Kalmar Strait and the settlement on its banks dates back to the 11th century, but it is unclear whether it was a city or just small village. It is believed that the city formed around Kalmar Castle, which, in turn, was built in the XII century around a watchtower designed to protect against pirates and Danes. Being a port city, Kalmar was known as one of the richest cities in Sweden and a center of trade, mainly exported by iron, traders from Germany.
{king_kalmar_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus:\n+10% tax income.\n+5% trade income.\n+5% vision radius (increases visibility). 
¬----------------------
{iking_kalmar}Emir Kalmar \nRuler of Småland 
{iking_kalmar_desc}Named Emir Kalmar and ruler of Smoland.\n\nDescription:\nKalmar is one of Sweden's oldest cities. Located in the south-east of the country, on the shores of the Baltic Sea. It is not known exactly when Kalmar received city rights, but the area in which it is located now was inhabited a long time ago, in written sources the mention of the Kalmar Strait and the settlement on its banks dates back to the 11th century, but it is unclear whether it was a city or just small village. It is believed that the city formed around Kalmar Castle, which, in turn, was built in the XII century around a watchtower designed to protect against pirates and Danes. Being a port city, Kalmar was known as one of the richest cities in Sweden and a center of trade, mainly exported by iron, traders from Germany.
{iking_kalmar_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus:\n+10% tax income.\n+5% trade income.\n+5% vision radius (increases visibility). 
¬----------------------
{oking_kalmar}Squid strategist \nRuler of Småland 
{oking_kalmar_desc}Named Kalmar's Strategist and ruler of Smoland.\n\nDescription:\nKalmar is one of Sweden's oldest cities. Located in the south-east of the country, on the shores of the Baltic Sea. It is not known exactly when Kalmar received city rights, but the area in which it is located now was inhabited a long time ago, in written sources the mention of the Kalmar Strait and the settlement on its banks dates back to the 11th century, but it is unclear whether it was a city or just small village. It is believed that the city formed around Kalmar Castle, which, in turn, was built in the XII century around a watchtower designed to protect against pirates and Danes. Being a port city, Kalmar was known as one of the richest cities in Sweden and a center of trade, mainly exported by iron, traders from Germany.
{oking_kalmar_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus:\n+10% tax income.\n+5% trade income.\n+5% vision radius (increases visibility).

{king_skara}Jarl Skara \nLord of Westergötland
{king_skara_desc}Named Jarl Skara and ruler of Westergötland.\n\nDescription:\nScara is located in western Sweden, in the historical province of Westergötland. The city was founded in 988, the rise of which dates back to the middle of the 11th century, after the transfer of the center of the first Christian bishopric to Sweden. In subsequent centuries, monasteries and other churches will be built in the city. One of which is the Skara Cathedral, dating from the 12th century and the first monastery of the Dominican Order, called the monastery of St. Olav. After which it becomes the cultural and church center of the province of Westergötland.
{king_skara_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues. \n+2 to piety.
¬----------------------

{dearmad_oslo}Jarl Oslo \n Governor of Eastern Norway
{dearmad_oslo_desc}Named Jarl Oslo and ruler of Eastern Norway.\n\nDescription:\nAccording to the arch of the sagas of the Icelandic skald Snorri Sturluson, Oslo founded Harrald III in 1048. Initially, the city consisted of two fortresses - a royal and bishop's castle. Within the city walls there were 9 churches and one hospital, about 400 wooden houses of merchants and artisans. Oslo soon became the cultural center of eastern Norway. Halvard Webjernsson became the patron saint of the city and is depicted on the city press. At the end of the XII century, the Abbey of Khoveday was built. Churches and abbeys became the main owners of large tracts of land that were important for the economic development of the city, especially before the Black Death. In the Middle Ages, Oslo reached its heights during the reign of Hakon V Saint. He began to build the Akershus fortress, and was also the first king to live permanently in the city, which helped make Oslo the capital of Norway.
{dearmad_oslo_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus:\n+5% tax income .\n+1 to loyalty. \n+1 to cruelty. 
¬----------------------

Churches and abbeys became the main owners of large tracts of land that were important for the economic development of the city, especially before the Black Death. He began to build the Akershus fortress, and was also the first king to live permanently in the city, which helped make Oslo the capital of Norway.

{king_eikundarsund}Jarl Egersunda \n Governor of Southwest Norway
{king_eikundarsund_desc}Named Jarl Egersunda and ruler of Southwest Norway.\n\nDescription:\nEgersund is a city in the county of Rogaland. The city is located along the southwestern coast of Norway, along the strait that separates the mainland from the island of Eigerä. The name "Egersund" comes from the Old Norse name of the Eigeröy Strait and the mainland, which was called Eikundarsund. The name comes from the rich deposits of oaks. It is known that before the Battle of Havrsfjörd, tribes of rugs prevailed in this region, who formed the first proto-state formations in this territory. After the victory in which Harald I began the process of uniting Norway. The immediate result of the battle was the establishment of King Harald’s power over the whole of western Norway. During the Christianization of Norway, old folklore from Egersund says that an altar was installed by locals where people made sacrifices to the ancient Scandinavian gods.
{king_eikundarsund_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus:\n+10% to tax revenue.\n-1 piety. 
¬----------------------

{king_bergen}Jarl Bergen \nLord of Northwest Norway
{king_bergen_desc}Named Jarl Bergen and ruler of Northwest Norway.\n\nDescription:\nBergen is a city located on the North Sea in the Midthorland region, protected from the sea by the islands of Askoy, Holsnøy and Sutra. The city was founded in 1070 on the banks of the Vogenskaya Bay by King Olaf III, four years after the end of the Viking era in England at the Battle of Stamford Bridge. However, a commercial village existed here from the years 1020-1030. The main export commodity traded from Bergen was dried cod from the northern Norwegian coast, which began around 1100. Dried fish was the main reason that the city became one of the largest shopping centers in Northern Europe. A few decades later, the stone castle of Bergenhus was erected from the northern edge of the bay. In the XII-XIII centuries, Bergen gradually assumed the functions of the capital of Norway. as the first city where an elementary central administration was created. The city cathedral was the site of the first royal coronation in Norway in the 1150s, and continued to receive royal coronations throughout the 13th century.
{king_bergen_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus:\n+5% tax income.\n+1 loyalty.\n+1 morale of all troops on the battlefield.\n+1 general health. 
¬----------------------

Dried fish was the main reason that the city became one of the largest shopping centers in Northern Europe. A few decades later, the stone castle of Bergenhus was erected from the northern edge of the bay. In the XII-XIII centuries, Bergen gradually assumed the functions of the capital of Norway. as the first city where an elementary central administration was created. The city cathedral was the site of the first royal coronation in Norway in the 1150s, and continued to receive royal coronations throughout the 13th century.
{iking_bergen_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus:\n+5% tax income.\n+1 loyalty.\n+1 morale of all troops on the battlefield.\n+1 general health.

{king_trondem}Jarl Trondheim \nLord of Northern Norway
{king_trondem_desc}Named Jarl of Trondheim and ruler of Northern Norway.\n\nDescription:\nTrondheim is a city located at the mouth of the Nidelva River on the banks of the Trondheim Fjord. The village was founded in 997 by Olaff Tryggvason, he also built a church and his halls here. After Oluff's death, Trondheim served as the capital of Norway during the Viking era and as a trading post. However, it is known that people lived in this region for thousands of years, where all free people gathered at the mouth of the Nidelva River. In 1070, the Nidarossian Cathedral and the residence of the archbishop were built here, located side by side in the middle of the city. The cathedral was the most important Christian pilgrimage site in Northern Europe along which routes from Oslo to southern Norway, as well as from Jamtland and Vermland Sweden.
{king_trondem_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues. \n+1 to fidelity.
¬----------------------

{dearmad_stockholm}Jarl of Norrköping \nRuler of Estergötland 
{dearmad_stockholm_desc}Named Jarl of Norrköping and ruler of Östergötland.\n\nDescription:\nNorköping is a city in Sweden located on the Mutala River, not far from its confluence with the Baltic Sea. The exact time of the foundation of the settlement is not known, it is only known that in the XII century a church dedicated to Olaf, the patron saint of Norway, is mentioned here. And also, what the city residents caught salmon in the river and used rapids on the Mutala river as a source of energy for mills. Norrköping will receive city status at a later time and will become the site of several battles.
{dearmad_stockholm_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to income from taxes. \n+5% to income from trade. \n+1 to fidelity.

{king_uppsala}Jarl Uppsala \nRuler of Uppeland
{king_uppsala_desc}Named by Jarl Uppsala and ruler of Uppeland.\n\nDescription:\nUppsala was the main pagan center in Sweden. The cult significance of Uppsala originated on a huge temple, the last flowering of which occurred at the end of the 11th century. Uppsala was a large village, the eastern part of which is probably , was the center of crown property through which the king exercised power. From early times until the Middle Ages in late February – early March, the All-Swedes Ting was held in Old Uppsala. According to Uppland’s Law, the king announced about the gathering of Leydang, the teams and commanders were determined. The Ting was held in conjunction with the pagan holiday Disablot and the annual Disating Fair. With the coming to power of Olaf II the Most Holy, the sacrifices ceased and the temples were destroyed, although the final baptism of Uppsala did not happen before the reign of Inge I. In order to eradicate the pagan According to the orders of the pope, Uppsala was made a strong Christian center. In the middle of the 12th century, the first archdiocese in Sweden was located in Uppsala and the first Cistercian monk Stephen of mon steal Alvastra Abbey.
{king_uppsala_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+10% to tax revenues. \n+1 to general’s health. \n+1 to piety.
¬----------------------

With the coming to power of Olaf II the Most Holy, sacrifices cease and the temples are destroyed, although the final baptism of Uppsala did not happen before the reign of Inge I. In order to eradicate pagan traditions, at the behest of the pope, made Uppsalu a strong Christian center. In the middle of the 12th century, the first archdiocese in Sweden was located in Uppsala and the first Cistercian monk Stephen of Mo Alvastra

The Ting was held in conjunction with the pagan holiday Disablot and the annual Disating Fair. {king_visby}Jarl Visby \nRuler of Gotland 
{king_visby_desc}Named Jarl Visby and ruler of Gotland.\n\nDescription:\nVisby is the main city of the Swedish island of Gotland. Visby's earliest history is unclear, but as you know, around 900 AD it was a shopping center. In the Viking era, the inhabitants of Gotland were actively trading, from the XI century. Gotlanders took a leading position in the intermediary trade in the Baltic Sea between Eastern and Western Europe. On the coast of the island there was a system of harbors called the Gothic coast. On the site of one of these harbors, the city of Visby subsequently arose. The control of the Swedish kings over the island, apparently, was rather weak. Thanks to the island's favorable location, the Gotlanders continued to dominate Baltic trade. Gotland merchants had their own guest house in Novgorod, and in the middle of the XII concluded an agreement with the Saxon Duke Heinrich Leo regarding the trading regime in Gotland and in Holstein.
{king_visby_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to income from taxes. \n+5% to income from trade. \n+1 to cruelty.
¬----------------------

{dearmad_helsinki}Prince Turku \n Governor of Southwest Finland
{dearmad_helsinki_desc}Named Prince of Turku and Southwest Finland.\n\nDescription:\nThe valley between the Aurajoki and Vähäjäoki rivers is a busy shopping intersection inhabited by villagers - the intersection of water and land trade routes. In 1155, the Swedish king Eric IX made his first crusade in Finland. Together with the king, the Catholic bishop of Uppsala, presumably an Englishman, Henry, arrived in the country, who led the missionary diocese in the provinces of Satakunta and Häme. Chronicles call St. Heinrich the first bishop of Finland. According to the legend of St. Henry in 1156, Bishop Henry was killed by the pagan Finnish Lally, and his body was buried in the church of Nausiainen. At the end of the XII century, the Novgorodians, together with the Karelians, made a sea voyage to Finland against the Swedes, and literally took the uneducated city of Turku. The status of the city of Turku was received much later on the basis of letters from Pontiff Gregory IX.
{dearmad_helsinki_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus:\n+5% tax income.\n+1 loyalty. \n+10% to vision radius (increases visibility range).\n+5% to movement range of a commander without an army. 
¬----------------------
{idearmad_helsinki}Emir Turku \n Governor of Southwest Finland
{idearmad_helsinki_desc}Named Emir Turku and Southwest Finland.\n\nDescription:\nThe valley between the Aurajoki and Väääjoki rivers is a busy trade intersection inhabited by villagers - the intersection of water and land trade routes. In 1155, the Swedish king Eric IX made his first crusade in Finland. Together with the king, the Catholic bishop of Uppsala, presumably an Englishman, Henry, arrived in the country, who led the missionary diocese in the provinces of Satakunta and Häme. Chronicles call St. Heinrich the first bishop of Finland. According to the legend of St. Henry in 1156, Bishop Henry was killed by the pagan Finnish Lally, and his body was buried in the church of Nausiainen. At the end of the XII century, the Novgorodians, together with the Karelians, made a sea voyage to Finland against the Swedes, and literally took the uneducated city of Turku. The status of the city of Turku was received much later on the basis of letters from Pontiff Gregory IX.
{idearmad_helsinki_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus:\n+5% tax income.\n+1 loyalty. \n+10% to vision radius (increases visibility range).\n+5% to movement range of a commander without an army. 
¬----------------------

In 1155, the Swedish king Eric IX made his first crusade in Finland. Together with the king, the Catholic bishop of Uppsala, presumably an Englishman, Henry, arrived in the country, who led the missionary diocese in the provinces of Satakunta and Häme. Chronicles call St. Heinrich the first bishop of Finland. According to the legend of St. Henry in 1156, Bishop Henry was killed by the pagan Finnish Lally, and his body was buried in the church of Nausiainen. At the end of the XII century, the Novgorodians, together with the Karelians, made a sea voyage to Finland against the Swedes, and literally took the uneducated city of Turku. The status of the city of Turku was received much later on the basis of letters from Pontiff Gregory IX.

¬------------------------------------------------- -----------------
{dearmad_stettin}Duke of Stettin \nPomeranian Ruler
{dearmad_stettin_desc}Named Duke of Stettin and ruler of Pomerania.\n\nDescription:\nThe first settlement of the West Slavic tribe of Pomeranians appeared here in the VIII century. Located at the mouth of the Oder, which flows into the Baltic Sea, at the intersection of European trade routes, the settlement has become an important commercial and industrial hub. Already in the 9th century, fortifications and a large sanctuary of the Slavic god Triglava were built on the hills near the shore of the Oder. In the X century, the settlement turned into a strong pagan fortress, around which a trade and craft settlement and port were formed, and the city itself was first mentioned under the Slavic name Kessin. After the conquests (1119-1121gg.) Of the Polish prince Boleslav III Pomerania was annexed to Poland. However, Kessin, or in the Polish manner, Shezin remained independent until 1124, when the newly gathered forces Boleslav III subjugated the city and baptized its inhabitants. However, he did not stay Polish for long - after 14 years the city went to Saxony, and then to the Holy Roman Empire, where he received the name Stettin.
{dearmad_stettin_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+10% tax revenue.
¬----------------------

{dearmad_wroclaw}Prince of Wroclaw \nRuler of Silesia
{dearmad_wroclaw_desc}Named Prince of Wroclaw and ruler of Silesia.\n\nDescription:\nIn the IV - beginning of the V century, one of the Vandal tribes settled in Wroclaw - sillings, from which, probably, Silesia got its name. The name Vortitslava and Vratislava appeared around 900 as the name of a Slavic settlement with a marketplace. It was located on an island near the confluence of the three tributaries of the Oder. By 990, Wroclaw and all of Silesia were conquered by the Polish prince from the Piast Meshko I dynasty. In 1000, his son Boleslaw the Brave and the Holy Roman Emperor Otto III established a Roman Catholic bishopric in the city. And although the city existed before, this date is officially considered the beginning of its history. In 1138, Wroclaw became the capital of the Polish principality of Silesia.
{dearmad_wroclaw_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% tax revenue.
¬----------------------
{idearmad_wroclaw}Khan of Wroclaw \nRuler of Silesia
{idearmad_wroclaw_desc}Named Khan of Wroclaw and ruler of Silesia.\n\nDescription:\nIn the IV - beginning of the V century, one of the Vandal tribes - Wielings settled in Wrocław, from where, probably, Silesia got its name. The name Vortitslava and Vratislava appeared around 900 as the name of a Slavic settlement with a marketplace. It was located on an island near the confluence of the three tributaries of the Oder. By 990, Wroclaw and all of Silesia were conquered by the Polish prince from the Piast Meshko I dynasty. In 1000, his son Boleslaw the Brave and the Holy Roman Emperor Otto III established a Roman Catholic bishopric in the city. And although the city existed before, this date is officially considered the beginning of its history. In 1138, Wroclaw became the capital of the Polish principality of Silesia.
{idearmad_wroclaw_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% tax revenue.
¬----------------------

{dearmad_krakow}Prince of Krakow \nRuler of Lesser Poland 
{dearmad_krakow_desc}Named Prince of Krakow and ruler of Lesser Poland.\n\nDescription:\nThe first mention of Krakow in historical documents dates back to 966: the Arab traveler Ibrahim ibn Yakub describes it as a prominent shopping center under the rule of the Czech prince. The Polish prince Meshko I conquered these places from the Czechs and included them in his possessions. Krakow quickly grew and became rich, and in 1000 Boleslav the Brave founded an episcopal department in Krakow. Pagan revolts in Poland led to the fact that in 1039, Casimir I moved his capital to Krakow, which became the center of the principality of the same name.
{dearmad_krakow_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to income from taxes. \n+5% to income from trade. \n+5% to public order as a governor. \n+1 to popularity.\n+1 General's health. 
¬----------------------

{king_plock}The Duke of Plock \nRuler of Mazovia 
{king_plock_desc}Named Duke of Plock and ruler of Mazovia.\n\nDescription:\nFounded in the late 10th century, Plock was an important cultural center of the Slavs. The most important place for the city center was Tumskaya Gora, where the first defensive fortress was built. In 1009, a Benedictine monastery was founded here. This event made the city a center of science and art. In 1075 the year the diocese of the Christian church was established here. From 1037 to 1047, Plock was the capital of the independent Masovian state Maslav and was the residence of many Masovian princes. From 1079 to 1138, the city was the capital of Poland, and then received the title of capital of the Duke of Plotsky.
{king_plock_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues. \n+1 to soldier morale.
¬----------------------

¬------------------------------------------------- -----------------
{dearmad_thorn}Count of Torun \nLord of Kuyavia 
{dearmad_thorn_desc}Named Count of Torun and ruler of Kuyavia.\n\nDescription:\nThe first settlements in the vicinity of Torun are dated 1100 BC. Despite its convenient location, until the beginning of the XIII century, Torun was only a small Slavic outpost guarding the ford across the Vistula. In the spring of 1231, the knights of the Teutonic Order laid a new fortress on the site of old fortifications. At the insistence of the first landmaster of the order, Hermann Balk, the castle was not built according to a rectangular plan, like most Teutonic castles, but in the form of a horseshoe, directed two ends to the Vistula. Its centerpiece was a huge octagonal tower. December 28, 1233, by the will of the Grand Master of the Order of Hermann von Salz, Torun received city status. It became the starting point for the conquest of the Prussian tribes by the Teutonic Order and the creation of the Teutonic state.
{dearmad_thorn_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+2 to nobility. \n+5% to public order in the role of governor. \n+1 to popularity.
¬----------------------

{king_palanga}Duke of Palanga \nLord of Courland
{king_palanga_desc}Named the Duke of Palanga and ruler of Courland.\n\nDescription:\nIn historical documents, the name Palanga was first mentioned in 1161, when King of Denmark Valdemar I captured and robbed the rich castle of the Baltic Curish tribe. Located on the ancient Amber Road, the castle was a center of trade and crafts. In the XIII century, this important and famous Lithuanian port city was constantly attacked by Swedes and Danes, as well as chivalry orders that were increasingly strengthened in Courland and Livonia.
{king_palanga_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues.\n+1 to cruelty.\n+5% to general’s movement range.
¬----------------------

Located on the ancient Amber Road, the castle was a center of trade and crafts. In the XIII century, this important and famous Lithuanian port city was constantly attacked by Swedes and Danes, as well as chivalry orders that were increasingly strengthened in Courland and Livonia.

¬------------------------------------------------- -----------------
{dearmad_riga}Duke of Riga \nLivonian ruler
{dearmad_riga_desc}Named the Duke of Riga and ruler of Livonia.\n\nDescription:\nThe first mention of Riga dates back to the 5th-6th centuries. when the city was inhabited by a Finno-Ugric tribe of Livs. Located at the mouth of the Western Dvina, the city became part of the famous trade route “From the Varangians to the Greeks”, which ensured its rapid growth and prosperity. In 1202, it became the founding place and the main base of the Knightly Order of the Brotherhood of the Hosts of Christ, better known by the name of the Order of the Swordsmen. In the first half of the 11th century, the city became the center of German commerce in the entire Baltic.
{dearmad_riga_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to income from taxes. \n+5% to income from trade. \n+1 to piety. \n+5% to public order as governor. \n+1 to popularity.
¬----------------------

In the first half of the 11th century, the city became the center of German commerce in the entire Baltic.

¬------------------------------------------------- -----------------
{king_hrodna}Prince of Gorodeny \nRuler of the Neman Lowland
{king_hrodna_desc}Named the Prince of Gorodeni and ruler of the Neman Lowland.\n\nDescription:\nThe official date of the founding of the city is 1128, when it is referred to as the center of the eponymous principality under the name Goroden. Starting from the first half of the XII century it was an important cultural, commercial and industrial center of the so-called Black Rus. Already then, stone fortifications existed in the city. Throughout the XII century, chronicles record the subordinate position of the city princes in relation to Kiev, but in the XIII century the city went to the Grand Duchy of Lithuania. Having become an important outpost on the border with the Teutonic Order, the city repeatedly repulsed the attacks of the crusaders.
{king_hrodna_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+10% to tax revenues. \n+1 to the command during the defense of the city.\n-5% agent recruitment cost. 
¬----------------------
{iking_hrodna}Khan of Gorodeni \nLord of the Neman lowland
{iking_hrodna_desc}Named Khan of Gorodeni and ruler of the Neman Lowland.\n\nDescription:\nThe official date of the founding of the city is 1128, when it is referred to as the center of the eponymous princedom under the name Goroden. Starting from the first half of the XII century it was an important cultural, commercial and industrial center of the so-called Black Rus. Already then, stone fortifications existed in the city. Throughout the XII century, chronicles record the subordinate position of the city princes in relation to Kiev, but in the XIII century the city went to the Grand Duchy of Lithuania. Having become an important outpost on the border with the Teutonic Order, the city repeatedly repulsed the attacks of the crusaders.
{iking_hrodna_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+10% to tax revenues. \n+1 to the command during the defense of the city.\n-5% agent recruitment cost.

{dearmad_vilnius}Prince of Vilna \nLord of Lithuania
{dearmad_vilnius_desc}Named Prince Vilna and ruler of Lithuania.\n\nDescription:\nThe city is located in the territory of the early medieval prefeudal culture of the Eastern Lithuanian Baltic mounds. There are more than ten mounds in the city. According to the legends recorded in the chronicles, the mythical Lithuanian prince Svintorog chose a place at the confluence of the Vilna river into Vilia for his burial. He ordered his son to burn his body in the mouth of Vilna after his death and henceforth to perform ritual corpse burnt here. The place was called the valley of the Holy Horn (Šventaragis Valley) .According to the legend, years later, the Grand Duke of Lithuania Gediminas went from Troki to hunt in the forests surrounding the valley of the Holy Horn. After a successful hunt, Gediminos stayed overnight in the Holy Horn. In a dream he saw a huge iron wolf on grief that howled like a hundred wolves. In the morning the prince asked the priest Lizdeika to explain the dream. Lizdeika explained that the wolf means the castle and the city that the ruler will lay here. The city will become the capital of all Lithuanian lands, and the howling of wolves means glory, which Paradise will spread throughout the world thanks to the virtues of the inhabitants of the city.
{dearmad_vilnius_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n-1 from piety. \n+2 to cruelty. \n+10% to tax revenues. \n+1 to the cavalry command.\n+10% to the movement range of a general without an army.
¬----------------------
{idearmad_vilnius}Khan of Vilno \nLord of Lithuania
{idearmad_vilnius_desc}Named Khan Vilno and ruler of Lithuania.\n\nDescription:\nThe city is located on the territory of the early medieval prefeudal culture of the Eastern Lithuanian Baltic mounds. There are more than ten mounds on the territory of the city. According to the legends recorded in the chronicles, the mythical Lithuanian prince Svintorog chose a place at the confluence of the Vilna river into Vilia for his burial. He ordered his son to burn his body in the mouth of Vilna after his death and henceforth to perform ritual corpse burnt here. The place was called the valley of the Holy Horn (Šventaragis Valley) .According to the legend, years later, the Grand Duke of Lithuania Gediminas went from Troki to hunt in the forests surrounding the valley of the Holy Horn. After a successful hunt, Gediminos stayed overnight in the Holy Horn. In a dream he saw a huge iron wolf on grief that howled like a hundred wolves. In the morning the prince asked the priest Lizdeika to explain the dream. Lizdeika explained that the wolf means the castle and the city that the ruler will lay here. The city will become the capital of all Lithuanian lands, and the howling of wolves means glory, which Paradise will spread throughout the world thanks to the virtues of the inhabitants of the city.
{idearmad_vilnius_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n-1 from piety. \n+2 to cruelty. \n+10% to tax revenues. \n+1 to the cavalry command.\n+10% to the movement range of a general without an army.
¬----------------------
{odearmad_vilnius}Strategist of Vilno \nLord of Lithuania
{odearmad_vilnius_desc}Named Strategist Vilno and ruler of Lithuania.\n\nDescription:\nThe city is located in the territory of the early medieval prefeudal culture of the Eastern Lithuanian Baltic mounds. There are more than ten mounds in the city. According to the legends recorded in the chronicles, the mythical Lithuanian prince Svintorog chose a place at the confluence of the Vilna river into Vilia for his burial. He ordered his son to burn his body in the mouth of Vilna after his death and henceforth to perform ritual corpse burnt here. The place was called the valley of the Holy Horn (Šventaragis Valley) .According to the legend, years later, the Grand Duke of Lithuania Gediminas went from Troki to hunt in the forests surrounding the valley of the Holy Horn. After a successful hunt, Gediminos stayed overnight in the Holy Horn. In a dream he saw a huge iron wolf on grief that howled like a hundred wolves. In the morning the prince asked the priest Lizdeika to explain the dream. Lizdeika explained that the wolf means the castle and the city that the ruler will lay here. The city will become the capital of all Lithuanian lands, and the howling of wolves means glory, which Paradise will spread throughout the world thanks to the virtues of the inhabitants of the city.
{odearmad_vilnius_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n-1 from piety. \n+2 to cruelty. \n+10% to tax revenues. \n+1 to the cavalry command.\n+10% to the movement range of a general without an army.\n+2 to command in battles against Catholics and Orthodox. 
¬------------------------------------------------- -----------------
{dearmad_holme}Prince of Dorpat \nRuler of the Baltic
{dearmad_holme_desc}Named Prince of Dorpat and ruler of the Baltic.\n\nDescription:\nOne of the oldest cities in the Baltic. The first settlement dating back to the 5th century was called Tarbat, as long as the Estonian name of the city - Tartu - went. In 1030, the settlement of Tarbat was captured by a detachment of the Kiev prince Yaroslav the Wise. He named the settlement Yuryev in his Christian name. Since in connection with these events the city was first mentioned in written sources, the year 1030 is sometimes considered the year of its foundation. In 1061, the city was burned by local Estonian tribes. Over the next two centuries, the fortified city often passed from hand to hand, until in 1224 it was conquered by the crusaders and renamed Dorpat.
{dearmad_holme_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues. \n+1 to the morale of all troops on the battlefield. \n+1 to piety.\n+1 to command when commanding infantry.

In 1219, here, after the battle with the Ests, the Danish king Voldemar II laid the fortress.

{dearmad_esztergom}Duke of Esztergom \nLord of Transdanubia
{dearmad_esztergom_desc}Named Duke of Esztergom and ruler of Transdanubia.\n\nDescription:\nOne of the oldest cities in Hungary. The first famous inhabitants of this settlement were the Celts. During the times of the Romans there was a fortified settlement called Salvio Mansio. After the settlement, the people settled Germanic tribes and Avars, and later Slavs who christened the Roman settlement of Stregom, which later became the basis for the modern name of the city, located at the important crossing of the Danube. Streg became one of the main cr epiches of the Principality of Nitran and Great Moravia. After the arrival of the Magyars in the beginning of the X century Esztergom became, after several decades, the residence of Grand Duke Gesa and until the 12th century. one of the residences of Hungarian kings. From X to XIII century. Esztergom was the center of the country's economic, political and religious life, its actual capital. In 976, the son of Geza Vaik was born here, who took the name Istvan at baptism and went down in history as Istvan the Holy. In 1001 he was crowned in Esztergom. During his reign the committee of the same name and the bishopric of Esztergom were formed.
{dearmad_esztergom_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues. \n+1 to fidelity. \n+1 to command during the defense of the city.
¬----------------------

{king_kassa}Duke of Eger \nLord of Slovakia
{king_kassa_desc}Named the Duke of Eger and ruler of Slovakia.\n\nDescription:\nThe settlement on the site of Eger has existed since ancient times. In the early Middle Ages, the region was inhabited by Germanic tribes, who were replaced by Avars. After the defeat of the latter, the surroundings of Eger were settled by the Slavs. In the X century, the city began to belong to the Hungarians. St. Stephen founded a bishopric in Eger. The first cathedral of the city was built on Fortress Hill, where the Eger Citadel is currently located. The city grew and developed around the cathedral and continued to be one of the most important religious centers of the country. In the 13th century, a powerful citadel was built on Fortress Hill.
{king_kassa_effects_desc}\nAnch Bonus:\n+5% tax income.\n+1 agriculture (increases city's agricultural income)\n+5% public order as governor.\n+1 popularity.

{dearmad_brasov}Duke of Brasov \nRuler of Transylvania
{dearmad_brasov_desc}Named Duke of Brasov and ruler of Transylvania.\n\nDescription:\nIn 1003, Istvan entered Transylvania with the army, and Gyula surrendered without a fight. This made it possible to organize a Transylvanian Catholic episcopate (with Dyulafekhervar as bishop) completed in 1009 when the bishop of Ostia (as papal legate) visited Istvan and approved the diocesan organization. In 1018, Istvan defeated Akhtum, the ruler of the lands in the lower reaches of the Mures river. According to the Chronicon Pictum chronicle, Istvan also defeated the legendary Kea and, the ruler of the Bulgarians and Slavs in the south of Transylvania. During the XII century in the eastern and southeastern part of Transylvania began to establish a sekhey-Hungarian tribe. In the XII-XIII centuries, areas in the south and northeast of the region also began to develop German colonists - Transylvanian Saxons “Siebenbürgen” (the German name for Transylvania, “Semigradier”) comes from the seven main fortified cities founded by the Transylvanian Saxons. The German influence became more noticeable when, at the beginning of the 13th century, the King of Hungary Andras II called on the Teutonic Order to protect After the Order expanded its territory beyond the borders of Transylvania without permission, Andras expelled the Knights in 1225.
{dearmad_brasov_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus:\n+5% to tax revenue. \n+1 to command. \n+1 to command when defending a city. \n+1 to cruelty.

{dearmad_zagreb}Prince of Zagreb \nLord of Croatia
{dearmad_zagreb_desc}Named Prince of Zagreb and ruler of Croatia.\n\nDescription:\nSlavic Croatian tribes that gave rise to the Croatian nation migrated to the eastern coast of the Adriatic Sea in the 7th century. Soon, the Kingdom of Croatia became one of the strongest in the region. In 1102, the ruling dynasty of Trpimirovich died away, and the Croatian crown was united in a dynastic union with the Hungarian. The first mention of Zagreb dates back to 1094, when the Hungarian king Laszlo I established a bishopric in a settlement on the hill Kaptol. At that time, the settlements of Hradec and Kaptol, which are part of the historical core of the city of Zagreb, were two independent settlements.
{dearmad_zagreb_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues.

{king_belgrade}Prince of Belgrade \nRuler of Serbia
{king_belgrade_desc}He was named Prince of Belgrade and ruler of Serbia.\n\nDescription:\nOnly in 878, in a letter from the pope of the Bulgarian Bulgarian Prince Vladimir Mikhail, the city was again mentioned, but under its Slavic name Belgrade. After the army of Charles the Great defeated Avars in Pannonia, the Franks in the place of Taurunum founded the settlement of Malevila. After settling it by the Slavs, it became known as Zemun. When the Franks left the region of Belgrade, in 827 the city became part of the First Bulgarian Kingdom. It was repelled by the Hungarians from the Bulgarians, but after some time Bulgaria managed to return the city. In 1018, the city became part of Byzantium and again began to play the role of an important border fortress of the empire. In 1040, an anti-Byzantine uprising led by Peter Delyan broke out in Pomorie. Belgrade was also among the captured cities, where Delyan declared himself the grandson of the Bulgarian king Samuel and was proclaimed by the Bulgarian king under the name of Peter II. In 1041 the uprising was crushed by the Byzantines. Throughout the XI-XII city was the scene of a fierce struggle between Byzantium and Hungary. Besides the armies of these powers, of several times devastated Crusaders marching through the area in the Holy Land.
{king_belgrade_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues. \n+1 to piety. \n+1 to the command during the defense of the city.\n+10% income from mines.

{king_scopia}Prince of Skopje \nRuler of the North of Macedonia
{king_scopia_desc}Named Prince of Skopje and ruler of the North of Macedonia.\n\nDescription:\nSkupi was a fortress in the Vardara Valley, which has been protected by stone walls since the second half of the 2nd century. In the 3rd – 4th centuries, it was the main economic, cultural, and administrative center of these territories. The city was ravaged several times by barbarians: in the year 269 - by the Goths, in the 5th century - by the Huns and, finally, in 518 it was completely destroyed by an earthquake. During the reign of Emperor Justinian, he was rebuilt again, but not in the same place, but on a hill, where his center is now located. With the arrival of the Slavs in the 6th century, the city was captured by the tribe of Brbsy, which called it Skopje. During the reign of Tsar Samuel, Skopje for a short time became the capital of the Bulgarian kingdom, later on it alternately fell under the power of Byzantium and Serbia.
{king_scopia_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues. \n-1 from fidelity. \n-1 from piety.\n+5% to general’s movement range.
¬----------------------
{iking_scopia}Khan Skopje \nRuler of North Macedonia 
{iking_scopia_desc}Named Khan Skopje and ruler of the North of Macedonia.\n\nDescription:\nSwupi was a fortress in the Vardara Valley, which has been protected by stone walls since the second half of the 2nd century. In the 3rd – 4th centuries, it was the main economic, cultural, and administrative center of these territories. The city was ravaged several times by barbarians: in the year 269 - by the Goths, in the 5th century - by the Huns and, finally, in 518 it was completely destroyed by an earthquake. During the reign of Emperor Justinian, he was rebuilt again, but not in the same place, but on a hill, where his center is now located. With the arrival of the Slavs in the 6th century, the city was captured by the tribe of Brbsy, which called it Skopje. During the reign of Tsar Samuel, Skopje for a short time became the capital of the Bulgarian kingdom, later on it alternately fell under the power of Byzantium and Serbia.
{iking_scopia_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenue. \n-1 from fidelity. \n-1 from piety.\n+5% to general’s movement range.
¬----------------------
{oking_scopia}Strategic Skopje \nRuler of the North of Macedonia
{oking_scopia_desc}Named Strategist Skopje and ruler of the North of Macedonia.\n\nDescription:\nSkupi was a fortress in the Vardara Valley, which has been protected by stone walls since the second half of the 2nd century. In the 3rd – 4th centuries, it was the main economic, cultural, and administrative center of these territories. The city was ravaged several times by barbarians: in the year 269 - by the Goths, in the 5th century - by the Huns and, finally, in 518 it was completely destroyed by an earthquake. During the reign of Emperor Justinian, he was rebuilt again, but not in the same place, but on a hill, where his center is now located. With the arrival of the Slavs in the 6th century, the city was captured by the tribe of Brbsy, which called it Skopje. During the reign of Tsar Samuel, Skopje for a short time became the capital of the Bulgarian kingdom, later on it alternately fell under the power of Byzantium and Serbia.
{oking_scopia_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues. \n-1 from fidelity \n-1 from piety.\n+5% to general’s movement range.
¬------------------------------------------------- -----------------
{dearmad_sofia}Duke of Sredets \nLord of Bulgaria
{dearmad_sofia_desc}Named the Duke of Sredets and ruler of Bulgaria.\n\nDescription:\nВ I — IV Serdika is the administrative center of the Roman province of Thrace. It was the favorite city of Emperor Constantine I the Great. The imperial court was here for many years and from here ruled the empire. The word of the emperor: " Serdika is my Rome ”, at first he wanted to build the capital of the Roman Empire -“ New Rome ”, but the strategic place of Byzantium won. As a result of the religious reform of Emperor Constantine I, Serdik became the bishop's place of residence. In 343, in the Cathedral of St. Sofia the Serdic Cathedral was held, which the church considers as a continuation of the First Council of Nicaea. In 357, the Roman historian Ammianus Marcellinus defined the city as “large and impregnable.” In V – VI, during the Great Migration of Nations, the city experienced invasions of barbarians and was devastated by the Huns in 441. VI century., During the reign of Emperor Justinian I the Great, Serdika was reborn as an important administrative center of Byzantium under the name Triaditsa. Only in religious terms the city was subordinated to the archbishopric. In 809 the city became part of the Bulgarian kingdom called Sredets. After the restoration of the Bulgarian state in 1185, the bishop of Sredets was elevated to the rank of Metropolitan.
{dearmad_sofia_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus:\n+5% tax income.\n+5% public order as a governor.\n+1 to popularity.\n+1 to loyalty.

The lord of this land had to skillfully combine not only the ability to effectively collect taxes, but also be a good logistician, as well as a cautious commander - after all, detachments of nomads often appeared in the south, whose intentions were difficult to predict.

{dearmad_constantinople}Ruler of Constantinople \nLatin Empire
{dearmad_constantinople_desc}Named ruler of Constantinople and the Latin Empire.\n\nDescription:\n11 May 330 Constantine the Great officially transfers the capital of the Roman Empire to the city on the Bosphorus and calls it Constantinople. Subsequently, the city grew and developed so rapidly that it was already half a century later, when Emperor Theodosius, new city walls are being erected. After the brutal suppression of the rebellion under Emperor Justinian, the capital is rebuilt again, attracting the best architects of its time. New buildings, temples, palaces, the main streets of the new city are decorated with colonnades. Greek-language culture, science flourishes, the Constantinople Higher School is reformed, a kind of the first European university. painting. Missionary activity is intensified, mainly among the Slavs. Constantinople played a fundamental role in all areas of Byzantine life.
{dearmad_constantinople_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+15% to income from taxes. \n+15% to income from trade.

{king_adrianople_desc}Named the Earl of Hadrianople and ruler of Thrace.\n\nDescription:\nThe city of Adrianople was founded by the Roman emperor Hadrian on the site of the Thracian settlement, which was named Uskudam and was the capital of the Kingdom of Odris on 9 August 378. Near Adrianople, the battle of the Roman army under command Emperor Valent with the Goths. The Romans were completely defeated, Emperor Valens was killed. Before the XIth city was the center of the eponymous archdiocese of the Patriarchate of Constantinople. April 14, 1205 between the crusaders led by Baldwin I and edinonnym Bulgarian-Polovtsian army under the leadership of the Bulgarian Tsar Kaloyan battle took place, which ended in the complete defeat of the Crusaders.

{dearmad_thessalonica}Count of Thessaloniki \nRuler of Macedonia
{dearmad_thessalonica_desc}Named ruler of Thessaloniki(Macedonia).\n\nDescription:\nThe city of Thessaloniki was founded by King of Macedonia Kassandra in 315 BC. The wife of King Kassandra was the half-sister of Alexander the Great-Thessalonica. It was then that the city became elistist In 146 BC, Thessaloniki was captured by the Romans. Theodosius I, in revenge for the murder of his representatives in the city, carried out massacres in which several thousand people were killed. With the collapse of the Roman Empire and the formation of the Byzantine Empire, Thessaloniki rendered in a favorable geopolitical position at the intersection of roads from Constantinople to Rome and from Athens to the Black Sea. After the Arabs captured Antioch and Alexandria, Thessaloniki became the second largest and most important city of the empire. In parallel, the national composition of the city became more diverse: many southern Slavs, Roman-speaking Wallachians settled here who immigrated from the northern mountainous regions. The local natives were the holy Great Martyr Dimitry of Solunsky and the holy Equal-to-the-Apostles Cyril and Methodius, the Enlightenment of the Slavs. Some of the important Thessaloniki attractions is the Hagia Sophia and Tomb dedicated to St. George, which in the beginning of V became Christian tserkovyu.V 995g.gorodom briefly seized bolgary.V 1185g.gorod was taken and plundered by the Sicilian Normans.
{dearmad_thessalonica_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+10% tax revenue.\n+5% trade income.

Theodosius I, in revenge for the murder of his representatives in the city, carried out massacres in which several thousand people were killed. With the collapse of the Roman Empire and the formation of the Byzantine Empire, Thessaloniki rendered in a favorable geopolitical position at the intersection of roads from Constantinople to Rome and from Athens to the Black Sea. After the Arabs captured Antioch and Alexandria, Thessaloniki became the second largest and most important city of the empire. In parallel, the ethnic composition of the city became more diverse: many southern Slavs, Roman-speaking Wallachians settled here who immigrated from the northern mountainous regions. The local natives were the holy Great Martyr Dimitry of Solunsky and the holy Equal-to-the-Apostles Cyril and Methodius, the Enlightenment of the Slavs. Some of the important x Thessaloniki sights is the Temple of Hagia Sophia and the Tomb dedicated to George the Victorious, which at the beginning of V became a Christian church. In 995 the city was temporarily captured by the Bulgarians. In 1185 the city was taken and plundered by the Sicilian Normans.

{dearmad_durazzo}Earl of Durazzo \n Ruler of Dirrachia
{dearmad_durazzo_desc}Named Earl of Durazzo and ruler of Dirrachia.\n\nDescription:\nThe city was founded in 627 BC under the name Epidaeme by the Greek colonists of Corinth on the Illyrian coast. Epidaeme was built in a place favorable for defense: the harbor created by nature was It is surrounded by land with swamps and high cliffs from the sea, which made the city impregnable. In Dirrachia, Cicero lived for some time in exile. In 48 BC, not far from Dirrachia, a battle took place between Pompey and Caesar. Dirrachius reached its heyday in IV. For several centuries, Dirrachius remained one of the most important Byzantine cities on the Adriatic. In the fall of 1081 the fleet of the Duke of Apulia, Calabria and Sicily, the Norman Robert Guiscard, began a long siege of the city. Emperor Alexei I Komnin, head of the fresh army, helped Dirrachius. 1081 between the troops of Robert and Alexei, a battle took place. 1082, a few months after the retreat of the Byzantine army, Robert managed to take the city, but in 1084. the Venetian fleet, allied to Byzantium, recaptured the Normans. In 1108, the city was besieged by Bohemund of Antioch, son of Robert Guiscard, and 1185 conquered by the Sicilian king William II.
{dearmad_durazzo_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% tax revenue.\n+1 to personal safety (reduced chance of death from an assassin). 
¬----------------------

{king_arta}Earl of Arta \nEpirus Governor
{king_arta_desc}Named Earl of Arta and ruler of Epirus.\n\nDescription:\nThe city is located on the same spot where the city of Ambracia, founded by the Corinthians in 640 BC, was located and where the nephew of the Corinthian tyrant Periandra ruled for some time , With the same name Periander. Ambracia from 229 BC was the residence of Tsar Epirus Pyrrhus, known for his campaign in Italy and his "pyrrhic" victory over the Romans. In 146 BC, the Romans took possession of the city. From the XI century the city is known by its current name. In 1203, captured by the Normans. by Constantinople in 1204, in the hands of the Crusaders of the Fourth Crusade, Arta became the capital of one of the three Greek states, Epirus Despotate, from 1229. From the classical period, the ruins of ancient Ambracia, including the Temple of Apollon, remained. Attractions: Church of St. Theodora in Arta. Byzantine Fortress . The Church of the Holy Mother of God The Comforter. During the reign of Michael I Komnenus Duca, a Byzantine fortress was built. Arta has a great Byzantine heritage from the era of Epirus despotate, in particular, the Church of St. Theodora first built in the XIII century, a unique architectural object, with many mosaics.
{king_arta_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+10% to tax revenue. \n+1 to piety.\n-1 to loyalty

{king_athens}Duke of Athens \nRuler of Attica
{king_athens_desc}Named the Duke of Athens and ruler of Attica.\n\nDescription:\nAthens was a large and powerful city, one of the cradles of Greek culture. During the Golden Age of Greece (about 500 BC to 300 BC. ) The city became an important cultural center. After the Golden Age, Athens did not lose its significance until the heyday of the Roman Empire. Philosophical schools were closed in 529 by the emperor of the Byzantine Empire, Justinian I. 200 years ago, Christianity was designated the official religion in the Byzantine Empire. Athens lost past led and turned into a provincial city. Between the 13th and 15th centuries, Byzantine, French and Italian knights from the Latin Empire lay claim to the city.
{king_athens_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+10% to tax revenues. \n+2 to fidelity. \n+5% to public order in the role of governor. \n+1 to popularity.
¬----------------------
