{dearmad_iraklion}Earl of Kandia \nPrince of Crete
{dearmad_iraklion_desc}Named Earl of Crete and ruler of Heraklion.\n\nDescription:\nThe city was built on the site of a small harbor, which is considered to be a port on the shores of the Cretan Sea, near the city of Knossos, the center of the Minoan civilization: Strabo. Much later than the Arabs, having captured Crete in 824, they turned this place into the fortified fort Handak, which they held for 140 years. To protect the city, the Arabs built powerful walls and surrounded them with a deep moat (hence the name of the city, which in Arabic means “moat”). .city was recaptured by the Byzantine commander Nikiforo m.Fokoy after a stubborn eight-month siege.Handak was looted and destroyed, his wealth on 300 ships was transferred to Byzantium.After about 250 years, the crusaders defeated Byzantium, and Crete was sold to the Venetians in 1204. During the time of unrest, the city fell into the hands of pirates, but in 1211 In the year the Venetian Republic established its rule here. During Venetian rule, the city received the name Candia, which was attached to the whole island. During this era, the city achieved significant prosperity, the Venetians surrounded it with new, very powerful and walls decorated with many magnificent buildings, fountains, squares, monuments, churches.
{dearmad_iraklion_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus:\n+5% tax income.\n+5% trade income.\n+5% legality.\n-5% corruption.\n+1 defensive command during an assault.\n+1 to nobility.

{odearmad_iraklion}Strategist of Heraklion \nRuler of Crete
{odearmad_iraklion_desc}Named Strategist of Crete and ruler of Heraklion.\n\nDescription:\nThe city was built on the site of a small harbor, which is considered to be a port on the coast of the Cretan Sea, near the city of Knossos, the center of the Minoan civilization: Strabo. Much later, the Arabs, having captured Crete in 824, they turned this place into the fortified fort Handak, which they held for 140 years. To protect the city, the Arabs built powerful walls and surrounded them with a deep moat (hence the name of the city, which in Arabic means “moat”). .city was recaptured by the Byzantine commander Niki after a persistent eight-month siege. Handak was looted and destroyed, his wealth on 300 ships was transferred to Byzantium. After about 250 years, the crusaders defeated Byzantium, and Crete was sold to the Venetians in 1204. During the time of unrest, the city fell into the hands of pirates, but in 1211 The year the Venetian Republic established its rule here. During Venetian rule, the city received the name Candia, which was attached to the whole island. During this era, the city achieved significant prosperity, the Venetians surrounded it with new, very walls, decorated with many magnificent buildings, fountains, squares, monuments, churches.

{dearmad_nicaea}Duke of Nicaea \nRex of Bithynia
{dearmad_nicaea_desc}Named the Duke of Nicaea and ruler of Bithynia.\n\nDescription:\nNicaean coins show interest in the city of emperors, often celebrated in the city in honor of the gods and emperors. During the Roman period, Nicaea remained an important city, located only 70 km from Of Constantinople. When Constantinople became the capital of the Eastern Roman Empire, Nicaea did not lose its significance, moreover, new walls were built and old walls were strengthened, in the early 300s AD the construction of public and religious buildings was actively underway. the Nicholas fortress was strategically important during the confrontation between Byzantium and the Seljuk Turks. For a long time, Nicaea was under the rule of Byzantium, but in 1077 the Seljuk Turks seized the city. Nikea passed from hand to hand until finally in 1078 it came under the control of the Seljuk Turks. .Nicaea became the capital of the Rumsky Sultanate. These events triggered the First Crusade, and at the request of Byzantium, the crusaders, with the support of smaller Byzantine units, approached the city in 1097. Nicaea was besieged: the siege continued Chez months, after which the Turks preferred to surrender to the Byzantine voyskam.Dlya mitigate discontent Crusaders Byzantine Emperor Alexios I Komnenos granted the horses and gave part of the ransom.
{dearmad_nicaea_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus:\n+5% to tax revenues.\n+1 to piety.\n+1 city defense command.
¬----------------------
{idearmad_nicaea}Emir of Nicaea \nRex of Bithynia
{idearmad_nicaea_desc}Named Emir of Nicaea and ruler of Bithynia.\n\nDescription:\nNicaean coins show interest in the city of emperors, often celebrated in the city in honor of the gods and emperors. During the Roman period, Nicaea remained an important city, located only 70 km from Of Constantinople. When Constantinople became the capital of the Eastern Roman Empire, Nicaea did not lose its significance, moreover, new walls were built and old walls were strengthened, in the early 300s AD the construction of public and religious buildings was actively underway. the centuries-old Nicaea fortress was strategically important during the confrontation between Byzantium and the Seljuk Turks. For a long time Nicaea was under the rule of Byzantium, but in 1077 the Seljuk Turks seized the city. Nikea passed from hand to hand until finally in 1078 it came under the control of the Seljuk Turks. .Nicaea became the capital of the Rumsky Sultanate. These events triggered the First Crusade, and at the request of Byzantium, the crusaders, with the support of smaller Byzantine units, approached the city in 1097. Nicaea was besieged: the siege continued earlier than a month, after which the Turks preferred to surrender to the Byzantine troops. To mitigate the discontent of the crusaders, the Byzantine Emperor Alexei Komnin provided horses and handed over part of the ransom.
{idearmad_nicaea_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus:\n+5% to tax revenues.\n+1 to piety.\n+1 city defense command.

{odearmad_nicaea}Nikea's strategist \nBythinian Ruler
{odearmad_nicaea_desc}Named as the Strategist of Nicaea and ruler of Bithynia.\n\nDescription:\nNicaean coins indicate interest in the city of emperors, often celebrated in the city in honor of the gods and emperors. During the Roman period, Nicaea remained an important city, located only 70 km from Of Constantinople. When Constantinople became the capital of the Eastern Roman Empire, Nicaea did not lose its significance, moreover, new walls were built and old walls were strengthened, in the early 300s AD, the construction of public and religious buildings was actively underway. The Nikea fortress was strategically important in the Middle Ages during the confrontation between Byzantium and the Seljuk Turks. For a long time Nicaea was under the rule of Byzantium, but in 1077 the Seljuk Turks seized the city. Nikea passed from hand to hand until finally in 1078 it came under the control of the Seljuk Turks. .Nicaea became the capital of the Rum Sultanate. These events triggered the First Crusade, and at the request of Byzantium, the crusaders, with the support of smaller Byzantine units, approached the city in 1097. Nicaea was besieged: the siege continued more than a month, after which the Turks preferred to surrender to the Byzantine forces. To mitigate the discontent of the crusaders, the Byzantine Emperor Alexei Komnin provided horses and handed over part of the ransom.
{odearmad_nicaea_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus:\n+5% to tax revenues.\n+1 to piety.\n+1 city defense command.

{dearmad_smyrna}Duke of Smyrna \nLord of Thrace
{dearmad_smyrna_desc}Named the Duke of Smyrna and ruler of Thrace.\n\nDescription:\nWith the fall of Ancient Rome, Smyrna fell into decay. In the early Byzantine era, it still remained a major religious and economic center, but decreased in size and never again reached its former prosperity .The remnants of the slave system are combined with feudalism. The beginning of the weakening of Byzantine influence was marked at the end of the XI century, when, after the Battle of Manzikert, the Seljuk Turks broke into Asia Minor and inflicted on the Byzantines many cities captured the zeal for another. In 1084 the turn of Smyrna came. Under the leadership of Chuck Bey, the Turks took control of the city. Also the Turks captured Fokey and many Aegean islands. Chuck Bey used Izmir as a base for naval raids on Byzantium. After his death in 1102 the city and the neighboring region were returned to the Byzantine Empire. Byzantine rule in the city lasted more than a century. But in 1204, after the capture of Constantinople by the crusaders and the fall of Byzantium, the city was captured by the Knights-Johannites, who then owned Rhodes, but a few years later, the Nicene Empire captured the city.
{dearmad_smyrna_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues. \n+1 to command.
¬----------------------

After his death in 1102 the city and the neighboring region were returned to the Byzantine Empire. Byzantine rule in the city lasted more than a century. But in 1204, after the capture of Constantinople by the crusaders and the fall of Byzantium, the city was captured by the Knights-Johannites, who then owned Rhodes, but cut a few years Nicaean Empire conquered the city.

Chuck Bey used Izmir as a base for naval raids on Byzantium. After his death in 1102 the city and the neighboring region were returned to the Byzantine Empire. Since the city is located on the shores of the Dardanelles in a place where the width of the channel is less than 1 mile, it has always been a strategically important point.

{king_isparta}Earl of Attalia
{king_isparta_desc}Named the Earl of Attalia.\n\nDescription:\nThe region fell economically in VIII after a devastating earthquake, raids by Arabs and sea pirates. Islam began to spread in the XI with the beginning of the Seljuk expansion in the region. In 1118 under the Byzantine Emperor John II Komnine, the city was an enclave of Byzantium. It was at a considerable distance from the lands of the empire, so that only sea communication was possible with the rest of the country. In 1119, John II made a number of campaigns against the Turks and made his way overland to Attalia by land. After the events of 1204, An Orthodox Italian named Aldebrand took control of the city, in 1206 the Turks besieged the city for 16 days, but the help of 200 Cypriot knights delayed its fall for a year. In 1207, the Seljuks conquered the region, the Greek name Attalia changed to Adalia. However, after a couple of years, local Christians The city was conquered by the Turks in 1216. A remarkable historical fact: during the second conquest, the Turks declared jihad to the Christians, and after the victory they beat out a death threatening message on the city walls for intimidation; however, it was written in Arabic a sight that the Greek Christians did not understand.
{king_isparta_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues. \n+1 to piety.
¬----------------------
{iking_isparta}Caliph of Attalia
{iking_isparta_desc}Named by the Caliph of Attalia.\n\nDescription:\nThe region fell economically in VIII after a devastating earthquake, raids by Arabs and sea pirates. Islam began to spread in the XI with the beginning of the Seljuk expansion in the region. In 1118 under the Byzantine emperor John II Comnenus the city was an enclave of Byzantium. It was at a considerable distance from the lands of the empire, so that only sea communication was possible with the rest of the country. In 1119, John II made several campaigns against the Turks and made his way overland to Attalia by land. After events 120 4, the authority in the city was taken over by an Orthodox Italian named Aldebrand. In 1206 the Turks besieged the city for 16 days, but the help of 200 Cypriot knights delayed its fall for a year. In 1207 the Seljuks conquered the region, the Greek name Attalia changed to Adalia. However, after a couple of years local Christians rebelled. The city was conquered by the Turks in 1216. A remarkable historical fact: during the second conquest, the Turks declared jihad to the Christians, and after the victory they beat out a threatening death message on the city walls; however, it was written in Arabic yazyu which the Greeks, Christians do not understand.

Islam began to spread in the XI with the beginning of the Seljuk expansion in the region. In 1118 under the Byzantine Emperor John II Komnine, the city was an enclave of Byzantium. It was at a considerable distance from the lands of the empire, so that only sea communication was possible with the rest of the country. In 1119, John II made a number of campaigns against the Turks and made his way overland to Attalia by land. 1204, the authority in the city was taken over by an Orthodox Italian named Aldebrand. In 1206 the Turks besieged the city for 16 days, but the help of 200 Cypriot knights delayed its fall for a year. In 1207 the Seljuks conquered the region, the Greek name Attalia changed to Adalia. However, after a couple of years local Christians rebelled. The city was conquered by the Turks in 1216. A remarkable historical fact: during the second conquest, the Turks declared jihad to the Christians, and after the victory they beat out a threatening death message on the city walls; however, it was written in Arabic ligature that the Greek Christians did not understand.

{dearmad_trebizond}Duke of Trebizond
{dearmad_trebizond_desc}Named the Duke of Trebizond.\n\nDescription:\nIn the 6th – 7th centuries, Trebizond was the center of the East Roman (Byzantine) province of First Armenia. After the catastrophic events associated with the wars of the time of Emperor Heraclius and the beginning of the medieval era of Trebizond (in medieval Greek pronunciation) becomes the main outpost of Byzantium in the east of the Black Sea. In the 7th-9th centuries, Trebizond was part of the province (theme) of Armeniak. In the 9th-11th centuries, the city was the center of the province (theme) of Chaldia. Muslim authors of the 10th century note that Trapezund often Muslim merchants visited as the main source of Byzantine silk. Since 1204, Trebizond became the capital of the small Greek state of the Great Comnenus, known as the Trebizond Empire.
{dearmad_trebizond_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+10% tax revenue.\n-1 from loyalty. 
¬----------------------

{dearmad_caffa}Prince of Kuffa \nRuler of Crimea 
{dearmad_caffa_desc}Named Prince of Kaffa and ruler of the Crimea.\n\nDescription:\nThe city was founded by Greek colonists from Miletus in the VI century BC. From 355 BC. Theodosius was part of the Bosporus kingdom. Destroyed by the Huns in the 4th century CE. During this period the Alans lived in the city and its environs, and the settlement received the Alanian name Ardabda - translated “seven-gods.” In the 5th century the city came under Roman (Byzantine) control empire, in the VI century was captured by the Khazars, and then again moved to Byzantium. Over the next centuries, it existed as a small village that fell under the influence of the Golden Horde in the XIII century. Subsequently, it was bought by Genoese merchants. The Genoese created a prosperous trading port city of Kaffa, which It served as the main port and control center for all Genoese colonies in the Northern Black Sea region. During this period, the city experienced its heyday. The city had a branch of the bank of St. George and a theater. There was a mint where coins were minted. Genoese maintained allied relations with the Golden Horde khans, who formally were the supreme owners of the territories of the colonies, granting them full self-government within the walls of the cities, and appointing a special prefect from the natives of Crimea to manage the rural district of the Kafin possessions.
{dearmad_caffa_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to income from taxes. \n+5% to income from trade. \n+1 to agriculture (increases the city’s income from agriculture).
¬----------------------
{idearmad_caffa}Kaffa Khan \nRuler of Crimea
{idearmad_caffa_desc}Named Khan Kaffa and ruler of the Crimea.\n\nDescription:\nThe city was founded by Greek colonists from Miletus in the VI century BC. From 355 BC. Theodosius was part of the Bosporus kingdom. Destroyed by the Huns in the 4th century CE. During this period the Alans lived in the city and its environs, and the settlement received the Alanian name Ardabda - translated “seven-gods.” In the 5th century the city came under Roman (Byzantine) control empire, in the VI century was captured by the Khazars, and then again moved to Byzantium. Over the next centuries, it existed as a small village that fell under the influence of the Golden Horde in the XIII century. Subsequently, it was bought by Genoese merchants. The Genoese created a prosperous trading port city of Kaffa, which It served as the main port and control center for all Genoese colonies in the Northern Black Sea region. During this period, the city experienced its heyday. The city had a branch of the bank of St. George and a theater. There was a mint where coins were minted. Genoese maintained allied relations with the Golden Horde khans, who formally were the supreme owners of the territories of the colonies, granting them full self-government within the walls of the cities, and appointing a special prefect from the natives of Crimea to manage the rural district of the Kafin possessions.
{idearmad_caffa_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to income from taxes. \n+5% to income from trade. \n+1 to agriculture (increases the city’s income from agriculture).
¬----------------------
{odearmad_caffa}Strategist of Theodosius \nRuler of Crimea
{odearmad_caffa_desc}Named the Strategist of Theodosius and the ruler of the Crimea.\n\nDescription:\nThe city was founded by Greek colonists from Miletus in the VI century BC. From 355 BC. Theodosius was part of the Bosporus kingdom. Destroyed by the Huns in the 4th century CE. During this period the Alans lived in the city and its environs, and the settlement received the Alanian name Ardabda - translated “seven-gods.” In the 5th century the city came under Roman (Byzantine) control empire, in the VI century was captured by the Khazars, and then again moved to Byzantium. Over the next centuries, it existed as a small village that fell under the influence of the Golden Horde in the XIII century. Subsequently, it was bought by Genoese merchants. The Genoese created a prosperous trading port city of Kaffa, which It served as the main port and control center for all Genoese colonies in the Northern Black Sea region. During this period, the city experienced its heyday. The city had a branch of the bank of St. George and a theater. There was a mint where coins were minted. Genoese maintained allied relations with the Golden Horde khans, who formally were the supreme owners of the territories of the colonies, granting them full self-government within the walls of the cities, and appointing a special prefect from the natives of Crimea to manage the rural district of the Kafin possessions.
{odearmad_caffa_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to income from taxes. \n+5% to income from trade. \n+1 to agriculture (increases the city’s income from agriculture).
¬------------------------------------------------- -----------------
{dearmad_kiev}Grand Duke of Kiev
{dearmad_kiev_desc}Named Grand Prince of Kiev\n\nDescription:\nThe city was founded by Prince Kiy in 430, the ruler of the Slavic tribe of the meadow. In 882, Kiev was conquered by the Novgorod prince Oleg, who moved his residence there, from that moment Kiev became the capital of the Old Rus` state. The Kiev Grand Dukes traditionally had supremacy over the princes of other lands of Rus`, and the Kiev table was the main goal in dynastic rivalries. In 968 the city withstood the siege of the Pechenegs, in which there was a merit of the fortified outposts of Kiev. In 988, by order of Prince Vladimir, the inhabitants of the city were baptized in the Dnieper, after which Rus` became a Christian state. In the middle of the XI century, Kiev reached its "golden age". Under the rule of Yaroslav the Wise, they maintain wide international relations: with Byzantium, Scandinavia, the countries of the east and Western Europe. The city is significantly increasing in size, the construction of St. Sophia Cathedral with numerous frescoes and mosaics is nearing completion. In the 70s of the XI century, Adam of Bremen in his writings called Kiev "the rival of Constantinople."
{dearmad_kiev_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+15% to income from taxes. \n+5% to income from trade. \n+15% to legality. \n-15% to corruption. \n+2 to command in battles against nomads and pagans. \n+2 to command in battles against the Orthodox.
¬----------------------
{idearmad_kiev}Khan of Kiev
{idearmad_kiev_desc}Named Khan of Kiev.\n\nDescription:\nThe city was founded by Prince Kiy in 430, the ruler of the Slavic tribe of the Polyans. In 882, Kiev was conquered by the Novgorod prince Oleg, who moved his residence there, from that moment Kiev became the capital of the Old Rus` state. The Kiev Grand Dukes traditionally had supremacy over the princes of other lands of Rus`, and the Kiev table was the main goal in dynastic rivalries. In 968 the city withstood the siege of the Pechenegs, in which there was a merit of the fortified outposts of Kiev. In 988, by order of Prince Vladimir, the inhabitants of the city were baptized in the Dnieper, after which Rus` became a Christian state. The city is significantly increasing in size, the construction of St. Sophia Cathedral with numerous frescoes and mosaics is nearing completion. In the 70s of the XI century, Adam of Bremen in his writings called Kiev "the rival of Constantinople."

{king_chernigov}Prince of Chernigov
{king_chernigov_desc}Named Prince of Chernigov.\n\nDescription:\nThe first mention of the city dates back to 907. Already in the IX century, it becomes the center of Seversky land, one of the largest cities in Ancient Rus`. The rapid growth of the city was promoted by a favorable geographical position in the Desna basin and its tributaries Dreams and Diet. In the Desna, the city maintained contact with Kiev and further along the Dnieper with Byzantium. Desna opened the way to the lands in the upper Volga and Oka, as well as to Novgorod. On the Volga-Don Road, Chernihiv maintained contact with the Arab East. Crafts, agriculture and trade were the basis of the economic activity of Chernihiv. In the XI-XIII centuries, the capital city of the Chernigov-Seversky principality, which occupied vast areas of the left bank of the Dnieper, had one of the strongest princely squads. At the end of the XI century in ancient Rus`, princely feuds erupted again. The city repeatedly passed from hand to hand.
{king_chernigov_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to income from taxes. \n+5% to income from trade. \n+1 to command.\n+1 morale of all troops on the battlefield. 
¬----------------------

{king_pereyaslav}Prince of Pereyaslavl
{king_pereyaslav_desc}Named by Prince Pereyaslavsky.\n\nDescription:\nPereyaslav was first mentioned in 907 in an agreement between Oleg and Byzantium. The name of the city means "adopted the glory." The Tale of Bygone Years tells us that in 992 Prince Vladimir Svyatoslavich founded a city by the ford across the Trubezh River, where his army defeated the Pechenegs. The leather man won the victory, who defeated the famous Pecheneg bogatyr in a duel and thereby “adopted his fame”. The Nixon Chronicle under 1001 states that the skinny name was Jan Usmoshvets, a comrade-in-arms of the epic hero Alyosha Popovich. Prince Vladimir Svyatoslavich laid here a large fortress to protect the southern borders of Rus` from the steppe nomads. Since the middle of the XI century, the city has been the capital of the Pereyaslavl principality, which played a crucial role in protecting Rus` from the Pechenegs, and later Polovtsy.
{king_pereyaslav_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+10% to tax revenues. \n+10% to the commander’s movement range.
¬----------------------

{king_severskiy}Prince of Novgorod-Seversky
{king_novgorod-severskiy_desc}Named Prince Novgorod-Seversky.\n\nDescription:\nThe first annalistic mention of the “new city” in the land of the northerners is contained in the “Teaching to Children” by Vladimir Monomakh. In the middle of the 10th century, the city was already a fully developed social organism - with a princely court, temples, good houses of warriors and artisans, with a trading post, which, as expected, consisted of a roundabout city, prison and hem. The economy of ancient Novgorod-Seversky was based on crafts, trade, agriculture, cattle breeding, karting, hunting, and fishing. Well-developed iron and pottery production. The first fortified settlement on the site of the city appeared at the end of the X century, during the reign of Vladimir Svyatoslavovich, although some historians prefer to connect the foundation of Novgorod-Seversky with the conquest of Yaroslav the Wise in 1044. For many years the city remained a defensive outpost for Kiev from the Polovtsy, the second most important city of the Chernigov Principality. After the Lyubech Congress of Princes in 1097, Novgorod-Seversky became the center of an extensive specific princedom, the clan nest of the Olgovichi - active participants in feudal strife.
{king_novgorod-severskiy_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues.\n+1 defensive command. 
¬----------------------

{king_turov}Prince of Turov
{king_turov_desc}Named Prince Turovsky.\n\nDescription:\nDregovich political, economic and cultural center. The city was first mentioned in 980 in the "Tale of Bygone Years." The city was founded at the confluence of the Yazda and Strumen rivers, the tributaries of the Pripyat. This geographical position contributed to the development of the city, as one of the options for the trade route "from the Varangians to the Greeks" passed through it. Turov consisted of a fortified Turov detinets and a roundabout city. In 1005, Prince Svyatopolk in Turov founded the temple in the Latin rite. After the marriage of Svyatopolk and the daughter of the Polish prince Boleslav the Brave, a Latin bishop Rainburn appeared in Turov, who bore the bishopric during his stay in Turov. In the XI century, the city became one of the centers of Christianity. During this period, Turov was an important trading center. In 1158, Turov and Pinsk were besieged by the princes led by Kiev, the siege lasted 10 weeks. In the 1180s, the independent Pinsk principality stood out from the Principality of Turov.
{king_turov_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues. \n+1 to agriculture (increases the city’s income from agriculture).
¬----------------------

{king_vladimir-volinskiy}Prince of Vladimir-Volynsky
{king_vladimir-volinskiy_desc}Named Prince of Vladimir-Volynsky.\n\nDescription:\nVladimir-Volynsky one of the oldest cities in Rus`: known since 988, then the Prince of Kiev Vladimir Svyatoslavovich imprisoned his son Vsevolod there. Favorable geographical position contributed to the development of ancient Vladimir. Since the XI century, it has been one of the largest cities in Kievan Rus, along with Kiev, Chernihiv and Pereyaslav. During this period, the city became a significant trading center, as well as an important military-strategic outpost on the western borders of the ancient Rus` state. Culture developed in the city, construction of fortifications, temples and monasteries was carried out. Starting from the XII century, during the feudal fragmentation of Rus`, the city became the center of the specific Volyn principality, in which a separate princely dynasty was established, founded by the grandson of Vladimir Monomakh - Prince Izyaslav Mstislavovich.
{king_vladimir-volinskiy_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues. \n+5% to public order in the role of governor. \n+1 to popularity.
¬----------------------

{dearmad_halych}Prince of Galich
{dearmad_halych_desc}Named by Prince Galitsky.\n\nDescription:\nThe first oral mention of Galich sounds in the epic about Duke Stepanovich, who left for Kiev, where Ilya Muromets served at the outpost. According to the epic, the city of Galich was better than Kiev in quality of life (cellars are deep, where beer barrels were kept on chains, had ventilation, in Kiev beer in the cellars is stale; all stoves in Galich are tiled with tiles, streets with a wooden flooring are covered with crimson canvases at the churches, etc.) The first written mention of the city appeared in Ipatiev Chronicle, and then to Lavrentievsk th chronicles dating back to the XII century. During the baptism of Rus under Vladimir the Baptist, there were already churches in Galich and, presumably, the baptism was carried out earlier than in Kiev by representatives of the ruling ancient family. Since the XII century, Galich was the capital of the Galician, and then the Galician-Volyn principality. The city was large enough by the standards of Ancient Rus`, although it could not compete with Kiev or Novgorod.
{dearmad_halych_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues. \n+1 to command. \n+10% to the commander’s movement range.
¬----------------------

{king_oleshe}Prince of Oleshye
{king_oleshe_desc}Named Prince of Oleshye.\n\nDescription:\nIn the 10th century, at the mouth of the Dnieper, where ancient Greek colonies existed at the time of antiquity, a village was founded again, which was founded by the warriors and merchants of Kievan Rus, trading along the Byzantium along the Dnieper. Moreover, the more than 300-kilometer massif of steppes and forest-steppes between the Black Sea and the Ros River remained virtually uninhabited by the Eastern Slavs due to the constant invasions of nomadic tribes from Asia, and therefore even during the years of relative migration lull. Oleshya was of unusually important strategic importance, as it was located at the intersection of land and sea routes at the Dnieper into the Black Sea, connecting Rus` through Byzantium with the Mediterranean Sea and Western Europe and around Crimea through the Sea of ​​Azov, Don and the Volga with the Caspian Sea and the Arab world. It was in Olesha that numerous ambassadors from Byzantium, the Caucasus, and Near Asia were met. In Oleshia, the Kiev princes also accepted Byzantine candidates for the Kiev metropolitan chair. Remote Oleshye was characterized by a turbulent socio-political atmosphere.
{king_oleshe_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+10% to trade revenue. \n+10% to the commander’s movement range.
¬----------------------

{king_mensk}Prince of Mensk
{king_mensk_desc}Named Prince of Mensk.\n\nDescription:\nThe earliest settlements in the territory of the modern city date back to the 9th century. The Svisloch river valley was inhabited by two East Slavic tribes: Krivichi and Dregovichi. Around 980, the territory of the modern city entered the Principality of Polotsk. The first annalistic mention of Mensk is contained in The Tale of Bygone Years; it dates back to 1067, when the sons of the Kiev prince Yaroslav the Wise appeared under the walls of Mensk, then owned by the Polotsk prince Vseslav Bryachislavich. Veche refused to surrender the city, but the Yaroslavichi brothers captured and destroyed it, and then defeated the troops of Vseslav Bryachislavich who came to the aid in the battle of Nemiga. After the death of Vseslav Bryachislavich, his sons divided his father's possessions into estates, as a result of which Mensk became the capital of a separate principality. Gleb Vseslavich became the first men’s prince. The capital status and favorable geographical position contributed to the economic development of the city and its transformation into a major trade and craft center. However, frequent internecine howls the princes hindered the prosperity of the city.
{king_mensk_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+10% to tax revenues.\n+1 to loyalty 
¬----------------------

{king_polotsk}Prince of Polotsk
{king_polotsk_desc}Named Prince Polotsky.\n\nDescription:\nThe first annalistic mention of Polotsk dates back to 862. The historical core of the city was the fortified settlement of Krivichi, which appeared on the site of the ancient settlement of Bancer culture on the banks of the Polota River, not far from its mouth into the Western Dvota. The city character of the fortifications of the settlement dates back to the middle of the 10th century. In the middle of the 10th century the Principality of Polotsk arose. It occupied the territory in the basin of the Western Dvina, the upper reaches of the Berezina and Neman. In 986, the Viking missionary Torvaldo The first Christian church and monastery of St. John the Baptist on the territory of Belarus was founded by a traveler, which served as the beginning of the spread of Christianity on Belarusian lands. In 988-1001, Izyaslav Vladimirovich, the son of Rogneda Rogvolodovna and Vladimir Svyatoslavich, the founder of the Polotsk princes dynasty, reigned in Polotsk. In the middle of the 11th century, the territories of the Principality of Polotsk expanded significantly, the cities of Usvyat and Vitebsk, as well as the lands between the Western Dvina and Disna, joined. Under Vseslav Bryachislavich Polotsk to grace has reached its highest power.
{king_polotsk_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+10% tax income.
¬----------------------

The historical core of the city was the fortified Krivichi settlement, which arose at the site of the ancient settlement of Bancer culture on the banks of the Polota River, not far from its confluence with the West in the Dvota River The urban character of the fortifications of the settlement dates back no earlier than the middle of the X century. In the middle of the X century, the Principality of Polotsk arose. It occupied the territory in the basin of the Western Dvina, the upper reaches of the Berezina and Neman. In 986, the Viking missionary Torval Traveler’s house, the first Christian church and monastery of St. John the Baptist was founded on the territory of Belarus, which served as the beginning of the spread of Christianity in the Belarusian lands. In 988-1001, Izyaslav Vladimirovich, son of Rogneda Rogvolodovna and Vladimir Svyatoslavich, the founder of the Polotsk dynasty, reigned in Polotsk. By the middle of the XI century, the territories of the Principality of Polotsk expanded significantly, the cities of Usvyat and Vitebsk, as well as the land between the Western Dvina and Disna, joined. Under Vseslav Bryachislavich Polotsk The Principality reached its highest power.

{king_pskov}Prince of Pskov
{king_pskov_desc}Named Prince Pskov.\n\nDescription:\nMiddle - third quarter of the 1st millennium AD dates back to the site of the Pskov settlement, the Slavic settlement "culture of long mounds", left by migrants from the south. In the 7th-9th centuries, a kindred family existed on the site of the Pskov settlement Pskov settlement, which died in a fire in the early 860s, is the carrier of the Ryuhe culture. The end of the 9th century - the beginning of the 11th century dates back to the Pskov settlement, which is represented by wooden log buildings with plank floors on logs and someone in the corner. The area of ​​the Pskov settlement reached 12–15 hectares by the middle of the 10th century, and the population increased by 5–7 times. This indicates the appearance of immigrant immigrants in the city, including those of Scandinavian origin. The official date of foundation of Pskov is considered to be 903 - year the first mention of the city in the annals. Until the 12th century, Pskov was part of Kievan Rus. After the proclamation of the Novgorod feudal republic in 1136, the city came under the rule of Novgorod.
{king_pskov_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues. \n+1 to cruelty. \n+1 to morale of soldiers. \n-1 from fidelity.
¬----------------------

{dearmad_smolensk}Prince of Smolensk
{dearmad_smolensk_desc}Named by Prince Smolensky.\n\nDescription:\nSmolensk is one of the most ancient cities of Ancient Rus`. In the dated part of the "Tale of Bygone Years" it is first mentioned under 862 as the center of the Krivichi tribal union. It is also mentioned in the Ustyuzhensky arch in the record under 863, when Askold and Dir, on a campaign from Novgorod to Constantinople, bypassed the city, as it was greatly fortified and crowded. In 882 the city was captured and annexed by Prince Oleg to Kievan Rus. After the establishment of the Principality of Smolensk in 1054, the youngest sons of Yaroslav were planted on the Smolensk table. In 1127, the Prince of Kiev, Mstislav the Great, gave Smolensk an inheritance to his 17-year-old son Rostislav Mstislavich. After the death of his father, Rostislav became virtually an independent prince and reigned in the city until 1160, when he occupied the throne of Kiev. Thus, the foundation was laid for an independent Smolensk principality, under the rule of the Rostislavich dynasty, which on the eve of the Mongol-Tatar invasion was one of the most powerful principalities of Rus`.
{dearmad_smolensk_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+10% tax revenue.
¬----------------------
{idearmad_smolensk}Khan of Smolensk
{idearmad_smolensk_desc}Named Khan of Smolensk.\n\nDescription:\nSmolensk is one of the most ancient cities of Ancient Rus`. In the dated part of the "Tale of Bygone Years" it is first mentioned under 862 as the center of the Krivichi tribal union. In 1127, the Prince of Kiev, Mstislav the Great, gave Smolensk an inheritance to his 17-year-old son Rostislav Mstislavich. After the death of his father, Rostislav became virtually an independent prince and reigned in the city until 1160, when he occupied the throne of Kiev. Thus, the foundation was laid for an independent Smolensk principality, under the rule of the Rostislavich dynasty, which on the eve of the Mongol-Tatar invasion was one of the most powerful principalities  of Rus`.

{dearmad_novgorod}Grand Prince of Novgorod
{dearmad_novgorod_desc}Named Prince of Lord Veliky Novgorod.\n\nDescription:\nIn the 7th century, a Slavic village appeared on the Prost river. In the first half of the 750s, Scandinavian settlements appeared in the lower reaches of Volkhov (Staraya Ladoga), but at the turn of the 760–770 years the Vikings were replaced by the Slavs. In the 9th century, at the source of the Volkhov River, on the outskirts of Slavensky hill, the settlement of Rurikovo Gorodishche already existed. Novgorod appeared around the turn of the 9th – 10th centuries or at the beginning of the 10th century]. The second most important after Kiev center of Kievan Rus, the capital of the Novgorod Principality. In the 11th century, many princes of Polotsk made raids on Novgorod. Vseslav Bryachislavich managed to capture the city in 1067. Then in Novgorod churches were looted, part of the city was burned, part of the population was taken into slavery. By the beginning of the XII century, Novgorod land included part of the Baltic states, part of Karelia, the southern part of Finland, the southern coast of Ladoga, Obonezhie, the shores of the Northern Dvina, vast expanses of the European north up to the Urals.
{dearmad_novgorod_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to income from taxes. \n+5% to income from trade. \n+5% to legitimacy. \n-5% to corruption. \n+2 to fidelity.
¬----------------------

{king_ladoga}Prince of Ladoga
{king_ladoga_desc}Named Prince of Ladoga.\n\nDescription:\nThe settlement appeared around 753 with the advent of the Scandinavians, in the 760s the Ladoga settlement was destroyed by representatives of the early Slavic culture. The settlement was a trade center of the North of Rus`. Around the 870s, the first wooden fortress was built at the confluence of the Ladozhka River in the Volkhov. In 862, the Varangians Rurik was called to reign. In 997, Eirik, the future Norwegian ruler, attacked Ladoga. The first Ladoga fortress, which existed for more than 100 years, was destroyed. The ancient Staroladozh fortress, which has become the "heart" of today's Staraya Ladoga, stands at the confluence of the Elena River in the Volkhov. In the times of Novgorod Rus, it was a strategically important place, because it was the only possible harbor where sea vessels could not stop, unable to sail along the thresholds of Volkhov.
{king_ladoga_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues. \n+5% to public order in the role of governor. \n+1 to popularity.\n+5% to general’s movement range.
¬----------------------

{king_beloozero}Prince of Beloozersky
{king_beloozero_desc}Named Prince of Beloozersky.\n\nDescription:\nFirst mentioned in the "Tale of Bygone Years" in 862 as the city of Beloozero, which participated in the calling of the Vikings. "They drove the Varangian overseas, and did not give them tribute, and began to rule themselves, and there was no truth among them, and the clan stood up for the clan, and they had strife, and began to fight with each other." In 882, according to the "Tale of Bygone Years", the whole Belozersky (the ancestors of the present Vepsians) took part in the campaign of Oleg the Prophet to Smolensk and Kiev. In 1071, an uprising of smerds, instigated by the sorcerers, breaks out on Beloozero, which suppresses voivode Yan Vyshatich, collecting tribute for Prince Chernigov's Svyatoslav Yaroslavich. In the middle of the XII century, Belozersky took part in the capture of Kiev by the squads of the Grand Duke of Vladimir Andrei Bogolyubsky, and at the end of the century they participated in the campaign of the Grand Duke of Vladimir Vsevolod the Big Nest on the Volga Bulgaria.
{king_beloozero_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to income from taxes. \n+5% to income from trade.\n+10% to general’s movement range. 
¬----------------------
{iking_beloozero}Khan of Beloozero
{iking_beloozero_desc}Named Khan of Beloozero.\n\nDescription:\nFirst mentioned in the "Tale of Bygone Years" in 862 as the city of Beloozero, which participated in the calling of the Varangians. "They drove the Varangian overseas, and did not give them tribute, and began to rule themselves, and there was no truth among them, and the clan stood up for the clan, and they had strife, and began to fight with each other." In 882, according to the "Tale of Bygone Years", the whole Belozersky (the ancestors of the present Vepsians) took part in the campaign of Oleg the Prophet to Smolensk and Kiev. In 1071, an uprising of smerds, instigated by the sorcerers, breaks out on Beloozero, which suppresses voivode Yan Vyshatich, collecting tribute for Prince Chernigov's Svyatoslav Yaroslavich. In the middle of the XII century, Belozersky took part in the capture of Kiev by the squads of the Grand Duke of Vladimir Andrei Bogolyubsky, and at the end of the century they participated in the campaign of the Grand Duke of Vladimir Vsevolod the Big Nest on the Volga Bulgaria.
{iking_beloozero_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to income from taxes. \n+5% to income from trade.\n+10% to general’s movement range. 
¬----------------------
{oking_beloozero}Beloozero Strategist
{oking_beloozero_desc}Named the Strategist of Beloozero.\n\nDescription:\nFirst mentioned in the "Tale of Bygone Years" in 862 as the city of Beloozero, which participated in the calling of the Varangians. "They drove the Varangian overseas, and did not give them tribute, and began to rule themselves, and there was no truth among them, and the clan stood up for the clan, and they had strife, and began to fight with each other." In 882, according to the "Tale of Bygone Years", the whole Belozersky (the ancestors of the present Vepsians) took part in the campaign of Oleg the Prophet to Smolensk and Kiev. In 1071, an uprising of smerds, instigated by the sorcerers, breaks out on Beloozero, which suppresses voivode Yan Vyshatich, collecting tribute for Prince Chernigov's Svyatoslav Yaroslavich. In the middle of the XII century, Belozersky took part in the capture of Kiev by the squads of the Grand Duke of Vladimir Andrei Bogolyubsky, and at the end of the century they participated in the campaign of the Grand Duke of Vladimir Vsevolod the Big Nest on the Volga Bulgaria.

{dearmad_moscow}Prince of Moscow
{dearmad_moscow_desc}Named Prince of Moscow.\n\nDescription:\nThe age of Moscow is not exactly known. Since the end of the 1st millennium AD, Slavs settled in the area of ​​modern Moscow: Vyatichi and Krivichi. Vyatichi made up the bulk of the original population of Moscow. that in the XI century there already existed a settlement, protected by a rampart and a moat, which allows it to be attributed to cities. In the XI century in Moscow there was a church, it was the Church of the Beheading of John the Baptist at the Borovitsky Gate. The first chronicle mention is the Ipatievsky annals on the heel Itza, April 4, 1147, when Rostov-Suzdal Prince Yuri Dolgoruky received his friends and allies in the town called Moscow, led by Novgorod-Seversky Prince Svyatoslav Olgovich. In the 12th century Novgorod birch bark, it is mentioned that new wooden fortifications were built here. the territory increased 3-4 times. By 1156, the chronicle attributes the foundation of the city of Moscow to Dolgoruky, among Dmitrov and other Suzdal cities, in the sense of building a wooden fortress — the future Kremlin.
{dearmad_moscow_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues. \n+1 to cruelty. \n-1 from fidelity.\n+5% to general’s movement range.

{king_yaroslavl}Prince of Yaroslavl
{king_yaroslavl_desc}Named Prince of Yaroslavl.\n\nDescription:\nYaroslavl is the oldest existing city on the Volga. It was laid by Prince Yaroslav the Wise during his Rostov reign (988-1010) on the cape above Strelka at the site or near the pagan settlement Medvezhy Ugol The reference to Yaroslavl in The Tale of Bygone Years dates back to 1071. According to the annals, the Magi, headed by 300 people, went up the Volga, killing the "noble wives" along the way, and reached Beloozero, where their detachment was defeated and they were executed by the governor Jan Vyshatich. Judging by their di confused with Yan, they were not so much defenders of the ancient pagan faith as adherents of bogomilism. In 1149, the city environs were devastated by the Novgorodians, therefore, the second mention of Yaroslavl was made in the annals. In 1152, the city was besieged by the Volga Bulgars, who suddenly approached it and immediately went to it however, they didn’t succeed in taking the city at once; they had to start a siege, which was lifted by help from Rostov in time. During the first two centuries of its existence, Yaroslavl remained a small border city of Rost ovo-Suzdal, only in 1218 Yaroslavl became the capital city of the new Yaroslavl principality.
{king_yaroslavl_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues. \n-1 from fidelity.
¬----------------------
{iking_yaroslavl}Khan of Yaroslavl
{iking_yaroslavl_desc}Named Khan of Yaroslavl.\n\nDescription:\nYaroslavl is the oldest existing city on the Volga. Judging by their debate here and there with Yan, they were not so much defenders of the ancient pagan faith as adherents of bogomilism. In 1149, the city neighborhoods were ravaged by Novgorodians, therefore, the second mention of Yaroslavl was made in the annals. In 1152 the city was besieged by the Volga Bulgars, who suddenly approached him and immediately went on an attack however, they were not able to take the city immediately, they had to start a siege, which was lifted in time from Rostov. ¬------------------------------------------------- -----------------
{dearmad_rostov}Prince of Rostov
{dearmad_rostov_desc}Named Prince of Rostov.\n\nDescription:\nThe first fortified settlement on Lake Nero, appeared in the land of Meri in the 7th century and has long been a Meryan tribal center. The settlement was a bastion of a pagan cult similar to the Slavic Veles, up to the XII century. They repeatedly expelled sent bishops and, according to some information, even killed them. In the IX century, Rostov, along with all the possessions of the Meryan tribe, was annexed to the state of Rurik with its capital in Ladoga. In the campaign of Prince Oleg to Constantinople, the Rostovs participated as allies: in the text of the contract between Oleg and the Greeks, they undertook to pay tribute to certain Rus` cities, which included Rostov. Since the second half of the 11th century, Rostov has been one of the two main cities of the Rostov-Suzdal Principality. Until the 12th century, Rostov was divided into two parts of the Chude with pagan temples and Rus` with the Christian church. Two people got along well with each other, in case of any threat they gathered a militia together.
{dearmad_rostov_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+1 soldier morale. \n+10% to tax revenues.
¬----------------------

{dearmad_ryazan}Prince of Ryazan
{dearmad_ryazan_desc}Named Prince of Ryazan.\n\nDescription:\nSlavic tribes (namely, Vyatichi) came to Oka in the area of ​​the VI century. Already in the 7th-8th centuries around the future Ryazan a whole network of settlements was founded - settlements and settlements. The largest of them are Borkovskoye, Glebovskoye, Khrapovskoye. Arable farming was laid as the basis of the Vyatichi economy. In the VI century, Vyatichi paid tribute to the Volga Khazars. In 966, the Kiev prince Svyatoslav Igorevich defeated their powerful power and subjugated the Vyatichi, including Ryazan and Murom lands in the Kiev state. It is known that Vyatichi participated in Oleg’s famous campaigns on Constantinople. Already in the 7th-8th centuries, near Ryazan, on the Borkovsky island, a fortified trading city was located. At the beginning of the XII century, the Ryazan lands became an independent Murom-Ryazan principality. It was a time of competition between the largest cities of Ryazan and Murom for the right to be the capital of a new state. Ryazan won the battle, since it was here that the princely court was taking place, the episcopal department was located, and there were also serious fortifications.
{dearmad_ryazan_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+1 to the morale of soldiers. \n+2 to the command during the defense of the city.
¬----------------------

{king_susdal}Prince of Vladimir
{king_susdal_desc}Named Prince of Vladimir.\n\nDescription:\n990 year — annalistic news of the founding of the city named by Prince Vladimir Svyatoslavich on the Klyazma River. About 1108 — the construction of the fortress by Vladimir Monomakh. Vladimir begins to grow and strengthen thanks to the care of Vladimir Monom Yuri Dolgoruky, who strengthened him as a stronghold of defense of the Rostov-Suzdal principality. Yuri Dolgoruky, who lived in Suzdal at that time, kept his residence ("compound") here. The city flourished due to Prince Andrei Bogolyubsky, who at 115 On 7th year he moved the capital of the principality here. In Vladimir, the Assumption and Dmitrievsky Cathedrals were erected in Vladimir as the new capital of North-Eastern Rus`. The Golden Gate became the central point of defense of the city and at the same time the symbol of the capital's status. To decorate the city, Prince Andrey spared neither money nor strength, having brought from Kiev Stone-cutters, along the perimeter of the city from the east, south and north, Silver, Copper and Irininy gates were built. In Vladimir and neighboring Suzdal, a Vladimir-Suzdal icon-painting school was formed; chronicle. The highest power of the Principality of Vladimir reaches the reign of Vsevolod the Big Nest. For the princes of Vladimir, the title of the "greats" is finally assigned, and Vladimir is the "capital city of all Rus`."
{king_susdal_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+10% to tax revenues. \n+1 to agriculture (increases the city’s income from agriculture).
¬----------------------

{king_murom}Prince of Murom
{king_murom_desc}Named Prince of Murom.\n\nDescription:\nMur was the extreme eastern outpost of Rus`. It was located at the crossroads of trade routes between Rus` and Bulgaria. Prince of Kiev Vladimir bequeathed to his son Gleb. According to legend, Prince Gleb received the city of Mur , made an attempt to convert its population to Christianity, but failed and was forced to escape from discontent in the fortified courtyard. Over time, Murom became more and more important as a shopping center. Bulgars repeatedly attacked Murom until it was fixed here the superiority of the Rus. Relatively long peace periods contributed to the development of crafts and trade. It is famous for its crafts: pottery, blacksmithing, bone carving, metalworking. Moore more and more strengthened his importance as a prominent Russian city on the Oka. From 1054 he became the possession of the Chernigov princes, who turned it into Chernigov princes center of the Murom-Ryazan inheritance. After the princely feuds and the congress of Rus`n princes in Lyubech in 1097, Murom fell into the lot of Yaroslav. The prince threatened and promises forced the Muromites to accept Christianity and baptized people .Synovya Jaroslav after the civil war divided the principality into two independent, Murom and Ryazan, which greatly weakened the position of Murom, which is why he often falls prey to the Bulgars.
{king_murom_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues. \n+5% to public order in the role of governor. \n+1 to popularity.
¬----------------------

{king_narovchat}Prince of Narovchat
{king_narovchat_desc}Named the ruler of Narovchat.\n\nDescription:\nMordovian settlements appeared in the 4th-3rd century BC. In the XII century, on the Moksha River, the Narovchatsky fortified settlement appears, like the Burtass fortress - an outpost in Mordovian lands. As new lands are developed, the settlement turns into a full-fledged city - the economic and administrative center of the Upper Primokshan. The fortifications of the Narovchatsky settlement, now known as the "hillocks", were built in the late XII - early XIII centuries.
{king_narovchat_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+1 to agriculture (increases the city’s income from agriculture). \n+10% to the commander’s travel range without an army.
¬----------------------

{oking_narovchat_desc}Named the ruler of Narovchat.\n\nDescription:\nMordovian settlements appeared in the 4th-3rd century BC. In the XII century, on the Moksha River, the Narovchatsky fortified settlement appears, like the Burtass fortress - an outpost in Mordovian lands. As new lands are developed, the settlement turns into a full-fledged city - the economic and administrative center of the Upper Primokshan. The fortifications of the Narovchatsky settlement, now known as the "hillocks", were built in the late XII - early XIII centuries.
{oking_narovchat_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+1 to agriculture (increases the city’s income from agriculture). \n+10% to the commander’s travel range without an army.
¬------------------------------------------------- -----------------
{king_sharukan}Prince of Sharukan
{king_sharukan_desc}Named Prince Sharukansky.\n\nDescription:\nPresumably the city of Sharukan appeared on the basis of the Alans settlement, had a mixed population and was a winter refuge of the Polovtsy. The city consisted of a relatively small number of stone buildings and a much larger number of nomad yurts. In 1111 and 1116, Sharukan was captured by the troops of Vladimir Vsevolodovich Monomakh and other princes. From ancient manuscripts it is known that the battle of 1111 began due to the clash of the opposing forces of the hunters. Sharukani’s men violated the bans that were unbreakable under Vladimir Vsevolodovich Monomakh and were severely punished for this. The exact dates of the battle for Sharukan are unknown, but, according to the surviving chronicles, it did not last long. In the XII - early XIII centuries, Sharukan was desolate and fell into decay.
{king_sharukan_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues. \n+10% to the commander’s movement range.
¬----------------------

{king_azaq}Prince of Azak
{king_azaq_desc}Named Prince of Azak.\n\nDescription:\nThe first Scythian settlements appeared about 2 thousand years ago. During the Scythian era, many settlements arose in the Northern Azov region, which subsequently played an important role in the development and establishment of the region, for example, the Tanais Bosporus colony. Also in the territory of present Azov there were two Greco-Meotian settlements, which were called Paniardis and Patarva. Due to its favorable position, extensive trade has developed here. Already in the 6-8 centuries, Iranian-speaking nomads were replaced by numerous Turkic tribes, and later by the Huns, Bulgarians, Avars, Khazars. In the 10th century, after the defeat of the Khazars in Rus`, the Tymutarakan principality and the Khazar fortress Sarkel became a city of Rus` called Belaya Vezha, The Sea of ​​Azov increased flow of the Slavic population. And in 1067 the city was subjugated by the Polovtsy and became known as Azov.
{king_azaq_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to trade revenue. \n+15% to the commander’s movement range.\n+1 Cavalry Command. 
¬----------------------

{king_tmutarakan}Prince of Tmutarakan
{king_tmutarakan_desc}Named Prince of Tmutarakan.\n\nDescription:\nThe city was founded by the Greeks from the island of Lesbos. In the 6th century, the Bosporus became a federation or part of the Byzantine Empire of Justinian I. In the 6th century, the city was conquered by the Turkic Kaganate and since that time received the new name Tumen-Tarkhan. Soon after the collapse of the Turkic Kaganate, Tumentarkhan became Khazar and is sometimes referred to as Samkerts in the sources of the 9th-10th centuries. . At this time, under the influence of raids, he turned into a fortress. The population of the city was multi-ethnic. Greeks, Armenians, Khazars, Alans settled here. The religious situation was also variegated: Christianity coexisted with Judaism and Tengrianism. The bulk of the population was engaged in trade. After the defeat of the Khazar Khaganate in 965 by the Kiev prince Svyatoslav Igorevich, the city came under the rule of Rus`. Through Tmutarakan, economic and political ties were maintained between the principalities of Rus`, the peoples of the North Caucasus and Byzantium. Greeks, Alans, Khazars, Slavs and Armenians continued to live in the city. After 1094, references to Tmutarakan disappear from chronicles of Rus`.
{king_tmutarakan_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues. \n+1 to piety.
¬----------------------

{king_khlynov}Prince of Vyatka
{king_khlynov_desc}Named Prince of the Vyatka Land.\n\nDescription:\nIn the first half of the 1st millennium AD, the Finno-Ugric tribes of the Udmurts (in the eastern part) and the Mari (in the western part) are formed in the basin of the Vyatka, in the north of the basin - tribes Komi. At the end of the XII - the beginning of the XIII centuries, the settlement of Vyatka land with the first rusichi immigrants began; they founded the first Rus` cities Nikulitsyn, Kotelnich, Khlynov on the banks of the Vyatka. With the beginning of the Mongol-Tatar yoke, the influx of immigrants sharply increased.
{king_khlynov_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues.\n+10% to general’s movement range. 
¬----------------------

{king_kazan}Prince of Kazan
{king_kazan_desc}Named Prince of Kazan.\n\nDescription:\nKazan was founded in 1004-1005. as a border outpost on the northern borders of the Volga Bulgaria. Ancient Kazan appears in the form of a small, but rather strongly fortified fortress, with powerful stone walls with a base width of about 1.8 - 2 m, made of untreated limestone “dry” or using clay-limestone mortar. Kazan is experiencing growth, becoming an important trade and political center. The favorable geographical position at the intersection of major trade routes connecting East and West contributes to the growth of the city.
{king_kazan_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues. \n+10% to the commander’s movement range.\n+1 to cruelty.

{dearmad_bulgar}Prince of Bulgaria
{dearmad_bulgar_desc}Named Prince of Bulgaria.\n\nDescription:\nThe city was founded in the 10th century by the Bulgars, Turkic-speaking tribes living in the Volga region. At first it was a small fortification, later it grew to the size of a city. The high coast at the confluence of the Kama River in the Volga created excellent conditions for the overview of the surrounding area and river navigation. In a short time he became the largest center of trade in his region. Soon after its foundation, Islam became the main religion of the Bulgars. In its heyday, the town was considered one of the centers of handicraft. Many skilled artisans, jewelers, blacksmiths and tailors lived in it.
{dearmad_bulgar_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus:\n+5% tax income.\n+1 command.\n+1 morale of soldiers on the battlefield.\n+1 cruelty.\n+15% general movement range.\n+1 loyalty. 
¬----------------------

{king_yelabuga}Prince of Yelabuga
{king_yelabuga_desc}Named Prince Elabuzhsky.\n\nDescription:\nThe exact date of foundation of Elabuga is unknown, the settlement was built by the Bulgars at the turn of the X-XI centuries, at the site of the winter crossing the Kama River. In the Bulgarian period, the settlement became an integral part of the trade-caravan road from the central regions of the Volga Bulgaria to the Middle and Upper Prikamye and further to the Arctic Ocean. In the XII century. A white-stone mosque-castle (Ak-mosque) with eight towers and half towers was built.
{king_yelabuga_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+1 to command when defending the city. \n+5% to the commander’s movement range.

{king_jaiksk}Prince of Saray
{king_jaiksk_desc}Named the Prince of Sarai.\n\nDescription:\nThe ancient city of Sarai Batu, the capital of the Golden Horde, was founded by Batu Khan in 1250. In the beginning, it was a nomad's rate, which eventually grew into a city. Sarai Batu was the main political center of the Golden Horde, but the economic center probably did not immediately. The first coins were issued here about 30 years after the foundation. About 75 thousand people lived in Saray-Batu. The population was multinational: the Mongols, Kipchaks, Alans, Circassians, Rusichi, Bulgars, Byzantines lived here. Each ethnic group settled in its quarter, where there was everything necessary for life: school, church, bazaar, cemetery. In the city there were quarters of artisans: potters, jewelers, glass blowers, bone cutters, masters in smelting and metal processing.
{king_jaiksk_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues. \n+1 to the cavalry command.
¬----------------------

{king_embi}Prince of Yaika
{king_embi_desc}Named Prince of Yaik.\n\nDescription:\nYaik located in the center of the Eurasian steppes, goes back to the Neolithic era. In the 1st millennium BC, during the heyday of nomadic cattle breeding, Yaik was associated with the Savromato - Sarmatian tribes that lived here. The first fortified settlements were erected by the Sarmatian-Alanian and Oguz-Pecheneg tribes. In 1219-1221 the steppes were invaded by the Mongol invaders led by Genghis Khan. The area has become an integral part of the state of the Golden Horde.
{king_embi_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues. \n+1% to the commander’s movement range.
¬----------------------

{king_astrakhan}Prince of Saksin
{king_astrakhan_desc}Named Prince of Saksin.\n\nDescription:\nItil is the capital of the Khazar Haganate in the middle of the VIII-X centuries. The name literally translates as "Big River". Woznik on the site of a winter road as a Khan’s headquarters. In sources IX, the city appears under the name Hamlidge (Hamlykh), which can be understood as a Khan's city. The name Itil appears in the 10th century. Itil was a multinational and religiously diverse city inhabited by Jews, Christians, Muslims, shamanists and pagans, many of whom were merchants from other countries. the needs of each faith There were religious temples: churches, mosques and synagogues. The city had about 30 quarterly mosques with schools and one cathedral mosque with a minaret. To resolve disputes, there were seven judges: two for Jews, Muslims and Christians, and one for all pagans. 968 / In 969, Itil was taken by the Kiev prince Svyatoslav Igorevich and completely destroyed. For some time the city was under occupation, and the Khazar ruler lived in exile on the coast in the possession of Khorezm. After the departure of the Rus, the royal court was able to return. According to al-Biruni, in the 11th century, Itilezhal in razvalinah.V XII-early XIII century in the Lower Volga there was a large city Saxin.
{king_astrakhan_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus:\n+5% tax income.\n+5% trade income.\n+1 loyalty\n+5% public order as a governor.\n+1 popularity. 
¬----------------------
{iking_astrakhan}Khan of Saksin
{iking_astrakhan_desc}Named Khan Saksin.\n\nDescription:\nItil is the capital of the Khazar Haganate in the middle of the VIII-X centuries. The name literally translates as "Big River". Woznik on the site of a winter road as a Khan’s headquarters. In sources IX the city appears under the name Hamlidge (Hamlykh), which can be understood as a Khan's city. The name Itil appears in the 10th century. Itil was a multinational and religiously diverse city inhabited by Jews, Christians, Muslims, shamanists and pagans, many of whom were merchants from other countries. the needs of every denomination oval religious churches: churches, mosques and synagogues. The city had about 30 quarterly mosques with schools and one cathedral mosque with a minaret. To resolve disputes, there were seven judges: two for Jews, Muslims and Christians, and one for all pagans. In 968 / In 969, Itil was taken by the Kiev prince Svyatoslav Igorevich and completely destroyed. For some time the city was under occupation, and the Khazar ruler lived in exile on the coast in the possession of Khorezm. After the departure of the Rus, the royal court was able to return. According to al-Biruni, in the 11th century, Itil lying down l in ruins. In the XII — beginning of the XIII century in the Lower Volga region there was a large city Saksin.
{iking_astrakhan_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus:\n+5% tax income.\n+5% trade income.\n+1 loyalty\n+5% public order as a governor.\n+1 popularity. 
¬----------------------
{oking_astrakhan}Saksin Strategist
{oking_astrakhan_desc}Named Saksin’s Strategist.\n\nDescription:\nItil is the capital of the Khazar Haganate in the middle of the 8th – 10th centuries. The name literally translates as “Big River”. Woznik on the site of a winter road is like a Khan’s headquarters. In sources IX the city appears under the name Hamlidge. (Hamlykh), which can be understood as a Khan's city. The name Itil appears in the 10th century. Itil was a multinational and religiously diverse city inhabited by Jews, Christians, Muslims, shamanists and pagans, many of whom were merchants from other countries. the needs of every faith There were religious temples: churches, mosques and synagogues. The city had about 30 quarterly mosques with schools and one cathedral mosque with a minaret. To resolve disputes, there were seven judges: two for Jews, Muslims and Christians, and one for all pagans. 968 / In 969, Itil was taken by the Kiev prince Svyatoslav Igorevich and completely destroyed. For some time the city was under occupation, and the Khazar ruler lived in exile on the coast in the possession of Khorezm. After the departure of the Rus, the royal court was able to return. According to al-Biruni, in the 11th century, Itillay in ruins. In the XII — beginning of the XIII century in the Lower Volga region there was a large city Saksin.
{oking_astrakhan_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus:\n+5% tax income.\n+5% trade income.\n+1 loyalty\n+5% public order as a governor.\n+1 popularity. 
¬------------------------------------------------- -----------------
{dearmad_sarkel}Prince of White Vezha
{dearmad_sarkel_desc}Named the Prince of the White Vezha.\n\nDescription:\nSarkel Fortress (literally "the white house") was built between 834 and 837 on the Don River. At the request of the rulers of Khazaria, who turned to the Byzantine emperor Theophilus, the construction was carried out with the mediation of Byzantine engineers. Sarkel became the main outpost on the northwestern border of the Khazars. It was based on a regularly replaced garrison of three hundred soldiers. The city on the trade route became a busy shopping center. The fortress and city of Sarkela were captured by Kievan Rus under Prince Svyatoslav I in 965. The city was renamed the White Vezha and populated by the Slavs. He remained Slavic until the XII century. In 1103, Vladimir Monomakh took with him to Rus` the Pechenegs and Torques. They formed the garrison of the White Vezha until the Polovtsy ravaged the city in 1117 and it was abandoned by the inhabitants.
{dearmad_sarkel_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues. \n+10% to the commander’s movement range.
¬----------------------

{king_magas}Prince of Magas
{king_magas_desc}Named the Prince of Magas.\n\nDescription:\nThe capital of the Alans Magas was allegedly founded in the VI century. In 943, the famous Arab chronicler Al-Masoudi first reported the city. During its heyday, about 15 thousand inhabitants lived in the city. The Great Silk Road passed through Magas, providing the city with wealth and prosperity.

{dearmad_tbilisi}Prince of Tiflis \nLord of Georgia
{dearmad_tbilisi_desc}Was named Eristavi of Tbilisi and ruler of Georgia.\n\nDescription:\nIn 853 Tbilisi was captured by Arab forces led by Bug-Turk. In 914, the emir Abul-Kasim invades southern and eastern Georgia. In 979, with the help of David Kuropalat, an uprising was crushed Varda Sklira against Basil II. In 1008–1010, King Bagrat III created the Single Georgian State by annexing Kakheti and Ereti in 1010. In 1023, a peace treaty was signed between Georgia and Byzantium, and the Byzantines attacked Georgia again in 1028. In 1064 and 1068 two campaigns of the Seljuks on Gro In 1073, the feudal lords revolted against George II. In 1083, George II began to pay tribute to the Seljuks, in 1099 David IV the Builder stopped paying tribute. In 1104, David IV the Builder convenes the Ruiz-Urbnis Cathedral, and in 1106 construction of the Gelati Monastery began. 1110 from the Seljuk Turks were liberated by Samsvilda, in 1115 — Rustavi, in 1117 — Gishi, in 1118 — Laura was freed from the Seljuk Turks. On August 12, 1121 the Seljuk army was defeated by Georgians in the Battle of Didgor, later Tbilisi was liberated from the Seljuk Turks in 1122, in 1123 — Dmanisi.
{dearmad_tbilisi_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to income from taxes. \n+10% to income from trade. \n-1 from fidelity. \n-0.5% to poverty (improves general order and population growth) .

{king_kutaisi}Prince of Kutaisi \nRuler of Imeretia
{king_kutaisi_desc}Named Prince Kutaisi and ruler of Imereti.\n\nDescription:\nKutaisi was founded in the 6-5th centuries. BC .. The history of Kutaisi begins in the II century BC. The Byzantine historian Procopius of Caesarea (VI century) in the book “The war with the Goths” (book 4, section 14), describes Kutaisi in this area: “There are many populated villages in this area This is the best of all the lands of Colchis. Wine is produced here and many good fruits are grown, which is not found anywhere else in the rest of Lazik. A river named Rion flows through this country. From here the Eet proceeded and set off, and as a result the poets call him Koytay, and the Colchian land of Koytaida. Very close to Kutais is very strong a new fortification called Ufimery; he was guarded with his garrison by the manhole with all care. In ancient times, according to many ancient historians and writers, including the ones mentioned above, Kutaisi was the capital of the Colchis kingdom, that is, kolkhs - ancient Georgians. From VIII to XIII centuries Kutaisi was the capital of the Abkhazian Kingdom.
{king_kutaisi_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to income from taxes. \n+5% to income from trade. \n+1 to personal safety (reduced chance of death from an assassin). 
¬----------------------

{king_baku}Prince of Baku \nRuler of Shirvan
{king_baku_desc}Named Prince of Baku and ruler of Shirvan.\n\nDescription:\nFrom the Middle Ages, Baku was located in the historical region of Shirvan, north of the region of Azerbaijan. From the second half of the 9th century, Baku became part of the Shirvanshahs. The population was engaged in crafts, trade, fishing, horticulture and oil production. Until the 11th century, the beginning of Turkization, the population of Baku continued to speak the language of indigenous peoples. In the XII century, Baku was surrounded by a two-row fortress wall and a moat. The Maiden’s Tower also entered the city’s defense system.
{king_baku_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues. \n-1 from fidelity.\n+5% public order in role governor.\n+1 popularity.

{dearmad_yerevan}Prince of Yerevan \nRuler of Armenia
{dearmad_yerevan_desc}Named Prince of Yerevan and ruler of Armenia.\n\nDescription:\nThe earliest mention of the city refers to the year 607, when a certain Daniil from Yerevan was mentioned among the Armenian churchmen who remained faithful to the decisions of the Chalcedon Cathedral. Yerevan was one of the settlements in the zone Persian-Byzantine wars in Armenia in the 7th century, mentioned in connection with the Arab conquest: in August 650 it was besieged by Arabs, but to no avail. The city fell under Arab rule in 658. In 660 there was an anti-Arab uprising. With the fall of Arab power and the restoration of the Armenian statehood city was part of the Kingdom of Ani Bagratuni; in the XI century it was conquered by the Seljuks. The city was localized in the historical region of Kotayk, of the XIII century “Kotayk is the city of Yerevan with its own region”.
{dearmad_yerevan_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to income from taxes. \n+5% trade income.\n+10% mining income. \n+5% public order in the role of the governor. \n-1 from fidelity.

{king_ankara}Prince of Ankara
{king_ankara_desc}Named Prince of Ankara.\n\nDescription:\nAnkara is one of the oldest cities in Asia Minor. Known since the 7th century BC under the Greek name Angor or Ankir (Ἄγκυρα, "anchor"), located at the intersection of busy trade routes connecting Europe and Asia. In the late Byzantine period, a large number of wealthy Greek families lived in the city. In 1071, after the defeat of the Byzantine army at the Battle of Manzikert, Ankara came under the control of the Seljuks, although there was no total destruction of Christians here. beat off the Turks had knights participating in the 1st Crusade, but after their departure the Turks again occupied the city. In 1118 the Byzantines managed to temporarily regain control of Angira, but in 1176 they lost it again forever. At the end of the XII century Orthodoxy in the city quickly fell into decay .
{king_ankara_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues. \n+5% to trade revenues. \n+10% to the commander’s movement range.

{dearmad_iconium}Prince of Iconium
{dearmad_iconium_desc}Named Prince of Iconium.\n\nDescription:\nIn the Bible, Iconion (Iconium) is mentioned in the Acts of the Apostles (14: 1), the trips of the Apostle Paul are connected with the city. It is considered the birthplace of St. Paraskeva-Friday (III century). the time of the Roman emperor Claudius, the city was handed over to the veterans and received the name "Claudiconium." The city belonged to the Roman province of Lycaonia, in Greek times the city belonged to Phrygia. It is evident from the imperial coins that Iconium had the rights of the Roman colony. Iconium is especially often mentioned in the era of the Crusades. Konya District in the 1070s took herring uki.The power of the Seljuk state was gradually weakening, while Iconium was the capital, the state was called the Iconic Sultanate, and the name Konya appeared a couple of centuries later.Konya was an active center of both Turkish and Persian culture. During the Seljuk period, the famous poet and mathematician Omar Khayyam (1048–1131). In the XIII century Mevlana Jalaleddin Rumi lived and was buried here, here in 1244 he met with Shems Tabrizi, and they formed the Sufi order of Mevlevi.

{dearmad_caesarea}Prince of Caesarea
{dearmad_caesarea_desc}Named Prince of Caesarea.\n\nDescription:\n In ancient times, it was known as Caesarea of ​​Cappadocia, Caesarea, Mazak and Eusebius. It was the residence of the Cappadocian kings. Then, after the conversion of Cappadocia to the Roman province, it was renamed Cesecari of Tiberi Roman coins in Asia. It was the center of the spread of Christianity. After the division of Cappadocia into provinces under the emperor Valens, Caesarea became the capital. In the 4th century the local pulpit was occupied by St. Basil the Great. Arab general (and later the first caliph Umayyadov) Mu Avia invaded Cappadocia and temporarily took Caesarea from the Byzantines in 647. The city was called Caesarea by the Arabs, and later Kayseri by the Seljuk Turks, when it was captured by the Alps Arslan in 1067. The forces of the latter destroyed the city and destroyed its population. In 1074–1178 The area came under the control of the Danishmendids and was restored in 1134. The Anatolian sultanate controlled the city during 1178–1243. The city came under the rule of the Ottoman Empire in 1515. 
{dearmad_caesarea_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus:\n+10% tax income.\n+2 to defensive command during an assault.\n+2 loyalty\n+10% to general’s movement range. 
¬----------------------
{idearmad_caesarea}Caliph of Caesarea
{idearmad_caesarea_desc}Named by Caliph of Caesarea.\n\nDescription:\n In ancient times, it was known as Caesarea of ​​Cappadocia, Caesarea, Mazak and Eusebius. It was the residence of the Cappadocian kings. Then, after the conversion of Cappadocia to the Roman province, it was renamed the place of Caenari Roman coins in Asia. It was the center of the spread of Christianity. After the division of Cappadocia into provinces under the emperor Valens, Caesarea became the capital. In the 4th century the local pulpit was occupied by St. Basil the Great. Arab general (and later the first caliph Umayyadov) uavia invaded Cappadocia and temporarily took Caesarea from the Byzantines in 647. The city was called Caesarea by the Arabs, and later Kayseri by the Seljuk Turks, when it was captured by the Alps Arslan in 1067. The forces of the latter destroyed the city and destroyed its population. In 1074-1178 The area came under the control of the Danishmendids and was restored in 1134. The Anatolian sultanate controlled the city during 1178–1243. The city came under the rule of the Ottoman Empire in 1515. 
{idearmad_caesarea_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus:\n+10% tax income.\n+2 to defensive command during an assault.\n+2 loyalty\n+10% to general’s movement range.
