{king_sinop}Prince of Sinope
{king_sinop_desc}Named the Prince of Sinope.\n\nDescription:\nSinope is in ancient times one of the main Greek colonies on the southern coast of Pontus of Euxinus, on the peninsula of the Paflagona coast, east of Cape Karambis. The colony was founded, according to legend, by the companion of Jason Autolik, which had a temple and an oracle here. Under Mithridates Yevpator, who was born and educated here, Sinop became the residence of the Pontic king and was decorated with magnificent buildings. Statues of Autolycus were then taken to Rome between other works of art by Lucullus. a vigorous and autonomous city, Sinop was colonized by the Romans in 45 BC. Sinop trade was famous for Cinnabar. As it ascended in IV AD, the role and welfare of Sinop began to decline. According to the Crusader Charter 1204 on the division of the Byzantine Empire, Sinop was nominally included in the Latin Empire, but in fact it was never controlled. From 1205 he belonged to the Trebizond Empire, but on November 1, 1214 he took the Seljuk Sultan with his cunning, immediately turning all the Greek churches into mosques. Having conquered the city, the Turks knocked out to Sinop st citadel manifesto to locals in Greek.
{king_sinop_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to income from taxes. \n+5% to income from trade. \n-1 from fidelity.
¬----------------------

{king_diyarbakir}Prince of Diyarbakir
{king_diyarbakir_desc}Named Prince Diyarbakir.\n\nDescription:\nHistorical name of this ancient city is Amida or Amed. In IV, by the order of Constantius II, city walls of basalt hewn stones were erected around it. In 359, Amid was conquered by the Iranian Shah Shahap Shahap Shaap. Subsequently, Justinian I conquered the city and carried out additional fortification works. Then Amid again passed into Iranian hands. In 640 he was conquered by the Arab tribe Bekir (or Bekr), in his honor was named Diyarbekir. Diyarbekir was one of the points of the Great Silk Road. In 958 visa Ntians regained control of the city. In 1001, Diyarbekir became the residence of the Kurdish dynasty of the Mervanids. In 1085 it passed into Turkmen hands.
{king_diyarbakir_effects_desc}\nAnch Bonus:\n+10% tax income.\n+1 command when commanding infantry.\n+2 command in defense when assaulting.\n+5% lawfulness.\n-5% corruption .

{dearmad_mosul}Prince of Mosul
{dearmad_mosul_desc}Named Prince of Mosul.\n\nDescription:\nThe city passed into hands with the rise of the Sassanids in 225. In the second century, Christianity began to spread among the Assyrian population of Mosul. It became the bishop's residence of the Nestorians in VI. 637, during the Caliph Urim al-Khattaba, the city was annexed to the Righteous Caliphate. Mosul received the status of the capital of Mesopotamia under the Umayyads in VIII, when it reached the peak of prosperity. During the time of the Abbasids, the city was an important trading center due to its strategic location on the trade routes to India , Persia, and the Mediterranean. At the end of IX, control of the city was taken by General Abbasid Ishaq ibn Kundai, but in 893 Mosul came under the direct control of the Abbasids. In X Mosul came under the authority of the local Arab dynasty of the Hamdanids. From Mosul Hamdanides under Abdullahan ibn Ibn the son of Nasir al-Daul expanded their control over Jazira for the next several decades, first as governors of the Abbasids, and later as de facto independent rulers. A century later they were supplanted by the Ukaylids. In XI, Mosul was conquered by the Seljuks. During the reign of the semi-independent Atabeks in 1127, it became the center of the Zangid dynasty.
{dearmad_mosul_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to income from taxes. \n+5% to income from trade.
¬----------------------

{dearmad_baghdad}Prince of Baghdad
{dearmad_baghdad_desc}Named Prince of Baghdad.\n\nDescription:\nBaghdad was founded on the west bank of the Tigris River on July 30, 762. The construction of this city, originally the capital of the state of the Abbasids, began by order of the caliph Abu Jafar al-Mansur. After the seizure of power in the Arab Khalifa The Abbasids decided to move the capital from Damascus east, closer to Khorasan, which served as the stronghold of their supporters. The new capital was closer to the geographic center of the caliphate, which significantly expanded its eastern borders in VII – VIII. In IX – X, Baghdad turned into a major cultural and the center of the Middle Eastern territories. Craft and trade with other countries developed rapidly and successfully. Baghdad received various products and expensive goods from Arabia, India and Europe. Documents drawn up by the Arab scholar Ibn-Khordadbeh in IX mentioned the trade relations of Baghdad with merchants ar-Rus. During the reign of the Abbasids (VIII-XIII). After the collapse of the state of the Abbasids, the political and administrative role of the city fell significantly, but cultural significance remained important for all Arab countries. Baghdad quickly acquired a stat a major research center: in the beginning of XIII 30bibliotek.V opened more than 945 city became part Buyid dynasty to 1055 was on the territory of the Seljuks.
{dearmad_baghdad_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to income from taxes. \n+10% to income from trade. \n-1 from fidelity.\n+1 agriculture (increases city's agricultural income)

{idearmad_baghdad}Caliph of Baghdad
{idearmad_baghdad_desc}Named by Khalifa of Baghdad.\n\nDescription:\nBaghdad was founded on the western bank of the Tigris River on July 30, 762. The construction of this city, originally the capital of the state of the Abbasids, began by order of the caliph Abu Jafar al-Mansur. After the seizure of power in the Arab The Abbasids decided to move the capital from Damascus east, closer to Khorasan, which served as the stronghold of their supporters. The new capital was closer to the geographic center of the caliphate, which significantly expanded its eastern borders in VII – VIII. In IX – X, Baghdad turned into a large cultural and economic center of the Middle East territories. Craft and trade with other countries developed rapidly and successfully. Baghdad received various products and expensive goods from Arabia, India and Europe. Documents drawn up by the Arab scholar Ibn-Khordadbeh in IX mentioned trade relations of Baghdad with merchants ar-Rus. During the reign of the Abbasids (VIII-XIII). After the collapse of the state of the Abbasids, the political and administrative role of the city fell significantly, but cultural significance remained important for all Arab countries. Baghdad quickly acquired a hundred the tus of a major scientific center: at the beginning of the XIII more than 30 libraries were opened. In 945, the city became part of the Buid dynasty, from 1055 it was in the territory of the Seljuk state.

{king_basra}Prince of Basra
{king_basra_desc}Named Prince of Basra.\n\nDescription:\nIn VIII-IX, Basra became one of the most important cultural and economic centers of the Caliphate. The city was born by the Arabian universal scientist Ibn al-Khaysam, writer and theologian Al-Jahiz and the Sufi mystic Rabia al-Adawiya. In 869 a rebellion of zinjas — black slaves — broke out and in 871 the zinjs plundered Basra. In 923, a radical Muslim sect invaded the city and devastated it. From 945-1055, Baghdad and most of Iraq were ruled by the Buid dynasty. Abu al-Qasim al-Baridis who controlled Basra and B Asit, was defeated, and its lands in 947 also came under Buid rule. In the mid-900s, the Basid governor of Basra was Sanad al-Daul al-Khabashi, who built a library of 15,000 books. In 1122, the Seljuk military commander Imad al-Din Zangi received Basra as a feudal possession. At the same time, the Great Friday Mosque was built in the city. In 1126, Zengi suppressed the rebellion of the townspeople. The founder of the Assassin sect, Rashid ad-Din Sinan ("old man of the mountain") was born in Basra between 1131 and 1135.
{king_basra_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues. \n+1 to nobility.\n+5% legitimacy.\n-5% corruption.
¬----------------------

{king_ahvaz}Prince of Ahwaz
{king_ahvaz_desc}Named Prince Ahwaz.\n\nDescription:\nAhwas, the once-winter residence of the Persian kings, lies south of the ancient capital of Shushter, on the left bank of the Karuna River, which flows under the Basra into the connected Tigris and Euphrates. This place is built of stones made of stones taken from the ruins of the ancient city near which it is located. They were engaged in crushing cane sugar, which was brought here in large quantities. On one of the barrows there is a huge pillar built of plates and bricks painted in different colors; the Arabs call it Qasr, i.e. castle. Ancient Ahvaz was the main city of the same name provintsii.Sluzhil residence of the last Parthian king Artabanus IV. Mani appeared here under the monarchy as the founder of Manichaeism. In the fourth residence of the Nestorian bishop, he was transferred from here to Gondisapor. Under the rule of the Arabs, Ahwas flourished, was famous for his trade and for all of West Asia served as the main folding place for sugar trade.
{king_ahvaz_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues. \n+1 to agriculture (increases the city’s income from agriculture).

{dearmad_dongola}Prince of El Kaim
{dearmad_dongola_desc}Named Prince of El Kaim.\n \nDescription: El Kaim is a city on the banks of the Euphrates, through which the trade route to the East passed. Trade caravans constantly stopped here to replenish supplies and rest on the way to Baghdad. Part of the merchant's gold flowed into the treasury of the ruler of El Kaim as tax revenues and trade fees, as well as from successfully concluded transactions.

¬----------------------
{idearmad_dongola}Emir of El Kaim
{idearmad_dongola_desc}Named Emir of El Kaim.\n \nDescription: El Kaim is a city on the banks of the Euphrates, through which the trade route to the East passed. Trade caravans constantly stopped here to replenish supplies and rest on the way to Baghdad. Part of the merchant's gold flowed into the treasury of the ruler of El Kaim as tax revenues and trade fees, as well as from successfully concluded transactions. 
{idearmad_dongola_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to income from taxes. \n+5% to income from trade.
¬----------------------

Trade caravans constantly stopped here to replenish supplies and rest on the way to Baghdad. Part of the merchant's gold flowed into the treasury of the ruler of El Kaim as tax revenues and trade fees, as well as from successfully concluded transactions.

{king_konosha}Prince of Al Mumini
{king_konosha_desc}Named Prince Al-Mumini.\n\nDescription:\nHis early history resembles that of East Arabia. In 899 A.D. the region came under the control of Karmat leader Abu Tahir al-Jannabi and was declared independent of the Abbasid caliphate of Baghdad. Its capital was in al-Muminia near modern Hofuf. By 1000, Al-Hasa had become the 9th largest city.
{king_konosha_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to trade revenue. \n+10% to the commander’s movement range.
¬----------------------

{king_kermanshah}Prince of Kermanshah
{king_kermanshah_desc}Named Prince of Kermanshah.\n\nDescription:\nIn the 11th century, Kermanshah became a major cultural and commercial center in western Iran and the southern Kurdish populated areas in general. In the 12th century, the local population in the region began to be called "Kurds" - but not as an ethnic group, but as a social group that kept the traditions of Iranian nomads along with religious zeal. Often falling under the influence of the Kurdish nobility, the rulers lost loyalty to the central government and became local leaders. 
{king_kermanshah_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenue. \n-1 to fidelity.\n+1 to piety.
¬----------------------

In the 12th century, the local population in the region began to be called "Kurds" - but not as an ethnic group, but as a social group that kept the traditions of Iranian nomads along with religious zeal. Often falling under the influence of the Kurdish nobility, the rulers lost loyalty to the central government and became local leaders. 
{iking_kermanshah_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenue. \n-1 to fidelity.\n+1 to piety.

In the 12th century, the local population in the region began to be called "Kurds" - but not as an ethnic group, but as a social group that kept the traditions of Iranian nomads along with religious zeal. Often falling under the influence of the Kurdish nobility, the rulers lost loyalty to the central government and became local leaders.

{king_isfahan}Prince of Isfahan
{king_isfahan_desc}Named Prince of Isfahan.\n\nDescription:\nThe ancient Isfahan was part of the Elamite empire. Under the name of Aspandan, it became one of the main cities of the Medes when the Iranian Medes settled there. Subsequently, the province became part of the Achaemenid Empire, and after the liberation of Iran from Macedon by the forces of Arshakids — part of the Parthian kingdom. Pahan was the center of a vast province ruled by Arshakid rulers. Under the Sassanids, Spahan was ruled by members of seven noble Iranian families who held high court posts. Moreover, during this period, Spahan was an important military center with powerful defensive structures. Many Jews and Christians lived in the vicinity of the city. After the final defeat of Iran, the Arabs captured the city. Esfahan, like other cities of Iran, fell under the rule of the Arabs until the Abbasid era. X under the Buids, Isfahan regains its significance. Under the Sultan Melik Shah, Isfahan became the capital of the Seljuk state. In XI, the famous Persian philosopher Avicenna lived and taught in Isfahan.
{king_isfahan_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to income from taxes. \n+5% to income from trade.
¬----------------------
{iking_isfahan}Ruler of Isfahan
{iking_isfahan_desc}Named Ruler of Isfahan.\n\nDescription:\nThe ancient Isfahan was part of the Elamite empire. Under the name of Aspandan, it became one of the main cities of the Medes when the Iranian Medes settled there. Subsequently, the province became part of the Achaemenid Empire, and after the liberation of Iran from Macedonia by the forces of Arshakids — part of the Parthian kingdom. Spahan was the center of a vast province ruled by Arshakid rulers. Under the Sassanids, Spahan was ruled by members of seven noble Iranian families who held high court positions In addition, during this period, Spahan was an important military center with powerful defensive structures. Many Jews and Christians lived in the vicinity of the city. After the final defeat of Iran, the city was captured by Arabs. Esfahan, like other cities of Iran, fell under the rule of the Arabs until the Abbasid era. .In X under the Buids, Isfahan regains its significance. Under the Sultan Melik Shah, Isfahan became the capital of the Seljuk state. In XI in Isfahan the famous Persian philosopher Avicenna lived and taught.
{iking_isfahan_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to income from taxes. \n+5% to income from trade.

{oking_isfahan}Isfahan strategist
{oking_isfahan_desc}Named Isfahan’s Strategist.\n\nDescription:\nThe ancient Isfahan was part of the Elamite empire. Under the name Aspandana, it became one of the main cities of the Medes when the Iranian Medes settled there. Subsequently, the province became part of the Achaemenid Empire, and after the liberation of Iran from Macedon by the forces of Arshakids — part of the Parthian kingdom. Spahan was the center of a vast province ruled by Arshakid rulers. Under the Sassanids, Spahan was ruled by members of seven noble Iranian families who held high court posts. In addition, during this period, Spahan was an important military center with powerful defensive structures. Many Jews and Christians lived in the vicinity of the city. After the final defeat of Iran, the Arabs captured the city. Esfahan, like other cities of Iran, fell under the rule of the Arabs until the Abbasid era. X under the Buids, Isfahan regains its significance. Under the Sultan Melik Shah, Isfahan became the capital of the Seljuk state. In XI, the famous Persian philosopher Avicenna lived and taught in Isfahan.
{oking_isfahan_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to income from taxes. \n+5% to income from trade.
¬------------------------------------------------- -----------------
{king_ray}Prince of Ray
{king_ray_desc}Named the Prince of Ray.\n\nDescription:\nRay is one of the oldest cities in Iran. The city was one of the centers of the Medes, and then the states of the Achaemenids, Seleucids and Sassanids, and was called Arsakia, which translates as white Saki - a Scythian tribe. Seleucus Nikator restored the city after the earthquake that happened during his reign and gave the city the name of Europe. During the Parthian wars, it was almost completely devastated and bloodless, later Arshak restored it again. In 1227, Jalal ad-Din defeated a Mongol detachment near Ray. Rei retained its significance in Muslim times.
{king_ray_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenue. \n+1 to piety.
¬----------------------

The city was one of the centers of the Medes, and then the states of the Achaemenids, Seleucids and Sassanids, and was called Arsakia, which translates as white Saki - a Scythian tribe. Seleucus Nikator restored the city after the earthquake that happened during his reign and gave the city the name of Europe. During the Parthian wars, it was almost completely devastated and bloodless, later Arshak restored it again. In 1227, Jalal ad-Din defeated a Mongol detachment near Ray. Rei retained its significance in Muslim times.
{iking_ray_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenue. \n+1 to piety.

{king_shiraz}Prince of Shiraz
{king_shiraz_desc}Named Prince Shiraz.\n\nDescription:\nShiraz, a stronghold of regional Arab power in Fars, is growing as an administrative center. In 869 The Turkic Saffarid dynasty comes to power. However, the Arab and Turkic populations are getting used to the Persian culture. In 870 Jami Mosque is under construction. Shiraz becomes the capital of the Buyid dynasty and becomes a major cultural center of the East. The Buyids defeat the Caliphs of Baghdad and Shiraz acquires international significance. Literature, science, arts are developing. Religious minorities also thrive. In 950 an underground canal was built from the mountains, which provided the city with clean water. In 1000 The Seljuks attack Shiraz, they are supported by the supporters of the remaining caliphate in the war against the Buyids. The war continues for 50 years, civil strife breaks out between the Buyids and the city is destroyed. In 1062 The Seljuks occupied Shiraz, but the conquerors adopted Persian culture during the struggle and began to patronize and maintain traditions and built a great empire. In 1090, as a result of a split in the Seljuk army, the Turks from the Salgurid family managed to seize power in Shiraz, they strengthened themselves in Shiraz and relied on Persian traditions. 1105 - The wall around the city with eight gates was restored. In 1110 Hanafis take power in the region. Nevertheless, tolerance flourishes in Shiraz, religions feel free. Turks and Caucasians settled in Shiraz. Temples are built, law and order flourishes.
{king_shiraz_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% tax income.
¬----------------------

The war continues for 50 years, civil strife breaks out between the Buyids and the city is destroyed. {king_yazd}Prince of Yazd
{king_yazd_desc}Named Prince of Yazd.\n\nDescription:\nMemories of the city appeared as far back as 3000 BC. It was designated as the city of Isatis in Media. Here the rules of the Achaemenid dynasty. Yazd, far from the historical capitals, was able to avoid brutal destruction. The city has many architectural monuments and cultural relics of ancient times. It was a thriving city with developed silk production. The Mausoleum of Dovazdeh-Imam (11th century) was built. During the invasion of Genghis Khan, artists, scientists and poets were able to escape from persecution here.
{king_yazd_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues. \n+5% to public order in the role of governor. \n+1 to popularity.

{king_damghan}Prince of Damgan
{king_damghan_desc}Named the Prince of Damgan.\n\nDescription:\nThe name Damgan is derived from “Deh” and “Mogan.” “Deh” means a village, and “Mogan” means a magi. This name was given by Zoroastrians, among whom were people such as King Cyrus and Darius of ancient Persia. It was founded by Damgan Khushang, the great-grandson of Keymars and the founder of the legendary Pishdadida dynasty. Until the 1st century AD, Damgan was the capital of this great province. During the invasion Alexander the Great in Iran, the Greeks called him Hecatompylos (“one hundred gates”). Damgan was half destroyed during the earthquake in 856. Damgan was an important city in the Middle Ages and was the capital of the province of Kumis (Kumes). Here, the Tari Khan mosque was built. Damgan shines like a bezel in the desert egione.S its rich cultural heritage and the true origin of the ancient civilization of Damghan is undeniable, and each relic in the city can confirm their true past, wiping the dust of oblivion with this shiny rims.
{king_damghan_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues. \n+1 to command. \n+1 General's health. 
¬----------------------

{iking_damghan_desc}Named Lord of the Damgan.\n\nDescription:\nThe name Damgan is derived from “Deh” and “Mogan.” “Deh” means the village, and “Mogan” means the Magi. This name was given by Zoroastrians, among whom were people such as King Cyrus and Darius of ancient Persia. It was founded by Damgan Khushang, the great-grandson of Keymars and the founder of the legendary Pishdadida dynasty. Until the 1st century AD, Damgan was the capital of this great province. Damgan shines like a bezel in the desert egione.S its rich cultural heritage and the true origin of the ancient civilization of Damghan is undeniable, and each relic in the city can confirm their true past, wiping the dust of oblivion with this shiny rims.

This name was given by Zoroastrians, among whom were people such as King Cyrus and Darius of ancient Persia. {king_gorgan}Prince of Gorgan
{king_gorgan_desc}Named the Prince of Gorgan.\n\nDescription:\nDuring the reign of Cyrus the Great in 559-530 BC, Gorgan was included in the Persian Empire. Under Darius I was part of the satrapy of Hyrcania. Alexander of Macedon conquered Hyrcania, but was wounded in battle, after which his vision deteriorated. After the fall of the Empire, Alexander Gorgan became a part of the Seleucid Empire. In III BC, the north-eastern nomads belonging to the Parn tribe invaded Parthia and Hyrcania. If the first was lost forever, then the second was temporarily won by the Seleucid ruler Ant Joach III the Great in 209 BCE For the Parthians, the new name for the guys, Hyrcania was an important part of the Empire, located between the territory of Parthia and their native steppe lands. It was there that their summer residence was located and it was they who built the Great Gorgan wall. In IX merchants of Rusichi traveled to the Caspian countries, they reached Gorgan, from where they sometimes sent their goods to camel to Baghdad. In 935-1090, emirs from the Persian Ziyarid dynasty ruled in Gorgan. The most supreme power over Gorgan in the X century belonged to Sam nidam then Bouida.
{king_gorgan_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues. \n+1 to agriculture (increases the city’s income from agriculture).
¬----------------------
{iking_gorgan}Lord of the Gorgan
{iking_gorgan_desc}Named the Ruler of Gorgan.\n\nDescription:\nDuring the reign of Cyrus the Great in 559-530 BC, Gorgan was included in the Persian Empire. Under Daria I was part of the satrapy of Hyrcania. Alexander of Macedon conquered Hyrcania, but was wounded in battle, after which his vision deteriorated. After the fall of the Empire, Alexander Gorgan became a part of the Seleucid Empire. In III BC, the north-eastern nomads belonging to the Parn tribe invaded Parthia and Hyrcania. If the first was lost forever, then the second managed to temporarily conquer the Seleucid rule Liu Antiochus III the Great in 209 BC For the Parthians, the new name for the Parnas, Hyrcania was an important part of the Empire, located between the territory of Parthia and their native steppe lands. It was there that their summer residence was located and it was they who built the Great Gorgan wall. In IX merchants of Rusichi, traveling to the Caspian littoral countries, reached Gorgan, from where they sometimes sent their goods on camels to Baghdad. In 935-1090, emirs from the Persian Ziyarid dynasty ruled in Gorgan. The most supreme power over Gorgan in the X century belonged to of the Samanids, the Bouida.
{iking_gorgan_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues. \n+1 to agriculture (increases the city’s income from agriculture).
¬----------------------
{oking_gorgan}Gorgan's strategist
{oking_gorgan_desc}Named the Strategist of Gorgan.\n\nDescription:\nDuring the reign of Cyrus the Great in 559-530 BC, Gorgan was included in the Persian Empire. During Darius I was part of the satrapy of Hyrcania. Alexander of Macedon conquered Hyrcania, but was wounded in battle, after which his vision deteriorated. After the fall of the Empire, Alexander Gorgan became a part of the Seleucid Empire. In III BC, the north-eastern nomads belonging to the Parn tribe invaded Parthia and Hyrcania. If the first was lost forever, then the second was temporarily won by the Seleucid ruler Antiochus III the Great in 209 BC For the Parthians, the new name for the guys, Hyrcania was an important part of the Empire, located between the territory of Parthia and their native steppe lands. It was there that their summer residence was located and it was they who built the Great Gorgan wall. In IX merchants of Rusichi, traveling to the Caspian littoral countries, reached Gorgan, from where they sometimes sent their goods on camels to Baghdad. In 935-1090, emirs from the Persian Ziyarid dynasty ruled in Gorgan. The most supreme power over Gorgan in the X century belonged to Samanids, then the Buyids.
{oking_gorgan_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues. \n+1 to agriculture (increases the city’s income from agriculture).
¬------------------------------------------------- -----------------
{king_mashhad}Prince of Mashhad
{king_mashhad_desc}Named Prince Mashhad.\n\nDescription:\n Throughout its history, Mashhad has been an important political, cultural and religious center. In 818, in the village of Sanabad, near Tusa, the 8th Shiite imam Ali bin Musa ar-Reed (Persian - Imam Reza), son-in-law of caliph al-Mamun, suddenly died. According to legend, he was poisoned by the son of the most popular of the Baghdad caliphs Harun ar-Rashid. The place of martyrdom (in Arabic - Mashhad) Reza among Muslims is very revered, especially among Shiites. The Mausoleum of Imam Reza was later built on the site of the tomb. Later, the village of Sinabad, during the destruction of the city of Tus, began to grow and develop, turning into the city of Mashhad. For the first time the word "Mashhad" as the name of the city was used in the X century by the geographer al-Mukaddasi. Mashhad is a holy Shia city. It houses the Mausoleum of Imam Reza.
{king_mashhad_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to income from taxes. \n+5% to income from trade.
¬----------------------

{king_geok-tepe_desc}Named the Prince of Keni-Kale.\n \nDescription: Keni-Kale is a city on the trade route to India and China. Many merchants stop here, taxes from which replenish the treasury of the ruler.

{king_khiva}Prince of Khiva
{king_khiva_desc}Named the Prince of Khiva.\n\nDescription:\nKhiva was founded more than 2500 years ago. In ancient times, the city was known as Heyvak. According to the tradition of Khiva, it was founded by one of the prophets. In its history, the city survived the Achaemenid conquest and the heyday when the borders of ancient Khorezm extended to Colchis. From 305-995 Khorezm, which included Khiva, was ruled by the Afrigid dynasty. In 712, Khiva was captured by the Arabs. After that, Khiva became part of the Muslim world. Despite the dependence on the Arabs, the Afigids retained power until the end of X. In 995-1017 The odes of Khorezm were ruled by the Mamunid dynasty. In the 11th century, Khiva became dependent on the Seljukids. In 1097 the Anushteginids dynasty came to power. In the 9th-12th centuries, besides many Islamic educational institutions, large centers of science successfully operated in Khorezm: astronomy, mathematics, medicine, chemistry etc. The “House of Wisdom", actually the academy of sciences created by the then ruler Al-Mamun in Baghdad, was led by Muhammad al-Khwarizmi, a native of Khorezm. Already in IX his fundamental works on mathematics, geography, and geodesy were known in Europe Huge science Noah left the legacy of Al-Biruni, Najmuddin Kubra and other scientists and theologians whose names are also associated with Khorezm.
{king_khiva_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues. \n+5% to legality. \n-5% to corruption.
¬----------------------

Despite the dependence on the Arabs, the Afigids retained power until the end of X. AT In the years 995-1017 Khorezm was ruled by the Mamunid dynasty. In the IX – XII centuries, besides many Islamic educational institutions, large centers of science successfully operated in Khorezm: astronomy, mathematics, medicine , chemistry, etc. The “House of Wisdom”, actually the academy of sciences created by the then ruler Al-Mamun in Baghdad, was led by Muhammad-al-Khwarizmi, a native of Khorezm. {oking_khiva}Khiva strategist
{oking_khiva_desc}Named Khiva's Strategist.\n\nDescription:\nKhiva was founded more than 2500 years ago. In ancient times, the city was known as Heyvak. According to legend, Khiva was founded by one of the prophets. In its history, the city survived the Achaemenid conquest and the heyday when the borders of ancient Khorezm extended to Colchis. From 305-995 Khorezm, which included Khiva, was ruled by the Afrigid dynasty. In 712, Khiva was captured by the Arabs. After that, Khiva became part of the Muslim world. Despite the dependence on the Arabs, the Afigids retained power until the end of X. In 995 -1017 years Khorezm was ruled by the Mamunid dynasty. In the 11th century, Khiva was dependent on the Seljukids. In 1097 the Anushteginids dynasty came to power. In the 9th-12th centuries, besides many Islamic educational institutions, large centers of science successfully operated in Khorezm: astronomy, mathematics, medicine, chemistry, etc. The “House of Wisdom", actually the academy of sciences created by the then ruler Al-Mamun in Baghdad, was led by Muhammad al-Khwarizmi, a native of Khorezm. Already in IX, his fundamental works on mathematics, geography, and geodesy were known in Europe. Huge Al-Biruni, Najm ad-din Kubra and other scholars and theologians, whose names are also associated with Khorezm, left a scientific legacy.

{king_urgench}Prince of Urgench
{king_urgench_desc}Named the Prince of Urgench.\n\nDescription:\nOne of the largest cities of the Great Silk Road. It is mentioned in the holy book of the Zoroastrians Avesta under the name "Urva." In the Kangyu period, the city is known as "Hangird", "Hajird." In 305 -995 years, Urgench as part of the state led by the Afrigid dynasty. After the Arab expansion, it was called Gurganj. In X on the right bank of the Amu Darya, the Afigids ruled under the Samanids. This was the origin of the North Khorezm state Urgench emirate, the capital of which this city was. It was second only to Bukhara in size. In 995, the emir Mamun ibn Muhammad defeated South Khorezm, killing the last Afrigide Abu Abdullah Muhammad. Having united the whole region under his authority, he began to rule from the south-Khorezm capital Kyatazm. .With the rise of the new Khorezm dynasty of Anushteginids, descended from the Turkmen tribe of Bekdili (Begdili), the city returns its capital status and under Alauddin Muhammad turns out to be the center of a huge empire in Central Asia and the Middle East .XII and early XIII were the heyday of Urgench is superior in terms of population and fame all the cities of Central Asia, in addition to Bukhara. He gives shelter to Avicenna, Al-Biruni, Ibn Battut and other famous thinkers of that time.
{king_urgench_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues. \n+5% to public order in the role of governor. \n+1 to popularity.\n+2 to cruelty.
¬----------------------
{iking_urgench}Lord of Urgench
{iking_urgench_desc}Named Lord of Urgench.\n\nDescription:\nOne of the largest cities of the Great Silk Road. It is mentioned in the holy book of the Zoroastrians Avesta under the name “Urva.” In the Kangyu period, the city is known as “Hangird”, “Hajird.” In 305 -995 years Urgench as part of a state led by the Afrigid dynasty. After the Arab expansion, it is called Gurganj. In X on the right bank of the Amu Darya, the Afigids ruled under the Samanids. This was the origin of the North Khorezm state Urgench emirate, the capital of which was In the Samanid Empire, it was second only to Bukhara in size. In 995, the emir Mamun Ibn Muhammad defeated South Khorezm, killing the last Afrigide Abu Abdullah Muhammad. By uniting the whole region under his authority, he began to rule from the south Khorezm capital of 7 Khat. conquered by Mahmud Ghaznevi. With the rise of the new Khorezm dynasty of Anushteginids, descended from the Turkmen tribe of Bekdili (Begdili), the city returns its capital status and under Alauddin Muhammad turns out to be the center of a huge empire in Central Asia and Middle East Ostok. XII and the beginning of XIII were the heyday of Urgench, surpassing all the cities of Central Asia in population and fame, except Bukhara. He gives shelter to Avicenna, Al-Biruni, Ibn Battut and other famous thinkers of that time.
{iking_urgench_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues. \n+5% to public order in the role of governor. \n+1 to popularity.\n+2 to cruelty.

{oking_urgench}Urgench strategist
{oking_urgench_desc}It is called the Strategist of Urgench.\n\nDescription:\nOne of the largest cities of the Great Silk Road. It is mentioned in the holy book of the Zoroastrians Avesta under the name "Urva." In the Kangyu period, the city is known as "Hangird", "Hajird." In 305 -995 years, Urgench as part of the state led by the Afrigid dynasty. After the Arab expansion, it is called Gurganj. In X on the right bank of the Amu Darya, the Afigids ruled under the Samanids. This was the origin of the North Khorezm state Urgench emirate, the capital of which was this mountain In the Samanid Empire, it was second only to Bukhara in size. In 995, the emir Mamun ibn-Muhammad defeated South Khorezm, killing the last Afrigide Abu-Abdallah Muhammad. By uniting the whole region under his authority, he began to rule from the south-Khorezm capital of Khat. conquered by Mahmud Ghaznevi. With the rise of the new Khorezm dynasty of Anushteginids, descended from the Turkmen tribe of Bekdili (Begdili), the city regains its capital status and under Alauddin Muhammad turns out to be the center of a huge empire in Central Asia and Middle East current. XII and the beginning of XIII were the heyday of Urgench, surpassing all the cities of Central Asia in terms of population and fame, except Bukhara. He gives shelter to Avicenna, Al-Biruni, Ibn Battut and other famous thinkers of that time.

{dearmad_jerusalem}Ruler of Jerusalem
{dearmad_jerusalem_desc}Named Ruler of Jerusalem(Judea).\n\nDescription:\nThe kingdom was created after the capture of Jerusalem by the crusaders in 1099. Gottfried of Bouillon, one of the leaders of the First Crusade, was elected the first king. He refused to accept this title, not wanting to wear the royal crown where the Savior wore a crown of thorns; instead, he accepted the title (“Protector of the Holy Sepulcher.”) Godfried died the following year, his brother and heir Baldwin I was not so pious and immediately accepted the title “King of Jerusalem.” Baldwin successfully expanded the kingdom, capturing the port cities of Acre, Sidon and Beirut, and also asserting its dominion over the crusader states in the North - the county of Edessa, the Principality of Antioch and the county of Tripoli. During it, the number of Latins who came with the Rear Guard Crusade increased, and also Latin appeared Patriarch. Italian city-states (Venice, Pisa and Genoa) began to play an important role in the kingdom. Around 1040 in Jerusalem, the Order of the Johannites (Hospitallers) founded a hospital for pilgrims. Another monastic order is the Templar. -obosnovalsya in the temple that has been converted from the Al-Aksa.Novoe generation born and raised in the Levant, considered the Holy Land as their homeland and a negative attitude to the newly coming krestonostsam.Takzhe they were often more like the Syrians, and not on the franc.
{dearmad_jerusalem_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus:\n+15% to tax revenues.\n+2 to defensive command during an assault.\n+2 to piety.\n-2 loyalty. 
¬----------------------
{idearmad_jerusalem}Ruler of Jerusalem
{idearmad_jerusalem_desc}Named Ruler of Jerusalem(Judea).\n\nDescription:\nThe kingdom was created after the capture of Jerusalem by the crusaders in 1099. Gottfried of Bouillon, one of the leaders of the First Crusade, was elected the first king. He refused to accept this title, not wanting to wear the royal crown where the Savior wore a crown of thorns; instead, he accepted the title (“Protector of the Holy Sepulcher.”) Godfried died the following year, his brother and heir Baldwin I was not so pious, and immediately adopted the title “King of Jerusalem.” Baldwin successfully expanded the kingdom, capturing the port cities of Acre, Sidon and Beirut, and also asserting its dominion over the crusader states in the North - the county of Edessa, the Principality of Antioch and the county of Tripoli. During it, the number of Latins who came with the Rear Guard Crusade increased, and also Latin appeared Patriarch. Italian city-states (Venice, Pisa and Genoa) began to play an important role in the kingdom. Around 1040 in Jerusalem, the Order of the Johannites (Hospitallers) founded a hospital for pilgrims. Another monastic order is the Templar. You — settled in a temple converted from the Al-Aqsa Mosque. The new generation, born and raised in the Levant, considered the Holy Land their homeland and negatively related to newcomers to the crusaders. They also often looked more like Syrians rather than Franks.
{idearmad_jerusalem_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus:\n+15% to tax revenues.\n+2 to defensive command during an assault.\n+2 to piety.\n-2 loyalty. 
¬----------------------
{odearmad_jerusalem}Strategist of Jerusalem
{odearmad_jerusalem_desc}Named Strategist of Jerusalem and ruler of Judea.\n\nDescription:\nThe kingdom was created after the capture of Jerusalem by the crusaders in 1099. Gottfried of Bouillon, one of the leaders of the First Crusade, was elected the first king. He refused to accept this title, not wanting to wear the royal crown where the Savior wore a crown of thorns; instead, he accepted the title (“Protector of the Holy Sepulcher.”) Godfried died the following year, his brother and heir Baldwin I was not so pious and immediately accepted the title “King of Jerusalem.” Baldwin successfully iril kingdom, capturing the port cities of Acre, Sidon and Beirut, and also asserting his dominion over the crusader states in the North - the county of Edessa, the Principality of Antioch and the county of Tripoli. During it, the number of Latins who came with the Rear Guard Crusade increased, and also Latin appeared patriarch. Italian city-states (Venice, Pisa and Genoa) began to play an important role in the kingdom. About 1040 in Jerusalem, the Order of the Johannites (Hospitallers) founded a hospital for pilgrims. Another monastic order - the Temple Yer — settled in a temple converted from the Al-Aqsa Mosque. The new generation, born and raised in the Levant, considered the Holy Land their homeland and negatively related to the newly coming crusaders. They also often looked more like the Syrians rather than the Franks.
{odearmad_jerusalem_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus:\n+15% to tax revenues.\n+2 to defensive command during an assault.\n+2 to piety.\n-2 loyalty.

{dearmad_antioch}Prince of Antioch
{dearmad_antioch_desc}Named Prince of Antioch and ruler of Syria.\n\nDescription:\nThe second of the Christian states founded by the crusaders during the 1st Crusade. The state was formed in 1098 after the conquest of Antioch by Boemund I of Tarenta. At the beginning of the XII century, the principality was in vassal dependence on Byzantium, and since 1119 - on the Kingdom of Jerusalem. The principality included the territory located between the Mediterranean coast of modern Syria and the Euphrates River, in the first half of the XII century it also included Plain Cilicia. The prince of Antioch was overlord of the county of Edessa (until 1144), and from 1163 - the county of Tripoli, with whom in 1207 Antioch was united by Boemund IV.
{dearmad_antioch_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues. \n+1 to the morale of all troops on the battlefield. \n-1 from fidelity. \n+1 to piety.

{dearmad_nicosia}Ruler of Cyprus
{dearmad_nicosia_desc}Named ruler of Cyprus(Nicosia).\n\nDescription:\nIn 1184, in Cyprus, which until then was part of the Byzantine Empire, the cousin of Emperor Andronik Komnin, Isaac, seized power. In 1191, Cyprus was conquered by Richard I the Lionheart, king of England. Richard sold Cyprus to the Templar Order for 100,000 Besant, then, after the Cypriots rebelled against the Templar rule, in 1192 he bought the island back and resold the former King of Jerusalem Guy de Lusignan, who became the first lord of Cyprus as a result. Guy (Guido), who died in 1194, was succeeded by his older brother Amory (Amalrich), who in 1195 recognized the suzerainty of the Holy Roman Empire and received the title of King of Cyprus from Emperor Henry VI. The ceremonial coronation of the first king of Cyprus Amory I was held on September 22, 1197 in Nicosia.
{dearmad_nicosia_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+10% to tax revenues.\n-1 to loyalty
¬----------------------
{idearmad_nicosia}Ruler of Cyprus
{idearmad_nicosia_desc}Named ruler of Cyprus(Nicosia).\n\nDescription:\nIn 1184, in Cyprus, which until then was part of the Byzantine Empire, the cousin of the emperor Andronicus Komnin - Isaac seized power. In 1191, Cyprus was conquered by Richard I the Lionheart, king of England. Richard sold Cyprus to the Templar Order for 100,000 Besant, then, after the Cypriots rebelled against the Templar rule, in 1192 he bought the island back and resold the former King of Jerusalem Guy de Lusignan, who became the first lord of Cyprus as a result. Guy (Guido), who died in 1194, was succeeded by his older brother Amory (Amalrich), who in 1195 recognized the suzerainty of the Holy Roman Empire and received the title of King of Cyprus from Emperor Henry VI. The ceremonial coronation of the first king of Cyprus Amory I was held on September 22, 1197 in Nicosia.

{odearmad_nicosia}Cyprus Strategist
{odearmad_nicosia_desc}Named the Strategist of Cyprus and the ruler of Nicosia.\n\nDescription:\nIn 1042, after the death of Emperor Michael V, the Cypriot governor Theophilos Eroticos tried to take advantage of the chaos and rebelled, but the emperor Constantine IX Monomakh, having established himself on the throne, ambassador and returned the island to the control of the empire. In 1092 another uprising followed, but it was also quickly suppressed. In 1184, Isaac Komnin managed to establish himself as the ruler of Cyprus, repelled the attack of the Byzantine fleet, and appointed an independent patriarch of Cyprus, who crowned him as emperor. In 1191, the bride and sister of King of England Richard I the Lionhearted shipwrecked near Cyprus, and were captured by Isaac. In response, Richard captured Cyprus during the Third Crusade en route to the Kingdom of Jerusalem.
{odearmad_nicosia_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+10% tax income.\n-1 to loyalty
¬------------------------------------------------- -----------------
{dearmad_adana}Prince of Cilician Armenia
{dearmad_adana_desc}Named Prince of Cilician Armenia and ruler of Adana.\n\nDescription:\nThe invasion of the Seljuks led to the mass resettlement of Armenians in Cilicia. The Byzantine Empire was unable to build its support among the population of the conquered Armenian lands. Within the borders of the empire, a number of semi-independent Armenian princes appeared located from Syria to Transcaucasia. The Armenians preserved their culture, church and statehood. In 1070, under the command of the future applicant for the crown of Nicephorus Melissen and the father of the future emperor Alexei Manuel Komnin It was defeated by the Seljuks near Sevastia. Without recognizing the rule of Mikhail, Varazhnuni broke with Byzantium, by 1071 he actually became the ruler of an independent Armenian state, strengthened by the migration of Armenians from the territories subjected to the Seljuk invasion. Prince Ruben laid the foundation for the Armenian dynasty and princedom. Syn Ruben Kostandand power to the East. The main enemy of the Armenians in Asia Minor and the Middle East were the Seljuks, the Armenian population, when the Crusaders appeared, considered them as allies. In 1100, Kos died Andino I, his principality was divided into two portions of his sons Levon and Torosa.Kogda Rubenids were ready to unite, Flat Cilicia became the object of a struggle between Byzantium and Antioch, the war between them went on with varying success.
{dearmad_adana_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus:\n+5% tax income.\n+5% trade income.\n+1 general health.\n+10% vision radius (increases visibility).

The Byzantine Empire was unable to build its support among the population of the conquered Armenian lands. A number of semi-independent Armenian principalities arose within the borders of the empire. located from Syria to Transcaucasia. The Armenians preserved their culture, church and statehood. In 1070, under the command of the future applicant for the crown of Nicephorus Melissen and the father of the future emperor Alexei Manuel Komnin and, it was defeated by the Seljuks near Sevastia. Without recognizing the rule of Mikhail, Varazhnuni broke with Byzantium, by 1071 actually became the ruler of an independent Armenian state, strengthened by the migration of Armenians from the territories subjected to the Seljuk invasion. Prince Ruben laid the foundation for the Armenian dynasty and princedom. Sin Rubenand expanded power to the East. The main enemy of the Armenians in Asia Minor and the Middle East were the Seljuks, the Armenian population, when the Crusaders appeared, considered them as allies. In 1100, Kos died tandinus I, his principality was divided into two destinies by his sons Levon and Toros. When the Rubenids were ready for unification, the Plain Cilicia became the object of the struggle between Byzantium and Antioch, the war between which was with varying success.

The main enemy of the Armenians in Asia Minor and the Middle East were the Seljuks, the Armenian population, when the Crusaders appeared, considered them as allies. In 1100 he died Kostandin I, his principality split into two destinies for his sons Levon and Toros. {dearmad_edessa}Count of Edessa
{dearmad_edessa_desc}Named Count of Edessa and ruler of the Euphrates.\n \nDescription:\nAfter the capture of Nicaea, Baldwin of Boulogne separated from the crusader army, which was heading south to Antioch and Jerusalem, and proceeded to Cilicia and from there went east to Edessa. Before the Crusaders appeared in the Euphrates interfluve Balduin, there was an Armenian principality there, the basis of the economy of which was transit trade. The instability of the foreign policy situation and the lack of a strong army forced the Ishkhans to look for a powerful patron on the side. The Armenian population initially considered the participants in the crusade, if not as liberators, then as allies capable of resisting the Seljuks. Prince Thoros of Edessa, invites and adopts Baldwin of Flanders, thereby agreeing to a division of power and income. A coup takes place. After the coup, the Armenian state was transformed into a Franco-Armenian one. Thus, the first state of the crusaders, the County of Edessa, appeared. In 1100, after the death of his brother, Godfrey yes Bouillon, Baldwin inherited the throne of Jerusalem, and Edessa passed to his cousin, Baldwin de Burke. Joscelin de Courtenay joined him. In 1119, the title of Count of Edessa was given to Joscelin de Courtenay.
{dearmad_edessa_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus:\n+10% to tax revenue.\n+2 to piety.

In 1119, the title of Count of Edessa was given to Joscelin de Courtenay.
{odearmad_edessa_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus:\n+10% to tax revenue.\n+2 to piety.
¬------------------------------------------------- -----------------
{king_tortosa}Count of Tripoli
{king_tortosa_desc}Named Count of Tripoli and ruler of Lebanon.\n\nDescription:\nLast of the four Christian Crusader states created after the First Crusade in the Levant. The county was founded by Count Toulouse Raimund IV, who sought to gain his own possession in the Holy Land. The war for this territory between the crusaders and the Arab emirs began in 1101. In 1102, Raimund IV conquered Tortosa, in 1104 Byblos, in 1102-1103 the crusaders began the siege of Tripoli. On 12 July 1109, the son of Raimund IV Bertrand, with the support of Tripoli managed to take and create their own state. The county reached its maximum size by 1132. To ensure their supremacy, the crusaders built many castles (most famous for the ruins of Krak and Mont Peleren). The military forces were represented by the orders of the “Johannites” and “Templars” who were granted land allotments in the county. In the county economy, a significant role was played by Genoese merchants, who enjoyed wide privileges in all cities, and in 1109 taught at the full disposal of the Bible. Nominally the county was in vassal subordination to the Kingdom of Jerusalem, but in fact was independent of it. A closer relationship existed between the county and the Principality of Antioch.
{king_tortosa_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues. \n+1 to fidelity. \n+1 to piety.
¬----------------------

{dearmad_acre}Earl of Acre \n (Saint-Jean-d'Acre)
{dearmad_acre_desc}Named Earl of Saint-Jean-d'Acre and ruler of Palestine.\n\nDescription:\nAcko brought real fame to the era of the Crusades. In 1104, after the First Crusade, the city was conquered by Baldwin I. Prior to that, the city belonged to the Arabs. They also built a fortress here, but Balduin began its minor rebuilding and strengthening. In 1187, Saladin took the city almost without a fight, but already in 1191 during the 3rd crusade after a two-year siege, Acre was recaptured by the crusader troops under the command of the French king Philip Augustus and the English king Richard the Lionheart. The city became the capital of the Kingdom of Jerusalem of the crusaders in Palestine and was okru The city received a new name — Saint-Jean-d'Acre. The military chivalric orders of the Hospitallers, Templars, and later the Teutonic Order found their own quarters in Acre. They built residential houses, warehouses, hospitals, churches and administrative buildings. Over 40 churches and 23 monasteries have grown in different parts of the city.
{dearmad_acre_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus:\n+5% tax income.\n+5% trade income.\n+1 command.\n+1 to piety.\n-1 loyalty

{idearmad_acre}Emir of Acre
{idearmad_acre_desc}Named Emir Acre and ruler of Palestine.\n\nDescription:\nAcko brought real fame to the era of the Crusades. In 1104, after the First Crusade, the city was conquered by Baldwin I. Prior to that, the city belonged to the Arabs. They also built a fortress here, but Balduin began its minor rebuilding and strengthening. In 1187, Saladin took the city almost without a fight, but already in 1191. During the 3rd Crusade, after a two-year siege, Acre was recaptured by the crusader forces under the command of the French King Philip Augustus and the English King Richard the Lionheart. The city became the capital of the Kingdom of Jerusalem of the Crusaders in Palestine and was surrounded by powerful defensive structures. The city received a new name — Saint-Jean-d'Acre. The military chivalric orders of the Hospitallers, Templars, and later the Teutonic Order found their own quarters in Acre. They built houses, warehouses, hospitals, churches and administrative buildings. more than 40 churches and 23 monasteries grew up in different parts of the city.

{dearmad_aleppo}Prince of Aleppo
{dearmad_aleppo_desc}Named Prince and Ruler of Aleppo.\n\nDescription:\nSassanids invaded Syria at the beginning of the 7th century. Soon, Arabs conquered Aleppo led by Khalid ibn Walida in 637. In 944, he became the residence of the independent Emirate of Al-Emirat Damid. and the city flourished, being the home of the great poet Al-Mutanabbi and philosopher Al-Farabi. The city was returned by the Byzantines in 962 and was part of the Byzantine Empire from 974-987. Aleppo and its emirate became a vassal state from 969 until the Byzantine-Selju wars. 1024-1080 with short breaks the city m operated Mirdasidov.Aleppo dynasty was twice besieged by the Crusaders in 1098 and 1124, but was not zavoovan.Zemletryasenie that occurred in 1138, destroyed the city and its okrestnosti.Haleb went to Saladin and then the Ayyubid dynasty in 1183.

{idearmad_aleppo}Emir Aleppo
{idearmad_aleppo_desc}Named Emir and ruler of Aleppo.\n\nDescription:\nSassanids invaded Syria at the beginning of the 7th century. Soon, Arabs conquered Aleppo under the leadership of Khalid ibn Walid in 637. In 944, it became the residence of the independent emirate, Prince Al-Hamid Hamid and the city flourished, being the home of the great poet Al-Mutanabbi and philosopher Al-Farabi. The city was returned by the Byzantines in 962 and was part of the Byzantine Empire from 974-987. Aleppo and its emirate became a vassal state from 969 until the Byzantine-Selju wars. 1024-1080 with short breaks the city It was ruled by the Mirdasid dynasty. Aleppo was twice besieged by the crusaders in 1098 and 1124, but was not conquered. An earthquake in 1138 destroyed the city and its environs. Aleppo passed to Saladin, and then the Ayyubid dynasty in 1183.
{idearmad_aleppo_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus:\n+5% tax revenue.\n+2 to defensive command during an assault.\n+20 siege engine building points.

{odearmad_aleppo}Strategist Aleppo
{odearmad_aleppo_desc}Named Strategist and Ruler of Aleppo.\n\nDescription:\nSassanids invaded Syria at the beginning of the 7th century. Soon, Arabs conquered Aleppo under the leadership of Khalid ibn Walid in 637. In 944, it became the residence of the independent emirate of Al-Emirat Damid and the city flourished, being the home of the great poet Al-Mutanabbi and philosopher Al-Farabi. The city was returned by the Byzantines in 962 and was part of the Byzantine Empire from 974-987. Aleppo and its emirate became a vassal state from 969 until the Byzantine-Selju wars. 1024-1080 with short interruptions the family was ruled by the Mirdasid dynasty. Aleppo was twice besieged by the crusaders in 1098 and 1124, but was not conquered. An earthquake that occurred in 1138 destroyed the city and its environs. Aleppo passed to Saladin, and then the Ayyubid dynasty in 1183.

{dearmad_damascus}Prince of Damascus
{dearmad_damascus_desc}Named Prince and ruler of Damascus.\n\nDescription:\nBetween 661 and 750, Damascus was the capital of the caliphate of the Umayyad dynasty, stretching from the Indus to the Pyrenees. Later, the city was ruled by Egyptian dynasties, and in 1076 became a part of the state of the Seljuk Turks. The Crusaders three times (in 1125, 1129 and 1148; the last time during the Second Crusade) tried unsuccessfully to capture Damascus. In 1154, Damascus was taken by the troops of Nur ad-din Mahmoud. After his death in 1174, Damascus came under Ayyubid rule. In 1260, Egyptian Mamluks seized power in Damascus. The period of their reign was marked by the flourishing of art and craft. Damascus steel and damask glass were exported to Europe.
{dearmad_damascus_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+10% to income from taxes. \n+10% to income from trade. \n+1 to piety. \n-1 from fidelity.
¬----------------------

{king_kerak}Prince of Karak
{king_kerak_desc}Named the Prince of El-Karak and the ruler of Jordan.\n\nDescription:\nIn the days of the Byzantine Empire, El-Karak was a diocese. The features of El-Karak of the Byzantine time can be from two mosaic maps located in the churches of Jordan: in the city of Madaba and in the city of Um Al-Rasas. On both maps El-Karak (on the map it is designated as Karakmoba) is depicted as a city surrounded by a defensive wall, although the fortress was built by the crusaders only in XII. In the southern part, the gates protected by two towers are clearly visible. parts located n a small church with a red roof. From the south to the north there are three rows of streets, the central of which leads to a large church, most likely a cathedral. The beginning of the formation of El-Karak as an impregnable fortress occurred in XII, when crusaders appeared in the Middle East The construction of the Crusader fortress began in 1142 under the direction of Payen de Milha. El-Karak had significant strategic advantages, located east of the Jordan River, since from his position it was possible to control the actions of nomadic shepherd in the Bedouin and follow the trade routes from Damascus and Cairo, as well as the routes of Hajj to Mecca.
{king_kerak_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues. \n+1 to the command during the defense of the city.\n+1 to personal safety (reduced chance of death from an assassin).

{dearmad_gaza}Prince of Gaza
{dearmad_gaza_desc}Named Prince of Gaza.\n\nDescription:\nArabs have repeatedly attempted to take possession of it; the Persians under Khozroi II succeeded for a while, and in 634 it finally fell into the hands of the Arabs. In the 7th-9th centuries, the city was part of the Arab Caliphate, in the 9th-11th centuries it was under the rule of the Egyptian dynasties of Tulunids, Ihshidids, Fatimids. At the end of the XI century it was captured by the crusaders, but after the victory of the Egyptian ruler Salah ad-din (1187), he returned to the Egyptian states. During this period, Gaza had the third largest Jewish population in Palestine after Jerusalem and Safed.
{dearmad_gaza_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus:\n+5% tax income.\n+1 loyalty\n+1 cavalry command.\n+2 personal safety (reduced chance of death from assassins).\n+1 general health.

{king_al_aqaba_desc}Named the Prince of Aqaba and the Khelim fortress.\n\nDescription:\nThe first settlement appeared on the site of the city about 6 thousand years ago. In ancient times, the city was called Elat, it was inhabited by the Edomite people, then the Nabataeans, it was a large commercial center. Then, under the name Aelana or Aila, he entered the Roman Empire. Later it belonged to the Byzantines, the crusaders, was part of the Arab caliphate. The fortress was originally built by the crusaders in the 12th century and was called Khelim.

{king_hajr}Prince of Taimy
{king_hajr_desc}Named Prince of Taimy.\n\nDescription:\nFirst time about the city (under the name "Tiamat") it becomes known from the Assyrian inscription of 8th century BC Assyrian king Tiglathpalasar III (745-727 BC. ) received a tribute from this city. The city was rich, because it lay at the crossroads of caravan routes to Yemen (Sabu). Jeremiah in the prophecies mentions him. The dynasty that ruled in the city raised its kind to the biblical character Kedar, the second son of Ismail. a whole tribe happened. The city is mentioned several times in the Old Testament. In 539 BC, the city was captured and settled in it by Nabonid (556-539 BC), the last king of the New Babylonian kingdom. Nabonid lived in Time for several years. It is not known when and under what circumstances Time became a Jewish city. that many residents once converted to Judaism. From Taima, a Jewish poet and warrior Samau'al Ibn Adiyah (beginning of the 6th century) was born. In 626-628, after the capture of Khaibar, the subordination of Fadak and Wadi al-Qur, Muhammad went to the city of Taimu .Time residents, apparently without a fight, agreed to pay tribute (jizya) and tax (haraj) .Thus, the Jews of Time We, by agreement with Muhammad, remained on their lands and owned their lands.

{king_mecca}Prince of Mecca
{king_mecca_desc}Named Prince of Mecca.\n\nDescription:\nKurayshites were experienced merchants and merchants. In VI they began to sell spices, because Wars at sea forced merchants to search for land routes. Byzantium controlled the Red Sea before, but piracy intensified during this period. During this period Mecca surpassed such trading cities as Petra and Palmyra in popularity. The Sasanian empire defended the city from the invasion of the Kingdom of Axum, led Christian leader Abraha. Mecca was an object of pilgrimage long before the advent of Islam, pagan pilgrims came to their temple and drank from Zamzam spring. Mecca was never a Muslim capital, but Muslim rights the firs took care of her well-being so that her citizens were satisfied with the living conditions. The threat of floods forced the caliphs to invite Christian engineers to build dams in the low blocks and dams to protect the territory around the Kaaba. The relocation of Muhammad to Medina reduced the importance of Mecca. Abdullah ibn al-Zubkayr during the Second Islamic Civil War. The city was besieged twice by the Umayyads, in 683 and 692. After that, for some time the city did not participate in political events, ruled by the Hashemites.
{king_mecca_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus:\n+10% to tax income.\n+5% to trade income.\n+1 to loyalty.\n-5% from lawfulness.\n+5% to corruption.
¬----------------------
{iking_mecca}Caliph of Mecca
{iking_mecca_desc}Named by Caliph Mecca.\n\nDescription:\nKuraysh were experienced merchants and merchants. In VI they began to sell spices, because Wars at sea forced merchants to search for land routes. Byzantium controlled the Red Sea before, but piracy intensified during this period. During this period Mecca surpassed such trading cities as Petra and Palmyra in popularity. The Sasanian empire defended the city from the invasion of the Kingdom of Axum, led Christian leader Abraha. Mecca was an object of pilgrimage long before the advent of Islam, pagan pilgrims came to their temple and drank from Zamzam spring. Mecca was never a Muslim capital, but Muslim rights the firs took care of her well-being so that her citizens were satisfied with the living conditions. The threat of floods forced the caliphs to invite Christian engineers to build dams in the low blocks and dams to protect the territory around the Kaaba. The relocation of Muhammad to Medina reduced the importance of Mecca. Abdullah ibn al-Zubkayr during the Second Islamic Civil War. The city was besieged twice by the Umayyads, in 683 and 692. After that, for some time the city did not participate in political events, ruled by the Hashemites.
{iking_mecca_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus:\n+10% to tax income.\n+5% to trade income.\n+1 to loyalty.\n-5% from lawfulness.\n+5% to corruption.\n+2 to piety.
¬----------------------
{oking_mecca}Mecca strategist
{oking_mecca_desc}Named Mecca's Strategist.\n\nDescription:\nQuraishites were experienced merchants and merchants. In VI they began to sell spices, because Wars at sea forced merchants to search for land routes. Byzantium controlled the Red Sea before, but piracy intensified during this period. During this period Mecca surpassed such trading cities as Petra and Palmyra in popularity. The Sasanian empire defended the city from the invasion of the Kingdom of Axum, led Christian leader Abraha. Mecca was an object of pilgrimage long before the advent of Islam, pagan pilgrims came to their temple and drank from Zamzam spring. Mecca was never a Muslim capital, but Muslim rights the firs took care of her well-being so that her citizens were satisfied with the living conditions. The threat of floods forced the caliphs to invite Christian engineers to build dams in the low blocks and dams to protect the territory around the Kaaba. The relocation of Muhammad to Medina reduced the importance of Mecca. Abdullah ibn al-Zubkayr during the Second Islamic Civil War. The city was besieged twice by the Umayyads, in 683 and 692. After that, for some time the city did not participate in political events, ruled by the Hashemites.

{dearmad_damietta}Prince of Dumyat
{dearmad_damietta_desc}Named Prince Dumyat.\n\nDescription:\nIn ancient Egypt, the city was known as Tamiat, but lost its significance in the Hellenistic period after the construction of Alexandria. Dumyat regains importance in the XII century and XIII century during the time of the Crusaders. In 1169, the fleet of the Kingdom of Jerusalem, with the support of Byzantium, besieged the port, but was defeated by Saladin. In preparation for the 5th Crusade in 1217, it was decided that Dumyat would be at the center of the offensive. Control of the Dumyat meant control of the Nile, the crusaders hoped that from there they could capture Egypt. From Egypt, they hoped to attack Palestine and return Jerusalem. The port was besieged and occupied by the Frisian crusaders in 1219 with the help of Francis of Assisi, but by 1221 the crusaders were defeated near Cairo and expelled from the country.
{dearmad_damietta_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to income from taxes. \n+5% to income from trade.

{dearmad_cairo}Prince of Cairo
{dearmad_cairo_desc}Named the Prince of Cairo.\n\nDescription:\n640 — Arab conquest of Egypt. 642 — founding by the Arab military commander Amir ibn al-Asa Fustat. 868 — The appointment of Ahmad ibn Tulun as governor of Egypt. During it, Egypt becomes virtually independent possession. 870 — the construction of the new capital of Egypt, al-Katai, near Fustat. 876-879 — construction of the mosque of Ibn Tulun. 969 — The Fatimids conquer Egypt. The founding of Cairo. 972 — the construction of al-Azhar, the creation of the oldest existing university in the world. 996-1021 — reign of the Fatimid caliph al-Hakim. Intensive monumental construction in Cairo. 1036-1094 — the reign of the Fatimid Caliph Mustansir. A severe economic, political and social crisis in the city and country. 1073-1094 — real power is in the hands of the vezir Badr al-Jamali. Stabilization of the economic, political and social situation in the city and country. July 1099.15 — the crusaders conquer Jerusalem and find themselves close to the Egyptian borders. 1176 — the construction of the Cairo citadel by Saladin. 1250 — the Mamluks (the slaves from whom military units are formed) manage to seize power in Cairo and Egypt. Aybek becomes the first Mamluk sultan. The new elite is recruited in the same way: in the Golden Horde, slaves continue to be procured to form the ruling Mamluk quascaste.
{dearmad_cairo_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+10% to tax revenues. \n+5% to public order in the role of governor. \n+1 to popularity. \n+1 to fighting spirit of soldiers on the battlefield.\n+1 to agriculture (increases the income of the city from agriculture)

{dearmad_alexandria}Prince of Alexandria
{dearmad_alexandria_desc}Named Prince of Alexandria.\n\nDescription:\nAlexandria was founded in 332 BC by Alexander the Great. Alexandria was deprived of a polis organization. Alexandria was built according to the plan of the architect Deinocrates. It was the capital of the Ptolemies and one of the most important centers of the Hellenistic world. came in IV – V AD In VIII – IX, the Jewish community flourished again, and Muslim rulers even provided Jews with the opportunity to make a pilgrimage to Jerusalem. In 725, Egyptian Copts revolted against Muslims, crushed by the last 733.In 868, power over Egypt passed into the hands of the Turkic dynasty of Tulunids, but in 905–935 the country fell under the direct rule of the Abbasid caliphs of Baghdad. In 914, the Fatimid army invaded Egypt from Tunisia and occupied Alexandria. By the end of X, Jews were considered the most influential merchants and usurers of both Alexandria and all of Egypt. They held in their hands trade with Arabia and India, and even credited the Fatimid caliphs. Since 1012, the caliph Al-Hakim began to persecute Jews and Christians, many of them were forced to leave Alexandria. After the First cre Many Palestinian Jews settled in the city’s hike.

Alexandria was built according to the plan of the architect Deinocrates. It was the capital of the Ptolemies and one of the most important centers of the Hellenistic world. came in IV – V AD In the eighth and ninth centuries, the Jewish community flourished again, and Muslim rulers even provided Jews with the opportunity to make a pilgrimage to Jerusalem. In 725, Egyptian Copts revolted against the Muslims, crushed by the latter only in 733. In 868, power over Egypt passed into the hands of the Turkic Tulunid dynasty, but in 905–935 the country fell under the direct rule of the Abbasid caliphs of Baghdad. In 914, the Fatimid army invaded Egypt from Tunisia and occupied Alexandria. By the end of X, Jews were considered the most influential merchants and usurers of both Alexandria and all of Egypt. They held in their hands trade with Arabia and India, and even credited the Fatimid caliphs. Since 1012, the caliph Al-Hakim began to persecute Jews and Christians, many of them were forced to leave Alexandria. After the First many Palestinian Jews settled in the city during the crusade.

{king_benghazi}Prince of Barnik (Benghazi)
{king_benghazi_desc}Named Prince of Barnik.\n\nDescription:\nAccording to the testament of Apion Ptolemy, Cyrenaica became a Roman province in 96 BC. In the 20th century BC, the city was incorporated into the Senate province of Crete and Cyrenaica. Berenice flourished by the rule of Rome, and AD III became the center of Cyrenaica. In 431 all Libya, including Cyrenaica, was conquered by vandals and suffered damage. In VI, Berenice fell under the rule of Byzantium. By the order of Justinian I, the walls and public baths were rebuilt. Under the Emperor of Mauritius, Cyrenaica is included in the Egyptian province. Mr. was weak, and the Berber uprisings turned the prosperous territory into a place forgotten by everyone. Islam walked through North Africa without proper resistance. The Roman influence on the region, with the exception of Berenice, was negligible, Byzantium had no support here. According to the Treaty of Alexandria 642, the conquest of Egypt the Arabs ended in victory. On September 17, 642 Alexandria fell, and at the beginning of 643, without resistance, Cyrenaica also. Berenice was already a small settlement in the midst of majestic ruins. In Arabs, the city was called Barnik for a long time MV 1200s settlement has played an important role in the growing trade between Genoese merchants and the tribes of the hinterland.
{king_benghazi_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenue. \n-1 from piety.\n+5% to general’s movement range.

{dearmad_tripoli}Duke of Tripoli
{dearmad_tripoli_desc}Named the Duke of Tripoli.\n\nDescription:\nDate of founding of the city VII BC In VII BC Ea - originally a colony of the Phoenicians. Since 643g. Tripoli: The name comes from the name of the region of Tripolitania, where there were 3 Phoenician colonies of Ea, Sabrat and Leptis Magna, the last two of which were neglected by the period of the Arab conquest. In VII-VI BC. The city of the Phoenicians. In 161. BC, the self-governing city of Ea as part of the Carthaginian Empire, the center of the region of Sirte. 161-106 BC, a semi-independent city as part of Numidia. About 300-450g. AD a local center with its council of the Roman province of Tripolitan with its capital in Leptis Magna. In 450-534 the regional center of the Kingdom of the Vandals. In 534-643 the center of the region is part of the province of Africa of the Byzantine Empire. In 643-909 the administrative center of the Arab Tripolitania, which was part of the province of the caliphate of Ifricius. In 1146-1158 as part of the Norman kingdom.

{king_al-mahdiya}Count of Mahdia
{king_al-mahdiya_desc}Named Earl of Mahdia.\n\nDescription:\nIn the 8th century BC, a Phoenician colony emerged here, which gradually turned into a large trading city that existed for many centuries, having experienced periods of prosperity and decline. In the Roman period, there was an important trading port, the city housed a large Roman garrison. The city owes its name to the caliph Ubaidallah, the ancestor of the Shiite Fatimid dynasty. He was declared Mahdi, that is, the "Savior", called to restore truth and justice on earth. Ubaidallah founded here in 916 the capital of the caliphate formed by him. Subsequently, Mahdia became a stronghold of pirates, who were attracted by both the geographical position of the city and its defenses with walls ten meters thick. The majestic city gates of Scythian el-Kahl (Dark Gate) were built here.
{king_al-mahdiya_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% to tax revenues. \n+1 to agriculture (increases the city’s income from agriculture).
¬----------------------

{dearmad_tunis}Duke of Tunisia
{dearmad_tunis_desc}Named the Duke of Tunisia.\n\nDescription:\nArabs founded the city of Kairouan and began to subjugate the settlements of Christians and Berbers. In 698, Byzantine Carthage, in the place of which Arab Tunisia was built, was destroyed and destroyed by Ibrahim ibn Aglab and his descendants as the Aglabids, ruled Tunisia, Tripolitania and eastern Algeria on behalf of the caliph 800-909. The Aglabid army consisted of descendants of the Arabs-conquerors, converted to Islam Berbers and black slave soldiers. Administrative posts were held by Arab and Persian immigrants, as well as some are Christians and Jews. At the beginning of X, the Ismaili uprising began in Ifrikia. In 909, the Ismaili army occupied the city of Kairouan, where Ubeidallah solemnly proclaimed himself a caliph under the name al-Mahdi. The first years of the new state were marked by long and stubborn attempts to conquer Egypt, center of the Fatimid state. In 1148, the Norman king of Sicily Roger II, with the help of George of Antioch, established his authority over the entire Tunisian coast. Christian Normans were founded in Tunisia under the Normans. In the year 1160, the Normans were driven out by the army of the Moroccan ruler Abd al-Mumin, who founded the Almohad dynasty in Maghreb.
{dearmad_tunis_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% tax revenue.\n+5% trade income.\n+5% legitimacy.\n-5% corruption. 
¬----------------------

In 698, the Byzantine Carthage, on the site of which Arab Tunisia was built, was established and destroyed by Ibrahim ibn Aglab and his descendants, as the Aglabids, they ruled Tunisia, Tripolitania and eastern Algeria on behalf of the caliph 800-909. The Aglabids army consisted of descendants of the Arabs-conquerors, converted to Islam Berbers and black soldiers-slaves. Administrative posts were held by Arab and Persian immigrants, and also not some Christians and Jews. At the beginning of X, the Ismaili uprising began on the territory of Ifricia. In 909, the Ismaili army occupied the city of Kairouan, where Ubeidallah solemnly proclaimed himself a caliph under the name al-Mahdi. The first years of the new state were marked by long and stubborn attempts to conquer Egypt, center of the Fatimid state. In 1148, the Norman king of Sicily Roger II, with the help of George of Antioch, established his authority over the entire Tunisian coast. Christianity was founded in Tunisia under the Normans. Coke and refined way soobscheniya.V 1160godu Normans were driven out by the army of the Moroccan ruler Abd al-Mu'min, who founded in the Maghreb Almohad dynasty.
{odearmad_tunis_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% tax revenue.\n+5% trade income.\n+5% legitimacy.\n-5% corruption. 
¬------------------------------------------------- -----------------
{king_eloued}Count of Constatine
{king_eloued_desc}Named Count of Constantine.\n\nDescription:\nConstantine the city was founded by the Phoenicians, who called it Seva (“Royal city”). Later, under the name of Cirt (meaning “city” in Phoenician) - the city was the capital of Numidia . During the Second Punic War, Scipio completely defeated the army of the Numidian king Sifax near the walls of Cirte. The attack of the Numidian king on the Roman merchants in Cirt served as an excuse for starting the Yugurt war. After the capture of the Romans, Cirta led the union of four African cities faithful to Rome. of Roman merchants, a large part of the population were also Greeks and Carthaginians. Then, within the Roman Empire, Cirta was the center of the province of New Africa (later it was returned the name "Numidia"). In 311 the city was destroyed by Emperor Maxentius during the fighting against Domitius Alexander (former governor of the province of Africa), but was restored in 313 by Constantine the Great (winner Maxentius), who gave his name to the city. Cirte-Constantine for a long time remained the most Latinized city in Africa, while remaining faithful to the imper torus even after the invasion of vandalov.V VII century Constantine was conquered arabami.Pod their rule the city became a major trading tsentrom.V years of peace Constantine traded with Pisa, Genoa and Venice.
{king_eloued_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% tax income.
¬----------------------
{iking_eloued}Emir of Constantine
{iking_eloued_desc}Named Emir of Constantine.\n\nDescription:\nConstantine is a city founded by the Phoenicians who named it Seva (“Royal City”). Later, under the name of Cirt (meaning “city” in Phoenician), the city was the capital of Numidia During the Second Punic War, Scipio completely defeated the army of the Numidian king Sifax near the walls of Circy. The attack of the Numidian king on the Roman merchants in Cirt served as an excuse for starting the Yugurt war. After the capture of the Romans, Cirta led the union of four African cities faithful to Rome. of Roman merchants, a large part of the population were also Greeks and Carthaginians. Then, within the Roman Empire, Cirta was the center of the province of New Africa (later it was returned the name "Numidia"). In 311 the city was destroyed by Emperor Maxentius during the fighting against Domitius Alexander (former governor of the province of Africa), but was restored in 313 by Constantine the Great (winner Maxentius), who gave his name to the city. Cirte-Constantine for a long time remained the most Latinized city in Africa, while remaining faithful to the imper to the Ator even after the invasion of the Vandals. In the 7th century, Constantine was conquered by the Arabs. Under their authority, the city became a major trading center. During the peace years, Constantine traded with Pisa, Genoa and Venice.
{iking_eloued_effects_desc}\nAnch bonus: \n+5% tax income.
